This was one of my favorite historic sites to see in Seoul. I would recommend seeing this for yourself. Some of the women dress up in Hanbok to take photos inside. Near local subways stations or you can catch a cab.

I don’t want to miss Gyeongbokgung Palace because it is the oldest and largest Seoul’s palace. The entrance fee is only 3,000 won but if you want to experience wearing Hanbok or Traditional dress you can rent for 30,000won + you can get a free entry discount. One more thing, don’t miss to watch the Royal Guard Changing Ceremonies. It is a great opportunity to experience a rare traditional scene in Korea.

There are several palaces in Seoul opened to the public. Gyeongbokgung is perhaps one of the more popular. Comparatively it does have more interesting structure. Of all the palaces I visit, Gyeongbokgung has activities that bring Korean culture closer to the visitors. Overall definitely one of the palace you should visit if palaces is on your agenda.

This is a huge palace that has been restored by a fire in the past. If you exit from the train station Gwanghwamun, you will be awed by a huge golden statue of King Sejong placed in the square outside the palace gate. Turn around and you will see the statue of a soldier guarding the whole place.The admission cost KRW3000. You could get to witness the Change of Guards ceremony at a certain time.Take your time to explore the splendour and architecture.
Rented a hanbok and was able to enter the palace for free. Joined the on-site tour in English and it was good :) Enjoyed the guard-changing ceremony too!

I was there with friend after our work it's amazing and beautiful.we very much enjoy wearing costumes hanbox a traditional Korea Stye where u can find rent from outside palace cost approx 15000-20000 won its so nice to get this experience and you don't have to pay for entrance fee if you are in the costume. There is parade for guards exchanges which is very interesting too. We spend almost half day there it really a wonderful time☺️

It's a nice palace, but there is nothing that describes the buildings or the history of it.I was hoping that it would provide some detailed history of the buildings and not just where people take pictures ONLY.

I decided to immerse myself in at least one major attraction (ended up with three), and this was the crown jewel. Not only were the buildings beautiful and fascinating, but on the day I visited, there were parades and demonstrations by costumed employees. It is hard to fathom the life the Koreans have been under, given near-continuous wars and occupations, but this palace does give the visitor a feeling of the grandeur of the country at peace. I would recommend this, as well as the neighboring museums, for a deep appreciation of the people, their politeness and hospitality, despite many years of turmoil.

We took the English tour. Included in the admission. The tour was well done explaining the history and pointing out many items you wouldn't notice on your own. Mostly outside, so it is best to go on a nice day.

We took the metro to Gyeongbokgung station and exited at exit 5. This will bring you to the left side entrance of the palace. The palace is huge so put on some good walking shoes to fully explore the entire compound. We arrived just in time for the changing of guards ceremony at 1100hrs which is a real highlight of our visit as we got to see the colorful and meaningful ceremony (commentary in English and mandarin is played on the PA System) explaining the ongoings. We then took some time to pose with the guards (warning no touching of their clothes or bodies when posing with them.) You will then need to buy tickets to access the inner section of the palace and pls note that washrooms are after the ticket booth somewhere in the middle section of the palace compound. We had to do a long detour back after we exited the compound. There are lot of locals and tourists in traditional hanbok dress who have purposely dressed up or rented outfits somewhere outside posing for photos throughout the palace. So incase you want to catch photos of someone in traditional dress. Also there is a hanbok dress up rental within the palace incase you want to join them. A must visit for a chance to see old Korean historical building and ceremonies.

Caught the changing of guards. It was very well executed. Fun taking photos with the 'guards'. The palace is big and impressive. There is also a folk museum. It is of high quality. The children folk museum is also fun. The exhibits are interactive and well designed. Really surprised that for such a nice place it is free to visit for all.

I don’t want to miss Gyeongbokgung Palace because it is the oldest and largest Seoul’s palace. The entrance fee is only 3,000 won but if you want to experience wearing Hanbok or Traditional dress you can rent for 30,000won + you can get a free entry discount. One more thing, don’t miss to watch the Royal Guard Changing Ceremonies. It is a great opportunity to experience a rare traditional scene in Korea.

There are several palaces in Seoul opened to the public. Gyeongbokgung is perhaps one of the more popular. Comparatively it does have more interesting structure. Of all the palaces I visit, Gyeongbokgung has activities that bring Korean culture closer to the visitors. Overall definitely one of the palace you should visit if palaces is on your agenda.

This is a huge palace that has been restored by a fire in the past. If you exit from the train station Gwanghwamun, you will be awed by a huge golden statue of King Sejong placed in the square outside the palace gate. Turn around and you will see the statue of a soldier guarding the whole place.The admission cost KRW3000. You could get to witness the Change of Guards ceremony at a certain time.Take your time to explore the splendour and architecture.
Rented a hanbok and was able to enter the palace for free. Joined the on-site tour in English and it was good :) Enjoyed the guard-changing ceremony too!

I was there with friend after our work it's amazing and beautiful.we very much enjoy wearing costumes hanbox a traditional Korea Stye where u can find rent from outside palace cost approx 15000-20000 won its so nice to get this experience and you don't have to pay for entrance fee if you are in the costume. There is parade for guards exchanges which is very interesting too. We spend almost half day there it really a wonderful time☺️

It's a nice palace, but there is nothing that describes the buildings or the history of it.I was hoping that it would provide some detailed history of the buildings and not just where people take pictures ONLY.

I decided to immerse myself in at least one major attraction (ended up with three), and this was the crown jewel. Not only were the buildings beautiful and fascinating, but on the day I visited, there were parades and demonstrations by costumed employees. It is hard to fathom the life the Koreans have been under, given near-continuous wars and occupations, but this palace does give the visitor a feeling of the grandeur of the country at peace. I would recommend this, as well as the neighboring museums, for a deep appreciation of the people, their politeness and hospitality, despite many years of turmoil.

We took the English tour. Included in the admission. The tour was well done explaining the history and pointing out many items you wouldn't notice on your own. Mostly outside, so it is best to go on a nice day.

We took the metro to Gyeongbokgung station and exited at exit 5. This will bring you to the left side entrance of the palace. The palace is huge so put on some good walking shoes to fully explore the entire compound. We arrived just in time for the changing of guards ceremony at 1100hrs which is a real highlight of our visit as we got to see the colorful and meaningful ceremony (commentary in English and mandarin is played on the PA System) explaining the ongoings. We then took some time to pose with the guards (warning no touching of their clothes or bodies when posing with them.) You will then need to buy tickets to access the inner section of the palace and pls note that washrooms are after the ticket booth somewhere in the middle section of the palace compound. We had to do a long detour back after we exited the compound. There are lot of locals and tourists in traditional hanbok dress who have purposely dressed up or rented outfits somewhere outside posing for photos throughout the palace. So incase you want to catch photos of someone in traditional dress. Also there is a hanbok dress up rental within the palace incase you want to join them. A must visit for a chance to see old Korean historical building and ceremonies.

Caught the changing of guards. It was very well executed. Fun taking photos with the 'guards'. The palace is big and impressive. There is also a folk museum. It is of high quality. The children folk museum is also fun. The exhibits are interactive and well designed. Really surprised that for such a nice place it is free to visit for all.

The Palace ground is big, There are Korean's who dress in their national costumes who look so beautiful. At the ticket area, you will find some people who want to be a free guide to you to speak english. They will explain to you the history of the Palace. Inside there is also a National Palace Musem of Korea. Take note that the guard changing ceremony is at 10.00 am & 14.00pm. The guard duty performance is @ 11.00 & 13.00pm .

Reconstructed palace of history. What a peaceful spot in the middle of a large and vibrant city. Kit yourself out in Hanbok costume for free entry or just pay and enjoy the delightful show. Koreans love this place. The costumes enliven and lighten the wide open spaces. The further you enter into the site, the nearer you get to the mountains. Delightful and a must see.

The palace grounds is very huge, and it is a great place for photo taking. Many tourists and locals, as well as students, visit the palace daily. The palace guards changing ceremony was interesting. It took place at around noon time. A small entrance fee is required to visit the palace.
Nice place to visit. Reminiscing the Korean dramas....Make sure to bring gadgets for picture takings. So many nice spots.

Suggest to go visit during the morning or later in the afternoon. We went just after lunch and it was a really hot day at 30 degree Celsius. We were so tired and thirsty and have to rest every now and then after 30mins walking or so. Bring a cap/hat, sunglasses and water if you do go during summer or hot day! Palace is huge and will be even more pretty I believe during the Autumn period. One can spend at least 3 hours covering the whole palace so it will be good to go during a cooler day. We did not wait for the guided tour as we did expect to spend more than 2 hours in the palace which in the end we did due to much walking and resting!

This is a large complex of restored palace buildings that also includes two stand-alone museums, each of which would be a worthwhile attraction in their own right. The combination could easily occupy half a day or more and provides a great combination of history, art, and architecture. The one sight to see even with only a short time in Seoul. Be aware that there are restoration works going on regularly, so there will be some construction fencing and inaccessible areas.The changing of the guard "show" takes place in the main courtyard and so does not require admission--handy if you "miss" it due to schedule or weather and want to do it separately.It is possible to combine it with the two "C" palaces in the area, but that would be a lot of walking and maybe an overload on "restored palace" experience.

This palace is impressive and has been restored well. It is one of the busiest palaces so we went in the morning to avoid crowds. The buildings are beautiful but there is barely any information. I highly suggest either reading up about the structures online or hiring a guide to take you around the site. Without either of these things we were left stuck looking at buildings and wondering their purposes. Additionally, spend the small extra for a multi ticket as you can see other nearby palaces with it.

It's a smaller scale palace compared to other countries. But it's a good place to learn Korea history. Free guided tour offered in English inside the palace, check the official website for the schedules. The free tour's duration is about an hour.

The attraction is very well maintained. There are many tourists going around here. You will see many people wearing hanbok. This is quite interesting, and do not forget to watch the ceremony on the changing of the guards.

This is one of several places you need to visit, learn about the different kingdoms, and how one king united the country preWWI, see the changing of the guards, and enjoy the beautiful view of the palace offers

The Palace ground is big, There are Korean's who dress in their national costumes who look so beautiful. At the ticket area, you will find some people who want to be a free guide to you to speak english. They will explain to you the history of the Palace. Inside there is also a National Palace Musem of Korea. Take note that the guard changing ceremony is at 10.00 am & 14.00pm. The guard duty performance is @ 11.00 & 13.00pm .

We did not wait for the guided tour as we did expect to spend more than 2 hours in the palace which in the end we did due to much walking and resting!

I highly suggest either reading up about the structures online or hiring a guide to take you around the site. Without either of these things we were left stuck looking at buildings and wondering their purposes. Additionally, spend the small extra for a multi ticket as you can see other nearby palaces with it.

The attraction is very well maintained. There are many tourists going around here. You will see many people wearing hanbok. This is quite interesting, and do not forget to watch the ceremony on the changing of the guards.

This is one of several places you need to visit, learn about the different kingdoms, and how one king united the country preWWI, see the changing of the guards, and enjoy the beautiful view of the palace offers

Sprawling Palace complex reconstructed based ancient documents, it is very interesting to see, but we would not have known what we were looking at, or the lifestyle and other interesting aspects of it if not for the guide we had. A good look at their ancient past.

If you only plan to see 1 Palace, this should be it because it is like the other main palaces, except huge, it takes a few hours to fully appreciate everything. Be sure to see an event with the guards, it's very interesting. Additionally you will see a lot of people wearing the traditional hanbok.
The palace is worth the visit for its unique oriental buildings and its change of guards which matches that at the Buckingham palace. The rooms are empty so don't expect to see fine interiors.

Came to see the Palace with my sister. Soooooo pretty and the weather was perfect. We loved it. There's a museum as well as a lot of people doing reenactments. It is a fair amount of walking and some stairs.

Expect a lot of outdoor walking as this palace consist of many separate buildings. So go on a sunny day if you want great photos or a cloudy day if you don't like constant exposure in the sun. You can watch the changing of the guards just outside of the palace as well but personally I didn't think it was that spectacular. There are several free guided tours in various languages each day which I highly recommend as it gives you a little bit of background of the palace including some interesting facts. It lasts for an hour or so and afterwards you will still get plenty of time to explore the place yourself. There are plenty of nice photo spots especially if you're in Hanbok (the traditional Korean clothing). Btw if you're dressed in Hanbok you get into the palace for free. Including the guided tour we spent around 2.5 hours there.
In the morning you can view the changing of the guards, then you can walk around the site and imagine yourself back then.

This palace is one of many, but only one must to see. Plan to use half of day to move around and get inspired by great culture. Best time to visit is outside summer months since it's quite hot and crowded this period. Easy to get there by subway since it's located just downtown if city. After that can connect with leisure walking around the city.

If you must visit a pavilion or palace, consider making the trip to Gyeongbokgung. Even when we visited on a rainy day, it was still worth it. The palace is humongous in proportion, and is right in front of the National Museum of Korea. I was aware that parts of Gyeongbokgung are already reconstructions from the original, but the scale is still astounding. You'll be swept away with the sights and ambiance of Korea's past dynasties. There are so many photo taking opportunities too, especially if you look around the nearby city for Hanbok rentals. If you're more into the history of the palace, there are English audio guide rentals for solo travelers and walking tours in Chinese and English. I absolutely adore this landmark and I feel like I haven't seen enough of it to truly understand its complexity. This is a must-visit!

The grounds are mostly outdoors and the palace/throne rooms are even more open air. It takes a while to cover the area and I wish there was more educational value to the location. The changing of the guard ceremony was neat.

Not far from the National Museum this Palace is set in very attractive gardens where the atmosphere is both clam and peaceful. Dating back over 600years it is still used today and we were told that it was the venue of a high level meeting involving major international dignitaries not too long ago. The pagoda style is typically Korean and although the building itself may only be of interest for a short period of time the grounds are well worth a visit.

Sprawling Palace complex reconstructed based ancient documents, it is very interesting to see, but we would not have known what we were looking at, or the lifestyle and other interesting aspects of it if not for the guide we had. A good look at their ancient past.

The pagoda style is typically Korean and although the building itself may only be of interest for a short period of time the grounds are well worth a visit.

We only got their around 3pm, and felt as though as we had to rush to see everything (and not get lost in the process!). Tea rooms were closing. There are walls within walls. We were heading to find the water feature, only to eventually find we'd been circumnavigating it: it was behind temporary walls for renovation!

Must see place to visit allow a couple of hours here to take in the culture, history and wander around exploring. The guards at the front seem to be more a tourist attraction with their stick on beards and more a part time job than others I have seen in London etc. Don't let this put you off thou as once inside you get to see and learn about the history of Gyeongbokgung Palace. Do make sure you take the free tour lasting just over an hour will give you a good insight into its history and best of all it is free, if you dress traditionally thou it is free entry, great to see so many doing it certainly adds to the atmosphere. Like most places in Seoul it was cheap admission and certainly worth the cost.
It's worth to get up early to watch the live Royal Guard changing ceremony and the free guided tours. The Korean female guides are very professional and patient in their sharing. Worth visiting!

We went here in traditional Hanbok (so you get in for free!). We brought ours but you can hire them in stores near to the Palace. Its a fun experience to walk round in Hanbok as you can imagine days past where the royalty would be walking round in those types of clothes. The museum areas are really informative and the palace is just beautiful. I would definitely recommend going if you are in Seoul.

This place is really busy at times, that busy that it is hard to get a good photo, it is pretty big to so make sure you have good walking shoes on and take water, you can not miss the changing of the guards at 11am 1pm and 3pm it good to watch.

A giant palace which many get lost easily if you don't have a guide or a map. Buildings are similar across the whole palace with minor differences. It would be great if you have a guide with you as many things they mentioned was not easily discovered by tourists.

I went with my sister when she came to visit me in Korea. I have been there many times before but it was the first time I attended the tour. This place is absolutely beautiful and the tour was very informative. Also went to the tea restaurant and had tea inside the palace which was an amazing experience. I felt very traditional!
Went 2 hours before closing and had more than enough time to see everything we wanted to. If you want a guided tour go early but a I don't think it is needed
Even if you have only very limited time, this is a must see. Very impressive and built to last. Takes 1-2 hours.

It's nice to visit here! you can try Korean traditional clothing nearby that you can get in the palace without admission fee. The palace is so big that you might need to spend whole morning here. Seeing their traditional building and have some pictures here are truly fun!

We only got their around 3pm, and felt as though as we had to rush to see everything (and not get lost in the process!). Tea rooms were closing. There are walls within walls. This place is absolutely beautiful and the tour was very informative. Also went to the tea restaurant and had tea inside the palace which was an amazing experience. I felt very traditional!
Went 2 hours before closing and had more than enough time to see everything we wanted to. If you want a guided tour go early but a I don't think it is needed
Even if you have only very limited time, this is a must see. Very impressive and built to last. Takes 1-2 hours.

It's nice to visit here! you can try Korean traditional clothing nearby that you can get in the palace without admission fee. The palace is so big that you might need to spend whole morning here. Seeing their traditional building and have some pictures here are truly fun!

The palace was great place to go. It is quite extensive and we took one of the free tours in English, which was offered at the museum, and was very informative. Our tour guide was Korean but spoke e cel lent English. We visited on "Culture Day", which is the last Wednesday of every month when admission to museums are free so that was great. Highly recommend to visit if in Seoul!
I visited Changdeokgung palace and this one and I definitely recommend this one if you only have time for one. We enjoyed watching the changing of guards and it had more structures to see.

First time coming to Korea with my husband. Always wish to try the Hanbok and finally i wore one. We were accompanied by our friend that stay in seoul. We went there by public bus and walk to the shop area to rent the hanbok with price KRW10.000 for 2 hours. If we wear hanbok then the entrance fee is free. We strolling around the palace and there were some music performance from the youngster which was really nice but we missed the changing guard ceremony as we arrived there at 15:00.

When visiting Seoul, it is necessary to tour palaces. I toured all of the palaces in Seoul. My conclusion, if you see one of the palaces, you have seen them all. That said, I still believe it is necessary to visit all the palaces as it is a one time experience. Gyeongbokgung's changing of the guard isn't too exciting, but still interesting.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is much more like a series of palaces within a palace. The majesty you feel when you walk in builds as you walk through its various inner palaces - as does the sense of wonder of how yet another suite of royal accommodations could be so impressively sited seemingly in total privacy despite being in a huge complex. And if you walk around the outer wall before entering you'll come across first a series of Mom&Pop hawker joints to eat in (recommended, they are full of personality and very honest, local food) and then some trendier renovated lanes full of boutiques and the like. Do make the effort to fully explore not just the palace, but everything there is around it.

If you go there in the morning,(around 10) you can see the changing of the guard. Then you can walk around until 11, and at 11 an english 1 hour tour starts and they can tell you all the history and stuff.
If you are a history buff, I recommend doing a guided tour. There is plenty of history to be explored. I recommend watching the change of guard.
A glance into Korean history. Super huge and pretty palace. It was once damaged during japanese invasion period but it was rebuilt..

Enjoyed walking and enjoying the sights and architecture, especially with visitors in Hanbok around. After awhile the buildings all sort of look the same. Appreciated those temporary exhibitions within the grounds.
Go there in the morning and catch the "Changing of the Royal Guards" which starts at 10 a.m. before exploring the large palace buildings. They are no less than stunning.

The palace was great place to go. It is quite extensive and we took one of the free tours in English, which was offered at the museum, and was very informative. Our tour guide was Korean but spoke e cel lent English. We visited on "Culture Day", which is the last Wednesday of every month when admission to museums are free so that was great. Highly recommend to visit if in Seoul!
I visited Changdeokgung palace and this one and I definitely recommend this one if you only have time for one. We enjoyed watching the changing of guards and it had more structures to see.

If you are a history buff, I recommend doing a guided tour. There is plenty of history to be explored. I recommend watching the change of guard.
A glance into Korean history. Super huge and pretty palace. It was once damaged during japanese invasion period but it was rebuilt..

Enjoyed walking and enjoying the sights and architecture, especially with visitors in Hanbok around. After awhile the buildings all sort of look the same. Appreciated those temporary exhibitions within the grounds.
Go there in the morning and catch the "Changing of the Royal Guards" which starts at 10 a.m. before exploring the large palace buildings. They are no less than stunning.

This place is much better to walk around coz its way less crowded. its a big facility as well so be prepared for lots of walking. Take photos with the soldier in ancient uniform at the front gate and also a demonstration from the soldiers as well
Definitely worth a visit when in Seoul. Very interesting and very well preserved for a small entrance fee. Try to see the changing of the guard ceremony - excellent to watch!

It is one of main palaces located in heart of Seoul city. Connected well by Seoul metro. Has a museum attached to it. Behind the palace you can visit folk museum where traditional Korean folk dance are exhibited

one of the top-things-to-do in seoul on websites and travel guidebooks.it's good and fun.a lot of locals and tourist wearing hanbok,huge complex so it'll take some time.there's also a guard-changing ceremony that you can watch. and its cool..

It's a awesome and magistic place. You can walk around and explore this gigantic place by your self. Guide's are also good but according to me no need for that. Many things are in English and you don't need to know much if you only want to see the palace....how the kings and queens lived. It's a big place....i listened to music and walked around!. After I visited the palace museum that is free and nice to see. I also visited the teahouse inside the palace and drank one of the kings favourite tea against illness it was a nice experience! If you like culture....then you must visit this place...u won't regret it!
You just can't go to Seoul and not visit this place. Such a beautiful palace and entry is not expensive. Very big place so reserve at less half a day here.
I enjoyed it. I went on a Sunday and many families and couples were there dressed in their traditional garments. It was fun!
Made me feel transported back to the time of the old Korean dynasty with a view of the palace, surroundings, the royal guards, and the heat! Nostalgic moment.
We enjoyed the history of this Palace. The changing of guards is fun to watch. The people coming to visit have an opportunity to dress in costume dresses to visit the Palace. Completely awesome!!!!

We came here as part of a shore excursion on a cruise. The buildings and grounds are very interesting. I don't remember if there was much signage so you may need a guide to interpret what you are seeing. There were many young people roaming the grounds in traditional Korean dress and you can pose for pictures with them. I found that very cool and I enjoyed my time here. There were not a lot of inside things to see, just peering through a door.

This place is much better to walk around coz its way less crowded. its a big facility as well so be prepared for lots of walking. Take photos with the soldier in ancient uniform at the front gate and also a demonstration from the soldiers as well
Definitely worth a visit when in Seoul. Very interesting and very well preserved for a small entrance fee. Try to see the changing of the guard ceremony - excellent to watch!

It is one of main palaces located in heart of Seoul city. Connected well by Seoul metro. Has a museum attached to it. Behind the palace you can visit folk museum where traditional Korean folk dance are exhibited

one of the top-things-to-do in seoul on websites and travel guidebooks.it's good and fun.a lot of locals and tourist wearing hanbok,huge complex so it'll take some time.there's also a guard-changing ceremony that you can watch. and its cool..

It's a awesome and magistic place. You can walk around and explore this gigantic place by your self. Guide's are also good but according to me no need for that. Many things are in English and you don't need to know much if you only want to see the palace....how the kings and queens lived. It's a big place....i listened to music and walked around!. After I visited the palace museum that is free and nice to see. I also visited the teahouse inside the palace and drank one of the kings favourite tea against illness it was a nice experience! If you like culture....then you must visit this place...u won't regret it!
You just can't go to Seoul and not visit this place. Such a beautiful palace and entry is not expensive. Very big place so reserve at less half a day here.
I enjoyed it. I went on a Sunday and many families and couples were there dressed in their traditional garments. It was fun!
Made me feel transported back to the time of the old Korean dynasty with a view of the palace, surroundings, the royal guards, and the heat! Nostalgic moment.
We enjoyed the history of this Palace. The changing of guards is fun to watch. The people coming to visit have an opportunity to dress in costume dresses to visit the Palace. Completely awesome!!!!

We came here as part of a shore excursion on a cruise. The buildings and grounds are very interesting. I don't remember if there was much signage so you may need a guide to interpret what you are seeing. There were many young people roaming the grounds in traditional Korean dress and you can pose for pictures with them. I found that very cool and I enjoyed my time here. There were not a lot of inside things to see, just peering through a door.
Downtown. It's seem have to visit this place before you visiting another place tourism. No wifi, Clean, clear signage, family.

Rent a hanbok from any of the hanbok stores nearby and get a ticket for free at the booth from the side. Otherwise you would have to pay a fee. Take pretty pictures with the hanbok though it might be hot wearing it.

It is a must see attraction in Seoul that every visitors should pay a visit here. However if you are not immensly interested in history, peeping in through the front door is fine since every palace look exactly the same.

Huge open and garden area to walk and must love the architectural work to be indpired. You can have pictures takenwith the guards at entrance. Beautiful area to wonder and see the museum and new President building but don't lose your entrance ticket to re-enter the palace ground. Also the temple building just above the museum. Worth the visit and canter around the palace ground plus the emper throne. Enjoy the magnificent architecture.
Outstanding museum attached to the palace. The grounds and palace were very interesting. Took lots of photos.

As Korea and Chinese has similar cultures, if you had been to Forbidden City in Beijing,then this is a dwarf version. However, if this is your first time in Korea, it would be recommended. One can tell that they put in a lot of effort to make the place interesting by adding a lot of cultural experience for tourist. Overall it's fun and entertaining and worth the visit!
It was great place to see the history of Korea- Josun Dynasty including good time and sad time. (the last King of Josen Dynasty)

Gyeongbokgung is the main among "Five Grand Palaces" in Seoul – Changdeokgung, Changgyeonggung, Deoksugung and Gyeonghuigung. But! Its rival -Changdeokgung became UNESCO World Heritage from 1997. Why didn`t Gyeongbokgung become despite its historical meaning? Thanks to its history! It was twice destroyed by the Japanese during the invasion and occupation. Last time Japanese destroyed it as the symbol of national independence and sovereign power. That`s why most buildings inside are rather new. Not restored but built again. Palace is closed eaurly at 5.00. p.m. That`s why I could visit it just with 3rd attemt. We`ve lost 1-st day in Seoul due to Jetlag, 2-nd and 3rg days I arrived from Namhanseong and Suwon just at closure. I arrived just in time for the closing. And only in the morning before leaving for Busan, I was able to come almost to the opening. It was a weekend and the Babylonian pandemonium was in the Palace. But mostly Koreans participated in Babylonian pandemonium. According to the traditional attitudes of the tourist to look at the Palace of nothing. No furniture. Sculptures no. Paintings either. In short, not Versailles, and not the Hermitage. If this is your first Palace, a slight disappointment or confusion can not be. I already had one Palace of the big five and 2 UNESCO world heritage in Suwon and Namhansanseong, so I was not surprised. Once ambivalent sense it is necessary to visit: Gangnyeongjeon (King's Quarters), Geunjeongjeon (Throne Hall), Gyeonghoeru (Royal Banquet Hall), Gyotaejeon (Queen's Quarters). They are almost the same. But next place will be romantic - Hyangwonjeong Pavilion near small lake. After that I would recommend to turn to right (East) and visit Korean folk museum. You`ll able to understand that the technological victories of Samsung, LG and Hundai on the world markets are not random, but prepared by the whole history of Korea. Entrance ticket is the same as in Gyeongbokgung.

a must visit when travelling to Seoul. As Joseon dynasty's main palace, it is one of the most preserved palace, beside Changdeokgung. It is always packed with tourist. you can visit the palace for free if you wear hanbok. To learn more about its history, you are suggested to join the palace guided tour.

This was the second time I was here because of night entry. From 19:00 - 21:30 you could wander around the palace for night scenes. There were not a lot to see but the most important thing was to see the building above the lake. The mot stunning view I saw in Seoul. Definitely can't miss the chance for night entry!
Downtown. It's seem have to visit this place before you visiting another place tourism. No wifi, Clean, clear signage, family.

Beautiful area to wonder and see the museum and new President building but don't lose your entrance ticket to re-enter the palace ground. Also the temple building just above the museum. Worth the visit and canter around the palace ground plus the emper throne. Enjoy the magnificent architecture.
Outstanding museum attached to the palace. The grounds and palace were very interesting. Took lots of photos.

One can tell that they put in a lot of effort to make the place interesting by adding a lot of cultural experience for tourist. Overall it's fun and entertaining and worth the visit!

It is always packed with tourist. you can visit the palace for free if you wear hanbok. To learn more about its history, you are suggested to join the palace guided tour.

This was the second time I was here because of night entry. From 19:00 - 21:30 you could wander around the palace for night scenes. There were not a lot to see but the most important thing was to see the building above the lake. The mot stunning view I saw in Seoul. Definitely can't miss the chance for night entry!
Very scenic view for couples to stroll around. The spring Breeze and setting sun makes it so relaxing to walk! Should drop by the national folk museum of Korea as well since it just beside.

This palace is highly accessible to those who visit Seoul. The palace has many features that both shared with other traditional Asian architecture, and also unique for Korea. Like many other grand structures built by hand in other parts of the world, this palace made me feel in awe over the engineering and human effort required to erect such a building. Worth a relatively quick 1 to 2-hour visit for first-timers to Korea.
Historic Palace in central Seoul on all the standard tours so you won't miss out seeing it, very enjoyable

One of the things that I look forward to when I visit the country is the overall cultural experience. A lot of countries today are so westernized and modernized that they lose the culture and what is their country is known for.But for Seoul it is intact. The palaces and its history are preserved. Must see when in South Korea!

It is a beautiful place and good to learn about their cultures. You will be in best experience if you rent a hanbok from nearby store and visit around the palace, I felt like I was in Korean drama, had a lot of Instagram shots ;)
A must if you visit Seoul! The views and the palace is heavenly. Try to go on weekday as so many people are there on weekend and hard to see the performances!
We visited the Palace in the morning where there were no crowds yet. There were several buildings to walk by. We were awed by the guards ceremony. Amazing! So surreal!

If you plan to do just one palace in Seoul do this one. It's quite nice and grand. I'm general palaces in Korea and China are not as lavish as in India but it's worth a visit. Best if you go wearing a local Korean dress which you can rent just outside the palace

Plenty to see here . Maybe the first thing people look at in Seoul . It gives some history and there are many shrines or temples around . Where the royal family used to live and in 1895 where the Queen was brutally murdered by the Japanese . Maybe 30 houses around and a change of guard on display at entrance . Price is cheap to gain entrance . And worth it Also you can drink tea inside one of the buildings - looks like a tea ceremony Many dressed up in traditional dress here .

Sunny day to walk, lot of visitors with hanbok (Korean traditional clothes) which you can hire from 15000 won for 4 hours, you can find the shops closed by to hire the clothes, inside the palace have a lot of places for photoshoot, it's a nice day out.
Very scenic view for couples to stroll around. The spring Breeze and setting sun makes it so relaxing to walk! Should drop by the national folk museum of Korea as well since it just beside.

Like many other grand structures built by hand in other parts of the world, this palace made me feel in awe over the engineering and human effort required to erect such a building. Worth a relatively quick 1 to 2-hour visit for first-timers to Korea.
Historic Palace in central Seoul on all the standard tours so you won't miss out seeing it, very enjoyable

We visited the Palace in the morning where there were no crowds yet. There were several buildings to walk by. We were awed by the guards ceremony. Amazing! So surreal!

If you plan to do just one palace in Seoul do this one. It's quite nice and grand. I'm general palaces in Korea and China are not as lavish as in India but it's worth a visit. Best if you go wearing a local Korean dress which you can rent just outside the palace

Plenty to see here . Maybe the first thing people look at in Seoul . It gives some history and there are many shrines or temples around . Where the royal family used to live and in 1895 where the Queen was brutally murdered by the Japanese . Maybe 30 houses around and a change of guard on display at entrance . Price is cheap to gain entrance . And worth it Also you can drink tea inside one of the buildings - looks like a tea ceremony Many dressed up in traditional dress here .

Sunny day to walk, lot of visitors with hanbok (Korean traditional clothes) which you can hire from 15000 won for 4 hours, you can find the shops closed by to hire the clothes, inside the palace have a lot of places for photoshoot, it's a nice day out.

This is definitely one place to visit. The main palace with the changing of the Guards in the morning. Changing of the Guards is a really colorful ceremony with Drums, cymbals and oriental trumpets. The palace is large but relatively new in that it was only restored in the last 150 years but rebuilt using traditional methods. here are some tips, do consider buying the Combo ticket if you are planning to visit two or more palaces. its cheaper using a combo ticket. a second tip, the combo ticket includes a visit to the secret gardens at Gyeongbuk kung. The Secret gardens are not open to the public, even with a Combo ticket. you have to reserve a place and then only be able to get in with a secret garden ticket or the combo ticket. The secret garden is quite magical . we booked about 6 days in advance. the ticket reservation opened at midnight and by the time of 8am the next day all reservations had gone. So stay up and book at midnight. :)

This Palace was located in a park which I would recommend going to see. The day we went was snowing and cold, but I think that only added to the atmosphere. While there were people there, the park was rather serene save for some passing tour groups. You couldn't go in the palace, understandably, but its good for a picture.

The palace was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty. Built in 1395, located in northern Seoul, South Korea.The place was very beautiful and it was mesmerizing soaking on the beauty of it. Take a slow walk and take lots of photos.
Enjoyed the visit here since it showcases the history and beautiful culture of Korea! Must visit especially first timers!

If you can try to time your arrival to see the changing of the guard by the main gate. Its easy ti forget yoh are in a busy mordern city as you spend a couple of hours exploring the buildings and gardens in the palace grounds. Its well worth getting a guide to walk you through. Lical residents dress up in traditional costume which adds colour and charm to the experience. my puctures tell a better story than what I can describe. Well worth the visit

Have been to gyeongbokgung few times. This is a really nice place to visit. My family loves it a lot as you can try on hanbuk for free and takes pictures in front of the gyeongbokgung. Not sure if they still have this service now. Anyways, its a great place that highly recommended.

I've seen other palaces in Seoul but this one has a different beauty and character. You will imagine how grandeous of this palace in the past. You can see how the rulers lived and how they were served by their attendants. Somehow interesting. The gardens and the view of the mountain made the scenery more beautiful. It is a relaxing place to stop and reflect for a moment. You will consider the garden view as romantic, too.

A palace in a city. I was stayed near City Hall subway. I was walking about 10 minutes to the Palace. If you are wearing Hanbok located outside the Palace (nearby shop houses, the rental price usually KRW 10,000 for 2 hours), then the entrance fee to the Palace would be waived, or else per pax for adult would be KRW 3,000 as listed on Korea Tourism website. However, I bought 3 adult ticket at KRW 4,500 on Sunday, which I don't know the reason why cheaper. There were some flea market stalls located all along the way to GwangHuaMen (I guess only available on Sunday).
Basically a palace with an admission fee. If you're not fond of historic places, you may explore other areas. This is a walking distance from Gwanghwamun Square as well.

Large palace that requires several hours to walk around the grounds and see the different buildings.Interesting to see the ancient palace grounds and gain some insight into Korean history. The grounds are well-maintained and clean. Can be crowded at times. When we went they had some sections of the palace sectioned off for renovation/restoration.Somewhat disappointing in that it seems the vast majority of the palace structures were all recreations. Personally, I would prefer to have the actual historical structures, but just roped/sectioned off to prevent damage from tourists.Regardless, we're glad to have visited the palace and thinks it's worthwhile to go when in Seoul.

Personally, I would prefer to have the actual historical structures, but just roped/sectioned off to prevent damage from tourists.Regardless, we're glad to have visited the palace and thinks it's worthwhile to go when in Seoul.
The palace is a beautiful oasis in the middle of a large, modern city, sparking your imagination eith ideas of what life must have been like 600 years ago in Korea, when kings ruled the country.

One of the more popular palaces in Seoul, and it is a short walking to another travellers place known as Bukchon Village. Enter via the main entrance and you can see 'guards' dressed up in ancient times standing still, 'welcoming' you to it.

The palace guide was very methodical and informative, patiently relating each facet of ancient palace life, especially how the rulers lived. Snippets of stories to make the narrative interesting. Brought us to the various buildings and gardens, explaining as we went along. Even waited for stragglers to gather before she continued.

Great and well maintained palace and grounds. Very clean and pleasant with so many Koreans dressed in their traditional clothes. Recommend accepting the school-children guides, they do it for school credits, are well informed and give you a really interesting tour of the palace. The guides do it voluntarily and do not accept any money, not even when you offer to at least buy them a drink. Interesting history. Recommend when visiting Seoul.

To explore the whole surrounding you need at least 2-3 hours. Very wide and cool fresh ambiance around the palace. So many tourists when we went there. You can rent Hanbok dress outside but my daughter did not like to wear it coz it's thick & itchy. We walked about 10 to 15 minutes to reach the Blue house which is at the back of the palace. But very nice to explore

Bf was excited looking at the guard swapping. It's a cultural program with volunteers dressing up in ancient outfits. What amazed me was how many men and women walked around through the garden taking selfies in beautiful traditional Korean clothes. Apparently you can rent them somewhere. A lot of couples in love taking romantic pictures. There's a cafe and another museum within.

Wonderful palace to see. Take a guide as you will miss so much without one. Went into the King court and bumped my head on the curved rock for the doorway. Please watch out for the as my head still hurts.

Very popular palace grounds for tourists and history or drama-loving locals wishing to experience romantic or glamorous moments as a palace maid, concubine or princess. Costume rentals are available nearby for about 20000 won for 4 hours. An open traditional musical song-dance troupe performs nearby followed by free photo sessions.

This was my second time at Gyeongbokgung Palace. The 1st time was on a tour so we didn't get to see some parts of it. It's a beautiful place to visit which has lots of history & great place to take photos as well.

the must do in seoul, entrance cost 3000won (3$)really typical and nice,one tip : nowadays there are korean teenagers students (wearing yellow clothe) they can guide you around the palace for free. they just want to communicate in english, they speak english perfectly for teenagers, so do it, if someone ask you to get a student guide, just say yes!

Costume rentals are available nearby for about 20000 won for 4 hours. An open traditional musical song-dance troupe performs nearby followed by free photo sessions.

This was my second time at Gyeongbokgung Palace. The 1st time was on a tour so we didn't get to see some parts of it. It's a beautiful place to visit which has lots of history & great place to take photos as well.

the must do in seoul, entrance cost 3000won (3$)really typical and nice,one tip : nowadays there are korean teenagers students (wearing yellow clothe) they can guide you around the palace for free. they just want to communicate in english, they speak english perfectly for teenagers, so do it, if someone ask you to get a student guide, just say yes!
Together with a guide a visit to this palace will give you a good idea of the history of South Korea. See the changing of the guard and learn about former dynasties.

Big area with not a lot of exhibit to hold your attention. We were there during their Royal Culture Festival, so there was more activities going on and lots of people dressed up, which helped add to the atmosphere. Can be pretty hot in May, not a lot of shelter in the grounds. Ticketing counters are also in the open. Paths are bumpy and rocky, making it difficult to push a stroller around.It's recommended to visit the National Palace Museum first to get a better understanding of the history of the place as there isn't many signages within.

The kitchen area had been renovated for several years and it had been open. And the cocubines' residence are under the renovated right now.The place where Queen was assassinated is open now for the limited period. It was not open at all for long time, and we had chance to see it 2 days ago. There were many visitors wearing Korean traditional costumes, Hanbok, because it is free admission for them, who wear the costume. They said there are many rental shops nearby. That made the place garden more beautiful.

Unlike most Asian Palaces you visit on city tours, this one had a lot of depth and diversification to it. The palace itself is beautiful but it leads into so many more things, such as the gardens and and water features. I normally find this stuff a bit of a bore; but this time round I was engaged and interested by the surroundings.... your walking through the past, with a thriving 21st century city surrounding you; it's very unique!
Of all the palaces in Seoul, I think this is a must to visit. The palace ground is huge and the scenery is amazing. Going to palaces can give you a glimpse of Korea's colorful history.
Beautiful palace and changing of the guard. English speaking tour guide gave good info. Also several museums.
Big and sprawling . Very spread out and lots of dust and open spaces. The changing of the guards was interestin

My wife and I visited Gyeongbokgung Palace earlier this year. At first sight, the palace is impressive. However, once you see the building...there really isn't a lot to do. The grounds could use some greenery and some flowers. There's lots of open spaces...maybe add a fountain or two?Allow 30-45 minutes tops.
A must visit! Great palace, very big area and many buildings, garden and museum inside. Very beautiful trees. You can feel real Seoul here!
Very interesting and amazing what mankind can do . Make sure u guys get tour guide to explain to you the building and what it was made for and who accuplied it.
Together with a guide a visit to this palace will give you a good idea of the history of South Korea. See the changing of the guard and learn about former dynasties.

Big area with not a lot of exhibit to hold your attention. We were there during their Royal Culture Festival, so there was more activities going on and lots of people dressed up, which helped add to the atmosphere. Can be pretty hot in May, not a lot of shelter in the grounds. Ticketing counters are also in the open. Paths are bumpy and rocky, making it difficult to push a stroller around.It's recommended to visit the National Palace Museum first to get a better understanding of the history of the place as there isn't many signages within.

The kitchen area had been renovated for several years and it had been open. And the cocubines' residence are under the renovated right now.The place where Queen was assassinated is open now for the limited period. It was not open at all for long time, and we had chance to see it 2 days ago. There were many visitors wearing Korean traditional costumes, Hanbok, because it is free admission for them, who wear the costume. They said there are many rental shops nearby. That made the place garden more beautiful.

Unlike most Asian Palaces you visit on city tours, this one had a lot of depth and diversification to it. The palace itself is beautiful but it leads into so many more things, such as the gardens and and water features. I normally find this stuff a bit of a bore; but this time round I was engaged and interested by the surroundings.... your walking through the past, with a thriving 21st century city surrounding you; it's very unique!
Of all the palaces in Seoul, I think this is a must to visit. The palace ground is huge and the scenery is amazing. Going to palaces can give you a glimpse of Korea's colorful history.
Beautiful palace and changing of the guard. English speaking tour guide gave good info. Also several museums.
Big and sprawling . Very spread out and lots of dust and open spaces. The changing of the guards was interestin

My wife and I visited Gyeongbokgung Palace earlier this year. At first sight, the palace is impressive. However, once you see the building...there really isn't a lot to do. The grounds could use some greenery and some flowers. There's lots of open spaces...maybe add a fountain or two?Allow 30-45 minutes tops.
A must visit! Great palace, very big area and many buildings, garden and museum inside. Very beautiful trees. You can feel real Seoul here!
Very interesting and amazing what mankind can do . Make sure u guys get tour guide to explain to you the building and what it was made for and who accuplied it.

We visited here with a guide on our one full day in Seoul. Happily our visit was timed so we got to see the changing of the guard ceremony which really added to our experience. Lucky to have our guide who explained the symbolism of the construction and feng shui. There were tons of Korean school kids there on field trips - apparently it's a thing for them to dress up in traditional costumes - very fun to see them. Many were also doing a scavenger hunt and "take a pic with a foreigner" was on the list so we are in several pics Very fun, enjoyed our visit.

We went to the palace with a guide (Ben Moon from Viator) who was not only quite knowledgeable about the palace but about Korean history and the city of Seoul. The Palace itself is quite impressive. An absolute must if you are in Seoul.
Beautiful palace and worth a visit whilst in Seoul.Easy to get to and lovely to spend approximately 3-4 hours just walking around.Definitely worth a visit!

The palace is an expansive display of royal living in Korea. Beautifully painted rooms, buildings and courtyards. The changing of the guard, with a band, is colorful and well executed - at 10:00 AM - get there a little early to get a good spot on the ropes. Don't miss the queen's gardens in the back.

It was like walking in to a time warp that transports you back in olden times. A lot of guests were dressed in traditional Korean attire. We even got to see the changing of guards ceremony which my kids particularly found amazing. So much to see, so many nice spots to take photos of.

I think a tour guide is necessary for something like this so they can help explain the history to you. There are not placards that do that here. Also make sure to be there for the changing of the guard.

Beautiful. many young women/men dressed in hanbok taking pictures. consider looking into reservation for inner place prior to visiting for access. Also, during certain time of the year, they apparently open for night visit with performances.

I just visited the outside of the palace as everything inside was either closed or needs a tour reservation one day in advance. The outside is beautiful enough to enjoy although most of the 'common' quarters do look a like. There is a free museum next door about palace life as well as some other museums nearby. The day I was there though it was very crowded with kids on school trips but if they get the same assignment as while I was there lots of those kids will ask to take a picture with you (assignment was take picture with a foreigner) which depending on your personality could be annoying or cute.

This palace is beautiful and serene, the centre is main building, very huge surrounded with a small palace, love the pond in the back. There is separate museum at the end, also one old traditional house which is interesting to walk inside to see how people live in the olden days. Tour guide is available at certain times, the changing guard ceremony is one of a good event not to miss. It is worth to spend half day to visit this palace.
Dont miss it as it is an important place in the history of South Korea. At the center of the city. Interesting.

We visited here with a guide on our one full day in Seoul. Happily our visit was timed so we got to see the changing of the guard ceremony which really added to our experience. Lucky to have our guide who explained the symbolism of the construction and feng shui. There were tons of Korean school kids there on field trips - apparently it's a thing for them to dress up in traditional costumes - very fun to see them. Many were also doing a scavenger hunt and "take a pic with a foreigner" was on the list so we are in several pics Very fun, enjoyed our visit.

We went to the palace with a guide (Ben Moon from Viator) who was not only quite knowledgeable about the palace but about Korean history and the city of Seoul. The Palace itself is quite impressive. An absolute must if you are in Seoul.
Beautiful palace and worth a visit whilst in Seoul.Easy to get to and lovely to spend approximately 3-4 hours just walking around.Definitely worth a visit!

Tour guide is available at certain times, the changing guard ceremony is one of a good event not to miss. It is worth to spend half day to visit this palace.
Dont miss it as it is an important place in the history of South Korea. At the center of the city. Interesting.
This time, I visited the palace in the Spring, and as in Fall, the palace and grounds are just gorgeous. Interesting to see the change of guards.

Beautiful palace in Seoul. My very first time visiting a palace in Seoul and I was immediately captivated by its timeless beauty. Highly recommend to visit for first timers to Seoul, South Korea. Easily accessible via public transport.

The very first time for us to be here in South Korea and it such a great experience for us and we are having fun and wonderful city tour. Our tour guide was Mia, such an ideal tour guide who was very energetic, friendjy and knowledgeable. Almost all she recommended about food to eat and to have/buy when we are in Korea were followed. Hope and pray, i could come back in different season and i want to go to Jeju Island on my next visit!

In terms of "Palace Grounds", I think this is the most beautiful.I have read reviews that this place is nothing special and that there are many people walking around. Simply not true, well, the "not special" part anyway.There will be lots of people walking around, its a main attraction when visiting Seoul so I'm not sure what why you would not expect this.This place is great for photography. So many different types of plants and flowers and lots of buildings to walk around and explore.Yo will see many people walking around in "Hanbok" which is a traditional dress of Korea. Colourful and beautiful imo.Grab a leaflet at the start which includes a map, its free and will ensure that you don't miss anything. There is also a way to see the "Blue House" which is where the president resides. I missed this first time round.Entrance is cheap and you can buy a drink and some snacks inside. I recommend taking a packed lunch, find a nice spot in the grounds and relax.The changing of the guard is a must see.A great day out for all.

Nothing really special. Some other palaces are even more attrative imho. Main place of attraction for thousands of tourists but I would not say this palace is the best one in Seoul. OF course it is the biggest one, time is running fast, you can easily spend 4-5 hours here and at the same time you'll have a feeling that it was 40-50 minutes... strange, really!

there were many people, but not much explanation about the buildings on the site. it might be nice for a picnic for family, but too much walking to see buildings which are not given any explanation in any language.

Entry into the palace is free when you walk in wearing a hanbok, which was what I did! I rented a hanbok from the nearby Bukchon Hanok Village. It costs 15,000 KRW for a 2 hour rental. It was very fun soaking in the history of the place, walking around in the hanbok and taking many photos! However, there were very few write-ups of the different spots in the palace so most of the time I actually didn't know what I was looking at. Most of the palace is also rather empty and there are many places where entry is denied and you can only look at the building from afar.
best place to know about korean culture and their history. their past and how time have changed everything
There are many beautiful palaces to visit in Seoul, and many feel like they are the same, but this one has the extra beauty of water ponds, so it became our favorite.
A very interesting and intriguing place to visit, however, strollers are not recommended. Queue for admission tickets was quick and easy.
This time, I visited the palace in the Spring, and as in Fall, the palace and grounds are just gorgeous. Interesting to see the change of guards.

best place to know about korean culture and their history. their past and how time have changed everything
There are many beautiful palaces to visit in Seoul, and many feel like they are the same, but this one has the extra beauty of water ponds, so it became our favorite.
A very interesting and intriguing place to visit, however, strollers are not recommended. Queue for admission tickets was quick and easy.
Its a must visit on the first trip to korea , renting hanboks while taking picture with the palace and the great atmosphere along with friends.
Very interesting place to visit in Korea. If you are like me who enjoys looking at ancient architecture, then visiting this place is a must. It really capture the feeling of being in that century.

Visited this place many of times and keep coming back with friends. It's great to see the historical attire that the staff wears and also the changing of the guard show. Everyone loves to take pictures with the guards and you will see a lot of people wearing tradition Korean attire that they rent from the local shops around the palace. A must visit in Seoul

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is quite impressive. The area behind the (restored) front gate is public and you're able to watch the very nice Royal Guard Changing Ceremony even for free.If you wanna enter the actual Palace ground it'll cost you the small entrance fee of about 3$ only. Sure worth it.The palace ground is quite big and impressive. Nice buildings and architecture. Lots of green areas as well. Many visitors are roaming the area in (mostly rented) Hanboks. A nice sight. Like I said, don't miss out on the guard changing ceremony. The Royal Guards change at least at 2pm and 5pm. Before the ceremony you can watch them train, just outside the walls (eastside). We went on a weekday and got some good spots to watch, not many visitors. It's enough if you show up about 15-20mins before (at least in spring). You also can take some nice pics together with the guards just outside the main gate.All in all a nice place to visit. A few minutes away only from the Bukchon Hanok Village, don't miss out on that one if you're in the area.Wanna know more about me and my trips? Check my profile.

The palace contained beautiful architect and history. We can rent some traditional hanbok at fair price to take photo here. If you want to explore everything here, you should spend about 2 hours or more.

We went to see the palace and a special "rehearsal" for a huge ceremony. Very interesting! Lots of people, lots of music, lots of heat. The rehearsal went on for over 2 hours starting around 11 am on Sunday. They worked on tiny parts of the ceremony over and over, yet missed glaring errors. However, it was very interesting to watch this changing ceremony, hear the very unique music. Costumes were incredibly elaborate. Don't know if this is a normal rehearsal done frequently, or only occasionally. It was not the normal changing of the guard After the heat became too intense, we went into the Museum It was free but there is not much there. They don't seem to have much historical memorabilia but they do have 2 very cool vintage autos in the atrium which seem like the center for all attractions. Only spent about 1 hr in the museum and that was more than enough time to cool off and sit for awhile.

We get to see the guard changing shift at 10am. It was an interesting ceremony ! The palace was big and there were many nice places for taking pictures. A great experience to visit the Palace when in Korea !
We managed to catch the Guard Changing ceremony and it's very interesting. If you watch K-dramas, you get an idea how the Joseon era was. The palace is huge with many people wearing the hanbuk.

The original palace of the Joseon dynasty, that has been destroyed & rebuilt several times. Very impressive. Try to arrive on the hour to see the changing of the guards, an impressive display with several lines of guards with flags & drums. We were there on a Saturday and there were lots of Koreans dressed up in rented old traditional costumes (taking lots of selfies). Great historical site.
You feel youself go back to the Ancient Orient when visiting it the way it is built reminds you of thr great kingdoms that were once in this part of the world.
Its a must visit on the first trip to korea , renting hanboks while taking picture with the palace and the great atmosphere along with friends.

We managed to catch the Guard Changing ceremony and it's very interesting. If you watch K-dramas, you get an idea how the Joseon era was. The palace is huge with many people wearing the hanbuk.

The original palace of the Joseon dynasty, that has been destroyed & rebuilt several times. Very impressive. Try to arrive on the hour to see the changing of the guards, an impressive display with several lines of guards with flags & drums. We were there on a Saturday and there were lots of Koreans dressed up in rented old traditional costumes (taking lots of selfies). Great historical site.
You feel youself go back to the Ancient Orient when visiting it the way it is built reminds you of thr great kingdoms that were once in this part of the world.

We came way too late and the ceremony just finished. So sad. The place is worth your half day time. It's beautiful and you will get to know Korea'a history better. Hanbok rental available on the area. Lots of people, both foreigner and korean, wear hanbok and stroll around the palace

Even if we visited the place in a rainy day we enjoyed its magnificence and beauty. There are many areas to visit: the library, meeting rooms, garden, small lak, etc. all beautiful and kept in excellent form. It gives the right idea of how was living in a place like this during the historical period. Well worth visit.

The palace gave an idea of life several 100 years ago. The pavilion in the centre of a lake was most attactive and, on the day I was there, was the background for wedding photos. We saw the colourful changing of the guard.
By far one of my favorite palace in Seoul, with mountains on the background, beautiful at whatever season, it is the symbol I have kept from Seoul.

This is a must see if you are interested in some culture while you are in Seoul. I suggest having a tour guide that can give you insight into the history. The changing of the guards is a nice ceremony and the art behind the King's chair are things not to miss.

Before heading into this beautiful palace, make sure you visit one of the Hanbok (Korean traditional dresses) rental places and rent an outfit to really feel like you've just walked into the Chosun Dynasty of Korea. We rented dresses for 18,000Won for 4 hours. If you dress up you don't have to pay for the entrance fee at the Palace! You can then add accessories to your outfit but getting your hair braided and adding a traditional headband and pick out a handbag of your choice. This dressing up made it especially fun for my 2 daughters, aged 8 and 4. The photos we took were amazing! Go early so you don't get caught in a flood of people.
Very interesting area of kings palace. I visited similar in Tokyo but this has different spirit. I would recommend to visit it.

It is large palace with different buildings and big park. You can spend hours here and you won't be bored, you will be relaxed. After 10.00 starts big noise with incoming groups. I don't know whether It was because of election or it was usual.

Was there to visit the palace in Apr 2017. Location is central u can take a subway to the station named after it and a short walk will take u to main gate. It happened to be I think royal culture week so many Koreans dressed in traditional hangbok so it was quite a sight. Entrance fee is not expensive only around 1500 won I think. I rented a audio guide in English but on hindsight I would suggest to take the free English guided tour at specific intervals daily. As the audio guide was cumbersome to use and info was a bit of overkill. But it gives some background on the palace which was central piece of Korean culture. The place was definitely much smaller than Beijing forbidden city which I feel is a much better tourist experience. Probably because most of buildings were burnt down during jap occupation and the rebuilt ones had spartan deco within. And there wasn't much exhibition on ancient palace exhibits unlike the forbidden city. Hence my average rating. But if u haven't been to china, I guess it's still a good way to spend 2-3 hours of your time understanding the Korean history and the royal family.

We had a lovely day wandering around Gyeongbokgung palace - the grounds are fairly expansive so wear comfy shoes, but many of the buildings aren't reconstructed yet so it is definitely ideal to visit when the weather is reliably nice. Super cheap to enter (₩3000) and a nice way to kill an afternoon.

Super cheap to enter (₩3000) and a nice way to kill an afternoon.

Amazed with the culture where traditions and the historical areas have been preserved. This Palace is really wide and you need a long time to explore. If you really interested in seeing the whole area, better come early.
Nice place to walk around for a few hours. Very pretty and we were lucky to see the flower blossom during the season. Can get crowded from time to time but overall is a must see in seoul

We went here the first day were were in Seoul, normally closed on Tuesdays but open for Buddha's birthday. Make sure you take the free English speaking tour. Very informative and educational. Loved seeing the teenage girls in their traditional Korean dress (Hanbok). I heard they get in free if they wear it. Adds to the experience, fun to see them doing selfies. So cute. The gardens were amazing, don't miss the water view in the back. Peonies were in bloom. If you go out the back gate you can see the "Blue Housea', the president's residence. Very highly guarded.

There really is not that much to see in Seoul, but you shouldn't be disappointed by this place, its big and cost around $3 to $4 Australian to enter, they have a office room you can go and borrow ( yes its free) traditional Korean costumes to walk around the site in, its fun to take photos
One of five great Palaces to visit.Close to metro station.Free entry for over 60.The architecture is stunning.Guide leaflets in English most udeful

I visited the palace as part of a weekend in Seoul and it was a great way to spend some time. The grounds are beautiful and the palace buildings are steeped in history. I would recommend getting a guided tour as we did not and so the deeper history of the palace remained unknown.

Without doubt Gyeonbokgung Palace visit is a must in Seoul. Gardens and the buildings are amazing !! I love to see people dressed with the traditional dress. If you go in the right moment, you also can see the cherry trees blossom !

TIP: Before going check the time of the FREE MULTILINGUAL tours! They provide interesting backstory and add some richness to the experience - highly recommend.We visited this place on a rainy day but it was still worth it. My mom and I came together because of the overwhelming reviews we read online but when we got here we were totally blown away. The structures were beautiful and in pristine condition, the backstories all interesting.

Went there specifically to catch changing of the guards which take place at 10am and 2pm. There are also other guard changing performances at different times so check the Visit Korea website for more info. Nice place to stroll around for an hour or so.
See the changing of the Royal Guard Ceremony-so colorful and enchanting. Take subway to Gyeongbukgung, exit 5.

I visited the palace as part of a weekend in Seoul and it was a great way to spend some time. The grounds are beautiful and the palace buildings are steeped in history. I would recommend getting a guided tour as we did not and so the deeper history of the palace remained unknown.

Without doubt Gyeonbokgung Palace visit is a must in Seoul. Gardens and the buildings are amazing !! I love to see people dressed with the traditional dress. If you go in the right moment, you also can see the cherry trees blossom !

TIP: Before going check the time of the FREE MULTILINGUAL tours! They provide interesting backstory and add some richness to the experience - highly recommend.We visited this place on a rainy day but it was still worth it. My mom and I came together because of the overwhelming reviews we read online but when we got here we were totally blown away. The structures were beautiful and in pristine condition, the backstories all interesting.

Went there specifically to catch changing of the guards which take place at 10am and 2pm. There are also other guard changing performances at different times so check the Visit Korea website for more info. Nice place to stroll around for an hour or so.
See the changing of the Royal Guard Ceremony-so colorful and enchanting. Take subway to Gyeongbukgung, exit 5.

This palace is the biggest palace of Seoul built by Joseon dynasty. It further includes many sub palaces, kitchens, utility areas, stables etc. that makes it a perfect palace. It was built about 600 years ago but destroyed in a fire, the present palace was restored a century ago. A well maintained palace. The changing of guards ceremony is delightful. A must if you have interest in history & monuments. Happy travelling!!
For 3,ooo Won this palace is a bargain. We spent a few hours walking around the grounds and the beautiful colors and paints were mesmerizing. Interesting place to visit,

Depending on how informative is your guide is, this is a must do historic site visit. We were here on a rainy day so it was cold and wet walking through the palace grounds, but our guide was very informative which made the visit interesting. We took a private tour as we had 3 kids in tow- but we did not reach there in time for the changing of the palace guards. Many tourist and locals were in periodic costumes which added to the lovely ambiance in spite of the wet day.

One of the grand palaces of South Korea. Very good place to visit, especially if you're looking for cultural exposure. Reminder to either bring umbrellas, or use sunscreen or both. :)It's also a bit (or a lot) of a walk inside so make sure you're wearing comfortable clothes and shoes. :)It has a connection to the National Folk Museum so you can come out that end and continue on to Bukchon Hanok village. And, if you're still not tired, you can go ahead and walk to Changdeokgung Palace (it -is- far, but doable). ;)
When I visited there was a rehearsal going on for a concert. It very enjoyable. I enjoyed the sense of calm, beauty and history of the palace.

Gyeongbokgung is the main palace of jeoseon dynasty. This ground had witness the birth of hangeul, modern society, until japanese occupation. The palace ground is really beautiful. Placed in the heart of Seoul. I watched 2 days 1 night korean variety show. They had episode where they explore the palace. From that show, i become even more fascinated by the palace
This place is huge. You'll find many locals and tourists wearing hanbok here. It does get very crowded so it's best to to get here early.
On tour, interesting to know the history of the palace. Fun to see a lot of people dressed in Korean outfit.
Interesting palace, a lot of people are dress like the old Korean days, and walking around. Not too good on a rainy day.
Your typical palace in the middle of the city. Crowded with other tourists. Good for what it is and helpful to have a guide.

This palace is the biggest palace of Seoul built by Joseon dynasty. It further includes many sub palaces, kitchens, utility areas, stables etc. that makes it a perfect palace. It was built about 600 years ago but destroyed in a fire, the present palace was restored a century ago. A well maintained palace. The changing of guards ceremony is delightful. A must if you have interest in history & monuments. Happy travelling!!
