Placed in the heart of Seoul. I watched 2 days 1 night korean variety show. They had episode where they explore the palace. From that show, i become even more fascinated by the palace
This place is huge. You'll find many locals and tourists wearing hanbok here. It does get very crowded so it's best to to get here early.
On tour, interesting to know the history of the palace. Fun to see a lot of people dressed in Korean outfit.
Interesting palace, a lot of people are dress like the old Korean days, and walking around. Not too good on a rainy day.
Your typical palace in the middle of the city. Crowded with other tourists. Good for what it is and helpful to have a guide.

The best point of this palace is its guard attractionThere is two kind of attractionGwanghwamun gate performance and also Changing guard performance. Both of attraction are an hour separated..So dont ever miss itNotes: when we visited this palace the attraction that we saw were- Gwanghwamun gate performance was at 1.00 pm- Guard changing was at 2.00 pm

It's an hour+ and brings you to the key areas with stories and explanations, more than what I expected for a free tour. The guides are humorous and very friendly. Visit the palace website for timings.

This Palace is located in a super central area of Seoul. I went for the changing of the guard and spent about an hour walking around. Its not as impressive as say the forbidden city in Beijing but its beautiful and i love how locals and some visitors dress up in the old style outfits and walk around the palace. Its something quite interesting to see. Its walking distance then to Insa-dong and also the area street. Def must visit and if time is short, you really can get around this in under an hour.

This is one of the big attractions in Seoul, but I felt there is so much to do in the city and this just isn't a top memory. The palace and the grounds are basically a reconstruction because of various wars. I know it's not their fault, but it makes it less interesting to me. It is pretty, but many of the buildings just feel like the same thing over and over. You're probably going to see it, but with such a wonderful city, I would recommend seeing more of modern Seoul.

We were welcomed by a teen guide working on her English skills. She was amazing and knew lots of details about the history of the palace. She explained that she did the tours once a month for school credit. The changing of the guard is a colourful must see. The only disappointment was that all you get to see are empty buildings. There are a few sticks of furniture - such as a replica throne and bed frame but not much else.

An ensemble of palaces and annexed buildings with a very beautiful gardenWe had some bigger expectations than changing the guard, but the process is rather tricky maybe because of the translation of the ceremony in 3 languages

Wear Hanbok to get free admission into the palace. You can rent them for about 15000 - 20000 KRW for 4 hours. Hanbok rental shops could be found in the neighborhood of Gyeongbokgung, you cant rent them from the palace itself.Sumunjang (Royal Guard) Changing Ceremony 10:00, 14:00 / 20 minutes per ceremony Gwanghwamun Gate Guard-on-Duty Performance 11:00, 13:00 / 10 minutes per ceremony Sumungun (Gatekeeper) Military Training (outside Hyeopsaengmun Gate)09:30, 13:30 / 15 minutes per ceremony

Beautiful palace which you cant skip if you come to seoul. Try to come early so you can see the changing guard which always start at 10am. The enterance fee costs 3000 won per person, which is reasonable to see all sides of the palace. Book the guide tour for the middle palace in advance so you can go up and see the inside bit. This will cost you nothing.

We booked ahead for the secret garden tour. One quick point-the website for this booking is great, even allowed us to change our times easily. Enjoyed the tour of the gardens, very pretty and less crowded. The Palace grounds were nice too, with the exterior of the buildings beautifully decorated. Enjoyed seeing visitors in their traditional Korean dress too, gives the visit a fun twist.

Charming huge palace. Great to visit in the weekend because there's plenty of tourists who like to dress up and have their picture taken while wearing traditional Hanbok.The first area of the Palace doesn't do it justice. Go explore to the other wings and you'll discover beauty everywhere.

The best point of this palace is its guard attractionThere is two kind of attractionGwanghwamun gate performance and also Changing guard performance. Both of attraction are an hour separated..So dont ever miss itNotes: when we visited this palace the attraction that we saw were- Gwanghwamun gate performance was at 1.00 pm- Guard changing was at 2.00 pm

Its something quite interesting to see. Its walking distance then to Insa-dong and also the area street. Def must visit and if time is short, you really can get around this in under an hour.

This will cost you nothing.

Enjoyed the tour of the gardens, very pretty and less crowded. The Palace grounds were nice too, with the exterior of the buildings beautifully decorated. Enjoyed seeing visitors in their traditional Korean dress too, gives the visit a fun twist.

Charming huge palace. Great to visit in the weekend because there's plenty of tourists who like to dress up and have their picture taken while wearing traditional Hanbok.The first area of the Palace doesn't do it justice. Go explore to the other wings and you'll discover beauty everywhere.

I love history so I always try to visit local historical sites to get a deeper understanding of a local history. Though the style was borrowed from ancient China it still has its own unique Korean features.
I find the history very interesting especially after visiting the Korea History Museum. The palace is amazing. Sat for a while to soak in the history I learned.

As the main and biggest palace in Seoul, Gyeongbukgong is a must visit attraction. You can get in free if you're wearing a hanbok.Got to see the changing of the guards at 10 am. I think it can be skipped, but if you're there anyway, it's still good to catch. With a map/short guide available, one can go around on their own, but would advise to take a guided tour since they offer it free anyway. It's a very big complex so it's best to wear comfortable shoes. Inside the complex is the National Folk Museum and you can get it there for free as well. So many beautiful historical sites in this palace - architecture, design and nature in one. Placed against a lovely mountain background, you will understand why this site was chosen as the main palace.
Enjoyed this place very much. Their is a lot of tourists so be prepared. If you wear traditional Korean clothes than you can waive the 5 US dollar fee that is required to go inside.

Today I have visited Gyeongbokghng Palace which is at walking distance from Gyeongbokghng metro station.The palace is huge is size and you have to walk a lot to cover all the parts of palace.The Korean architecture is full of colours & they use lot of wood for making building.The live music show during the visit was treat for the eyes ( girls playing drums).Also many local people were dressed in Korean colourful traditional dresses, everyone looking great.A not to miss place ..

When in Seoul all visitors seem to go to this old Palace as the center piece of Sth Korean history which indeed it was. Holds great attraction for visitors from Japan who seem to arrive here by the bus load. A great stroll though history

Gyeongbokgung palace was our first highlights of our Korean adventure. We higher a local guide that introduced to us to all palace secrets and stories and regardless that most of it that we so was a reproduction from originally made palace due to all destruction that happened, we had a more than clear and authentic experience in understanding the greatness of architecture, art and inventions that can put our European medieval knowledge and accomplishment at shame. Monument more than worth to be put on MUST SEE list!

I was lucky enough to visit here on the last Wednesday of the month when entry to public attractions such as this are free.The palace is beautiful and a great way to spend a couple of hours. The place is huge, much larger than I expected so make sure you have plenty of time to explore.

It was neat but it was busy, too busy. Would have been a better experience to go outside of the changing of the guards to experience the palace. Don't get me wrong the palace is quite beautiful but the crowds were particular busy at this time. The crowds did provide a great opportunity for people watching, a favourite travel activity.
Made it in time for the parade.The guards wore very colorful attire The palace was really huge so lots of walking to do if you want to see the grounds. Its very crowded as its a tourist attraction

I love history so I always try to visit local historical sites to get a deeper understanding of a local history. Though the style was borrowed from ancient China it still has its own unique Korean features.
I find the history very interesting especially after visiting the Korea History Museum. The palace is amazing. Sat for a while to soak in the history I learned.

So many beautiful historical sites in this palace - architecture, design and nature in one. Placed against a lovely mountain background, you will understand why this site was chosen as the main palace.

Monument more than worth to be put on MUST SEE list!

I was lucky enough to visit here on the last Wednesday of the month when entry to public attractions such as this are free.The palace is beautiful and a great way to spend a couple of hours. The place is huge, much larger than I expected so make sure you have plenty of time to explore.

It was neat but it was busy, too busy. Would have been a better experience to go outside of the changing of the guards to experience the palace. Don't get me wrong the palace is quite beautiful but the crowds were particular busy at this time. The crowds did provide a great opportunity for people watching, a favourite travel activity.
Made it in time for the parade.The guards wore very colorful attire The palace was really huge so lots of walking to do if you want to see the grounds. Its very crowded as its a tourist attraction

This palace is located in the middle of town, surrounded by Seoul city, very interesting. I got here with a tour guide but I did not pay attention to the explanation, just taking some pictures which are beautiful. Well, a historical side in the city, very clean, and beautiful sceneries. But, you have to be ready to take a long walk.

Make sure to catch the changing of the guard. It is a nice display of old Korean culture. Put notice to the many Korean visitors in traditional costumes. It gives the place a nice atmosphere. The tea house is rich decorated and serves Korean tea and sweets.

The Gyeongbokgung Palae is de biggest of the five grand palaces built by the kings of the Joseon Dynasty. The magnificant Gwanghwamun entrance gate is situated right in the hear of Seoul and one of its most famous landmarks. if you don't have much time for your visit to Seoul, this place can't be missed. The palace buildings are mostly reconstructions, because lots of the buildings were destroyed during the Japanese occupation. The Koreans took great care in reconstructing the building as faithfully as possible.The site is very big, so you'll at least need two hours to see everything. When in a hurry make sure not to miss Gyeonghoeru, a beautiful construction sitting on top of 48 stone pillars. reflected in the surrounding artificial lake. Likewise he trone hall (Geunjeongjeon) is a National Treasure which will leave a lasting impression.Don't miss the traditional changing of the guards ceremony!
Good place,good culture,but not much direction about a place in english writing.so much turn around to find what i want to.very big place need much time to around it

We spent a very enjoyable few hours at this palace. It covers a surprisingly large area, so you do need time to explore it all. The setting, with mountains behind, is wonderful and having so many locals dressed in Hanbok adds to the enjoyment. The combination ticket, which gives entry to 4 palaces and Jongmyo Shrine for W10,000 (less than £7) make it excellent value for money. Not to be missed.

The Korean Tourism Organisation post an announcement that the Palace has a special night opening. I went there and find a traditional concert in open air. superb.THe night view - superbDo join the Korean Tourism Organization facebook for notification of special events.

Visited this place... Beautiful and good for taking pictures.... There are many place in the city... Mostly similar... Its better to choose 2 palace only... Any two... Because almost all palaces are same...

It's kind of dry at first, now knowing what to expect inside. What you first see upon reaching Gyeongnokgung grounds is the largest structure. Once you're inside, you will be greeted with more old Korean palace, temples and houses and greenery. While inside the palace grounds, you can see this mountain that accentuates the whole scenery. Each area gives a new perspective, all equally magnificent. Don't miss this while in Seoul.

It's is always great and inspiring to visit historic locations like the palaces in South Korea, and this is one of the ones that have to visit.We were lucky to take pictures with local students who dressed up in traditional clothes who were visiting the palace on that day.

After living in Japan for 5 years, I feel that sometimes I get a bit oversaturated with all the beautiful things I've seen here, but this palace still managed to impress me with its size and beautiful gardens. It was so enjoyable walking around, very serene and amazing. Definitely a must-visit if you're in Seoul! If you can make it when the changing of guards occurs, you should definitely try as the ceremony of it is really cool to experience.

After living in Japan for 5 years, I feel that sometimes I get a bit oversaturated with all the beautiful things I've seen here, but this palace still managed to impress me with its size and beautiful gardens. It was so enjoyable walking around, very serene and amazing. Definitely a must-visit if you're in Seoul! If you can make it when the changing of guards occurs, you should definitely try as the ceremony of it is really cool to experience.
A nice palace, a bit crowded during our visit, but worth a visit and take a visit wearing hanbok, a traditional korean dress.

We enjoyed going through out the grounds of this Grand Palace. My favorite place was the Banquet Building. It was three levels high on the edge of a lovely lake surrounded by willow trees. Outside the palace there are businesses where you can rent a beautiful traditional Hanbok outfit to wear for the day. We didn't rent any of them, but really enjoyed seeing all the beautiful Hanboks worn by others, it really added to the experience. We also visited the National Folk Museum, which is also on the same grounds of the palace. I recommend going to it. As we were leaving we were able to see the changing of the guards. Highly recommended that you go here when visiting Seoul. One of our family members has problems walking great distances, so they rented a wheelchair. These chairs are very narrow in the seat. She isn't over weight but she had problems sitting in it.

Went during the Lunar New Year. Admission was free and you get to go the Natural Folk Museum while you are there. There were cultural performances and activities all around the place you can do. I even managed to try on their traditional hanbok for free!
Really gave a feeling for the scale of a palace and the significance of the royal family. Very much and "outside" tour with little insight into the life in the buildings

Visited with two young kids - you can tell an attempt was made to make the place wheel chair accessible but we had a really hard time getting the stroller across the grounds. . There's not much to see inside as most of its not original but reconstruction. If you been to the Imperial palace in other Asian cities (Beijing, Tokyo, Taipei) you will not find this site particularly impressive. On the plus side - admission is cheap and tourist sights are few in the city. Makes a relaxing stroll on a sunny day.Be mindful it closes on Tuesday
A great place to wander around and wonder and take photos. If possible make sure to take in the changing of the guard as it is quite special. A very worthwhile afternoon or morning!
It is a very beautiful place which definity needs a visit. It gives you a taste of the local culture and is definitely highly recommended

We were fortunate to get there in time to see the changing of the guard which of itself would have been worth the visit. It has suffered from several fires and eventually was burned down during the Japanese occupation. Fortunately, it has been reconstructed several times and now brought back to its former glory.

No doubt the palace is a must see while in Seoul. Easy accessible by subway but if possible go on a weekday. I went on a Saturday and it was crowded with people. It seems that on Saturdays children from schools are brought here as a field trip so you have 5-7 years old running all over.  On the other hand, the architecture was so beautiful is amazing to see that even though most of the palace was badly deteriorated as a result of the Japanese invasion the efforts for reconstruction allows tourist to submerge in this wonder.

Haven't been to many palaces in my lifetime, but walking through this one certainly made for a nice, informative afternoon! Loads of people in Hanbok (admission is free is you are wearing one?) enjoying themselves. The buildings themselves are georgous inside and out. Heartbreakingly poignant were the residences for Empress Myeongseong. With the mountains looming on the one side and skyscrapers on the other, an overall interesting exploration of Korea's past. Maybe try to visit on off-peak hours, it got quite busy and crowded on our way out.
A nice palace, a bit crowded during our visit, but worth a visit and take a visit wearing hanbok, a traditional korean dress.

The architecture of the buildings are nice and too many Koreans wearing hanbok the Korean costume, so it gives you feeling of tradition and culture of Korea while you are there. The palace has many buildings and there are national folk museum and national palace museum also so you visit them all together and you will have very good Korean cultural experience. Don't miss the changing of the guards during your visit we watched them at 2:00 pm but i think they have another changing show at 11:00 am. You can join your visit with Insandong area which it is very near about 10-15 minutes walking and one stop by metro.
We absorbed so much of Korean history when we went there. From watching changing of guard to viewing the palace.... I would recommend it to anyone.

We arrived at 1pm when there was a guard duty ceremony, and then went on the free one hour English guided tour. People wearing traditional dress were everywhere. Beautiful guardens and interesting buildings and statues. With several museums inside too.

My wife and I went to Seoul so I could visit sites and locations from serving there many years ago in the military. We like the luxury of Four Seasons hotels but like the location of the Seoul Four Seasons as it was central to the locations I wanted to visit. My contacts with the staff started long before we arrived. I email the Concierge in relation to the locations I wanted to visit and how to best coordinate my travels. In a few emails we had complete a plan which included all sites within our limited time. The Concierge team is excellent. They continued to guide us after we arrived.When we checked in we soon learn this excellence extended though the entire staff from the escort to our room, dining staff, everyone. We felt very much at home and comfortable. We had a premiere room with a great view of modern Seoul. The room was very spacious, clean, modern and well equipped for any traveler. The first evening we ate a late dinner at the hotel. Great service and great food, a sampling of Korean dished. Each morning we ate at the breakfast buffet. We managed to eat light but walking and viewing all the culinary offerings is a tour in its self.An excellent exhibit of historic Korean royal architecture. Visit in the mornings around 10:00 am entering at the South Gate to catch the changing of the royal guards. Note the building techniques, colors and layout to the palace buildings. At extensive as these palace grounds are the represent only about 14% of the original structures.Make it a point to exit through the North Gate. The building straight head is the Presidential Blue house (named for its blue title roof). Korea’s equivalent to the White House.

This is one of the old palace in Seoul.You will definitely love this place if you are a fan of Korean drama, you can find many familiar corners where movies were filmed. Wearing Hanbok , walking around the palace is a great experience for Korean fan too. You can hire custom some place such as Hanok Village , they allow you to hire it from 1 hour to 1 day.

I was there in late April , all threes were blooming inside and made this palace like a heaven , interesting views and nice architectures, many ladies and gents worn Korean customs and were roaming there I could imagine that I was in 500 years back , was such a great experience , don't miss it :)
Make sure you get to see the changing of the guard which happens at regular intervals throughout the day

Well kept palace with plenty of photo taking opportunities. Korean girls get in free if they dress in traditional South Korean dresses which adds nicely to the authenticity and they're more than happy for you to have your photos taken with them as long as they can have photos with you too.
This place is same location with national folks museum. I came here by walk from insadong and bukchon.Better you take pic here when using hanbok ;))
We came here on a private tour from the Incheon Cruise Port. Very nice place to walk around. I would come here again and spend some more time.

The architecture of the buildings are nice and too many Koreans wearing hanbok the Korean costume, so it gives you feeling of tradition and culture of Korea while you are there. We came here on a private tour from the Incheon Cruise Port. Very nice place to walk around. I would come here again and spend some more time.

Its was nice and big palace. There are tour guide in english, japan & korea. Please rent hanbok and take picture in this area! there are walking distance between palace & national folk village. Bukchon hanok village also walking distance!

I've been to other palaces in Asia that has more information . This was just little halls after halls with no information and any cultural history. The architecture of the buildings are nice . So took some pictures but not worth the visit if you're looking for detailed tours. I expected to see some lovely gardens and rooms with beautiful furniture and information on how and what they used each hall for . So I was very dissapointed.

Had part of a morning spare in Seoul so went for a short walk and tumbled upon this palace, dating back to 1395. It sits juxtaposed against mirrored glass modern buildings but the serenity within its walls holds the modern world at bay. The outer walls are long and impressive but they nevertheless still hide the scale of what lies behind. One can but only imagine life within the cloistered palace walls and its inner and outer courts, gardens and lake. After reading about the destruction of the palace by fire during the Japanese invasion in 1592 and the taking apart by the Japanese of the reconstructed buildings during their occupation between 1910 - 1945, one must admire the Korean spirit and skill in ensuring such a faithful restoration of the Heungnyemun Gate, the Gwanghwamun Gate and the various royal and princely quarters. Walking through the palace grounds while there were so many locals wearing traditional costume/clothing during their own visits made it easier to imagine the daily bustle of a bygone era.An interesting place to visit.

It was absolutely stunning and bigger than I thought it would be. We had conveniently come on a cultural day (which is the last wednesday of every month) so entrance was free!! We also got a free English tour which I would highly recommend. She was super nice and friendly!! You can just find a tour there so look up the times when your language will be available. I learned way more history than I would've by just looking. Overall, a very beautiful place with lots of history

Gyeongbokgung Palace is arguably regarded as being the most beautiful and grandest of all five palaces. It also houses the National Palace Museum of Korea and the National Folk Museum within the premises of the complex.

We didn't get into the palace but only the square with two big gates. There were many tourists (probably) wearing hanbok, which make me think of the scenes in Korean dramas. A historic site but I only spent around 15 minutes taking pictures there.
Was really impressed by the palace and spent most of a full day there wandering around all of the different buildings.

We took the Airport Express Train from Incheon to Seoul in 50 minutes. Purchased the Express Ticket at the airport, easily followed the orange signs, assigned seats, off in Seoul. Short subway and a short walk and were at the Palace at 10 am in time for changing of the guards ceremony. Not to be missed. Very colorful and ornate. The Palace is huge. A court yard within a court yard within a court yard. Beautiful. Make sure to find the gardens. Gives you an idea of the landscaping of the past. Serene.

Wonderful complex enhanced by very knowledgeable guide who described the site and history entertainingly and clearly making the visit very enjoyable. The Palace is a 'Must See' for any visitor to Seoul.

We went by taxi from our hotel down past The Square on a Sunday - where 1000,s of people were setting up another protest for the day & arrived @ Gyeongbokgung Palace Gate to be greeted by 100,s of people all dressed up in various costumes taking pictures of each other.Gyeongbokgung Palace ls huge & overlooks The Square & the city buildings in the background.We took photos of & had photos taken with hundreds of attractive costume dressed young women from many countries - Singapore- Taiwan - Japan - China - Sth Korea - USA ,with eeryone having a wonderful time .A few men were dressed up albeit they didnt look anywhere as good as the women did.There is a changing of the Guard outside The Palace on a regular basis & the public are encouraged to have photos taken with the assembled Guards as they stand to attention outside The Palace Gate.More Photos with the lovely Cherry Blossom trees in the Palace Grounds & it was time to leave this picture paradise.Highly recommended & the best part of our time in this great city

Its was nice and big palace. There are tour guide in english, japan & korea. Please rent hanbok and take picture in this area! there are walking distance between palace & national folk village. Bukchon hanok village also walking distance!

Gyeongbpkgung is so beautiful and traditional. I think the best beautiful is the house behind the palace and some house middle the river. When I went there the water is bacame ice hahaah but it's look so beautiful.

I thought that this place was going to look like forbidden city, huge and all that. But It s not.This is a serene place with beautiful cherry blossom and scenic building. Dont forget to watch the guard changing ceremony, it was pretty impressive. And oh, free admission if you are wearing hanbok. So make sure you rent a hanbok nearby, there are so many choices.
Nice stroll around Gyeongbokgung. Touristy thing to do... but we are indeed tourists. Decent gardens at the back.

This is a great place to learn the Joseon dynasty period of Korea. It is fascinating to see a huge palace complex in the middle of a city. The highlight of this place is the changing of guards ceremony, as if traveling back in time.

This place is a must-see, especially if you want to learn more about Korean history. The palace itself is stunning, but you can feel more like a part of the korean history if you wear a hanbok (korean traditional clothes) which you can borrow from a nearby hanbok rental.
Interesting part of history. Changing of the guards was worth a look. The gardens are lovely for a stroll.
Not knowing much of the Korean history the Gyeongbung palace is a nice visit..huge complex and with nice weather a god walk..

Maybe because I've been to the forbidden city in Beijing. This palace seemed a little plain, but is a great location for Korean-themed photoshooting. There's is an entrance fee of 3,000 Korean wons btw.
The palace is well maintained and very clean. Impressed with the palace building and their history. Very nice place to take photos.

Our tourist Guide told us a lot of the history of this place and we are so amused of the tale. I love the cherry blossom trees around the palace area. I just find it soulful roaming around at this wonderful place

Gyeongbpkgung is so beautiful and traditional. I think the best beautiful is the house behind the palace and some house middle the river. When I went there the water is bacame ice hahaah but it's look so beautiful.

Our tourist Guide told us a lot of the history of this place and we are so amused of the tale. I love the cherry blossom trees around the palace area. I just find it soulful roaming around at this wonderful place

An absolute must. I was here for the afternoon and wish that I had allowed a full day. Acres and acres of space and lots to explore. The photographic opportunities are in abundance here. It was extremely busy and a hot sunny day with blossom everywhere. Many, many couples taking photographs in traditional dress which is so stunning. Even though it was busy, you can still lose yourself in the grounds and find some quiet spots to sit with a picnic lunch if you wish. The admission for myself was only 3000 won which is super super cheap and makes English Heritage Admission prices absolutely ludicrous. I came away having had a super day with stacks of wonderful memories and photographs.
I would like to recommend this place to foreigners who visit to Korea.You can learn Korea history and tradition!Also, can feel Korean life style.You can get to there by subway No.3 (Orange line).

Korea Grand Palace "Kyoung Bok Gung"Great place to learn Korea history and tradition.You can get there by subway No.3 (Orange line).I've been to Old Palace in other countries, because, can know their history and tradition.Also, this place is same.Really different architecture and life style.I would like to recommend this place to foreigners who visit to Korea.

If you're visiting Seoul this is a must see! We loved this Palace and we're in awe of its beauty. My mother in law had a broken toe so this was a hard day for her but we did get her a wheelchair. A lot of Walking and uneven ground with some stairs made for a painful day for her but she made it! Stay for the changing of the guard ceremony if possible.

Nestled in the city centre of Seoul was the beautiful palace of Gyeongbukgung. The cherry blossom was everywhere in the palace which turned it into charm and amazing! Travelling to the palace by using public transportation was very convenient, just outside Exit 5 of subway station. Make sure you take time to observe the guard shift change at the main gate - so amazing!

Korea's last dynasty's palace(Joseon Dynasty). If you are a foreigner or first time visiting abroad born korean, you must visit this palace. Use a guided tour. You will learn and understand the construction and the design. Don't forget to visit the museum. You will see the Korea's then and now.
great! It was a national palace of Chosun dynasty. Although I am not an expert at architecture, i can feel the beauty of ancient asian tradition.

The palace complex is not the original one. The former complex was ransacked by the Japanese when they occupied the land. Work is in progress to restore the complex. In general, it is not the most beautiful palace I have ever seen. It's pale comparison to palaces in Japan. However, it should be one of the best options in Seoul especially it's close the Bukchon village where you can have combined walking tour.

This was the first palace built in the Joseon dynasty and is where the dynasty's 500-year history began. There are five remaining palaces in Seoul and Gyeongbokgung is the largest. The palace offers visitors a glimpse into the Joseon's royal culture, life and architecture. You can also visit the National Palace Museum (located near the entrance of the palace) to learn more about the Joseon royal culture. To learn about the Korean lifestyle in the past, you can visit the National Folk Museum of Korea.Be prepared for a long walk if you want to explore the entire palace area, it was so huge! I visited in spring 2017 and the palace garden was so beautiful with all the cherry blossom trees. If you wear a hanbok, you can enter for free. The changing of the guards ceremony is also not to be missed!

Absolutely a beautiful palace that reflects traditional local culture and history. You may want to visit at the time that free English speaking your guide provided near the entrance- you can get detailed info visitor centers- to get most of the palace.

An absolute must. I was here for the afternoon and wish that I had allowed a full day. Acres and acres of space and lots to explore. The photographic opportunities are in abundance here. The admission for myself was only 3000 won which is super super cheap and makes English Heritage Admission prices absolutely ludicrous. I came away having had a super day with stacks of wonderful memories and photographs.

I visit at spring time when the flowers are blossoms. I recomend to rent a hanbok at street around the palace before enter the palace and feel like a royal family
Beautiful. Peaceful!interesting!Worth to visit I can spend whole day here !thats how beautiful it is!

I had such a great day going around the palace grounds. The grounds were fascinating and the crowds were average. It only cost approx $4 CDN to enter and enjoy the area for as long as you can discover.

A real highlight of my trip. The Palace grounds are amazing and with the mountain ranges in the background, make for some superb photos. I would suggest getting here early and purchasing the four Palace day pass as it's great value. Really, a must see.

The performance is great. It's wonderful to see how the traditions are preserved through such performances. The guards were very professional an didn't flinch even though tourists were all around them buzzing with cameras.

This is actually a palace complex since there are several palaces in the same area with the one in picture being located in a big pond while 2 other palaces are located on land. Very nice place to relax and enjoy the scenery in Seoul as even the surrounding area of the palace is nice with mountains, trees and modern buildings.

We were told by our Korean friends to wear Hanbok (Korean traditional clothing) and will get free entrance to Gyeongbokgung Palace. We rented 4 hours for 2 sets, total 30, 000 won near the palace. Many tourists and even locals wear the Hanbok in; we felt at ease. I would highly recommend to do so, great experience wearing Hanbok into palace and have a taste how the older times people have to manage.
We enjoyed the Change of Guards ceremony prior to visiting the palace. It is a large area and we had a guided tour with English explanations that made it of much more value.
Cool place to see while in Seoul. Took a 90 minute walking tour and wondered around afterward.Tour guide was informative.

We went to the palace for the free english guided tour... it was very informative and Kim was very helpful and nice. The palace was BEAUTIFUL! So much details and beauty on the palace and its entire neighborhood esp for the photo geeks out there! it's a must visit place when visiting South Korea!
I visit at spring time when the flowers are blossoms. I recomend to rent a hanbok at street around the palace before enter the palace and feel like a royal family

We visit the Palace as it is one of our plan to view the history of South Korea. The Gyeongbokgung Palace is a huge complex area. They keep the traditional ceremony in the complex, e.g. exchange guard ceremony. If you have time you can rent Korean traditional dress outside the Palace, and took picture surrounding the Palace. There is lake also near the Palace which is so quiet and calm. A very recommended place when you visit Korea.
The palace was amazing.Being the onset of spring,the trees at the palace was covered in beautiful blossoms

This is the biggest and most impressive temple in Seoul. It has lots of different temples that are all beautiful. You can easily spend a day walking round here. A must do for a visit to Seoul. It's also reasonably priced and there are lots of locals dressed up in traditional dress.

I appreciate Korean Palaces so much because it shows how much they treasure their history. It was well preserved and strictly kept clean, and thus it has become a highly respected place. I wish the Philippines valued its history as much as Koreans did. :(
Go there for a good morning walk.Nothing much to see. Very empty palace. Lucky the entrance fee is not expensive.

The place is oozing with history and the Korean people should be proud of their heritage. Its vast place and well maintained even if there is a long walk everything was dandy and clean. Memorable experience

We go there and rent hanbok to use in the place...There so much old building with traditional ornament... as i am architect i like this place an a building concept... there are a hole to make heater for the king's throne...we should be accompanied by a guide to the history and forms to explain of building...

Catch the changing of the guard ceremony at 10am. Nice place lots of photo opportunities. Lots of walking required. The largest imperial palace built in the 14th century Gyongbokgung Palace. There's a marvelous changing of the guard ceremony at 10am and if you come in traditional costume, you get an entrance fee discount!
The palace is beautiful and a great visit while in Seoul. At 2pm we were fortunate enough to see the guard shift at the palace entrance. Definitely an amazing experience.

We visited the palace on Sunday morning in early April, just when the cherry trees starting to blossoms. We saw many girls, boys, women and men walking around in their hanbok. It was such a pretty sight to see. It felt almost like we traveled back in time during the imperial time. Unforgettable time.

There is lake also near the Palace which is so quiet and calm. A very recommended place when you visit Korea.
The palace was amazing.Being the onset of spring,the trees at the palace was covered in beautiful blossoms

This is the biggest and most impressive temple in Seoul. It has lots of different temples that are all beautiful. You can easily spend a day walking round here. A must do for a visit to Seoul. It's also reasonably priced and there are lots of locals dressed up in traditional dress.

I appreciate Korean Palaces so much because it shows how much they treasure their history. It was well preserved and strictly kept clean, and thus it has become a highly respected place. I wish the Philippines valued its history as much as Koreans did. :(
Go there for a good morning walk.Nothing much to see. Very empty palace. Lucky the entrance fee is not expensive.

The place is oozing with history and the Korean people should be proud of their heritage. Its vast place and well maintained even if there is a long walk everything was dandy and clean. Memorable experience

We go there and rent hanbok to use in the place...There so much old building with traditional ornament... as i am architect i like this place an a building concept... there are a hole to make heater for the king's throne...we should be accompanied by a guide to the history and forms to explain of building...

Catch the changing of the guard ceremony at 10am. Nice place lots of photo opportunities. Lots of walking required. The largest imperial palace built in the 14th century Gyongbokgung Palace. There's a marvelous changing of the guard ceremony at 10am and if you come in traditional costume, you get an entrance fee discount!
The palace is beautiful and a great visit while in Seoul. At 2pm we were fortunate enough to see the guard shift at the palace entrance. Definitely an amazing experience.

We visited the palace on Sunday morning in early April, just when the cherry trees starting to blossoms. We saw many girls, boys, women and men walking around in their hanbok. It was such a pretty sight to see. It felt almost like we traveled back in time during the imperial time. Unforgettable time.

If you want to learn Korea's roots, the Gyeongbokgung Palace is an amazing spot.Doing research, having an audio guide or a tour guide is a recommendation when you want to learn more of what you'll see in the palace & it is worth it. The architecture we saw was amazing and reminds us a tad of the Chinese culture as well. It is also an amazing spot for capturing photographs.PS: I heard from our tour guide that if you rent & wear a Hanbok, you get free entrance to the palace. :)

It's a very busy place during weekends, but I do consider it to be worth it. You have to pay a small fee for the entrance but can stay as long as you'd like to. You're able to rent some historical and traditional Korean clothes for enhance the experience.

The reason why people flock to see this sight is because of it historical value. At the same time, they shot a popular korea novela here. But as my title mentions, not much to see except the changing of guards which happens only at 10am daily.

We visited this palace on a beautiful sunny day and it was great to see the change of guard ceremony. Try to schedule your visit during the change of guard ceremony which happens several times during the day. The staff even lets you wear the traditional outfit for free of cost and it's a great photo opportunity. Overall a great vibe and a must do when you are in Seoul. You will spot a lot of couples wearing traditional hanbok.

This is a must-see for anyone visiting Seoul. Try to arrive on a weekday when it's not so crowded. Be sure to walk Sejongdaero and visit the statues of Admiral Yi Sun Shin and King Sejong as you approach the palace. Beautiful and historic.

This palace has been preserved quite beautifully. Admission is a mere $4USD and quite worth it. We happened to be lucky enough to catch all the cherry blossoms and flowers blooming. Many people choose to rent the traditional Hanboks prior to entering, as it's quite inexpensive and makes a beautiful photograph.

Beautiful architecture. huge space to walk. a must place to visit when you go to Seoul. Can rent their Hanbok traditional outfit and take pictures at the palace. Do go during the time of change of guards which will be around 12:30 - 1pm.

Good place to visit for historical sightseeing. We visited the place in the morning and were intrigued when we saw ancient Korean dresses wore by both men and women. The place is big which is good for strolling around enjoying the palaces and the lakes

My husband and I had a chance to visit this palace. The grounds are very nice. Great spot for photography and learning about Korean culture and history. Have on closed toe shoes made for walking because some areas around the grounds are gravel or compact soil. Worth a visit when in Seoul!

We went Nov 2016; was a interesting, historical kind of visit. If you like museums, history and sight-seeing, you should visit. There were other palaces but we decided to visit this one as it is one of the most accessible, being close to central Seoul. Furthermore, after this, we walked to the Gwanghwamun Square where we could see the protests preparation (during the weekdays)!

Furthermore, after this, we walked to the Gwanghwamun Square where we could see the protests preparation (during the weekdays)!
Excellent English language tour by knowledgable guide. Also free entry to museum kept us occupied for a couple of hours with a visit to the excellent cafe.

After around 15 mins after each of the four guard changing ceremonies during the day, there is the option to dress up (for free) as a palace guard. You get a choice of up to 4 different robes etc. And you can have a group size of up to 6 where you can all go in together to wander around the main square area. The 5 minute restriction time starts when the last member of your group is dressed!!We are loved this activity and we even had local korean students asking us to take selfies with them. The palace itself is very beautiful and worth the entrance fee to wander around the grounds. The lake is particularly beautiful.
One palace that should be visited is this one. Awesome blossoms and very beautiful!! Crowded but you still have your space.

Many of the buildings are restored with attention to the original. Make this a must-visit on your sightseeing agenda. There are a few free English speaking guides available. It is also one of the stops on sightseeing tours but they generally rush you, so I would recommend that you go on your own and enrich yourself with all the cultural and historical information. A Changing Of The Guards ceremony is particularly interesting. Nearby, also visit the Blue House, residence of the President.

This is such a nice and tranquil place where you have beautiful views, ambience, heritage, beauty of colors and calm waters all stiched together in one place where you can unwind and seek peace of mind. Amazing for photography too.

We were there to see the changing of the guards, in traditional outfits upon entering. Great place to take pictures. Grounds are very peaceful. Loved the ones dressed in traditional outfits, it adds to the experience. This also gets them free admission.

We could see cherry at the entrance of the Palace. The Palace is really big. Apart from different places or rooms you can see, the scenery inside is fantastic! I took a lot of photos of those beautiful scenes. It is really worth of paying 3000 won entry fee to have a look.
historical place and worth to visit.get to know the history of Seoul and the Joseon Dynasty.wonderful building structures.
Free entry if you are wearing hanbok. The palace closed every Tuesday. It's a good place to take photo.
Being here is like traveling back in time. Going through the palace you'll see and feel how they've lived.

If you want go to another 3 palace and Jongmyo shrine better you but package for 4 palace and Jongmyo Shrine and you can go in 1 day from morning 9.00 AM (South Korea - Seoul time) take alot of picture
There is an entertaining changing of the guards ceremony at certain time interval. You can took pictures with the guards too. An amazing historical palace to visit in Seoul.

Great place to get the early history of Seoul and the Joseon Dynasty. Wonderfully restored buildings and grounds gives insight to what life was like during this time period. Get there for the changing of the guard ceremony as it is fascinating.

Walking on a Saturday afternoon with limited time, went to this palace, terrific, just 3,000 Wan and there is a good 3 hours f sightseeing to be had. Well worth the visit and the walk to get there down the long avenue.

Worth a visit. It was spectacular in Autumn. This mostly re-constructed complex was historically interesting. The changing of the guards was contrived but entertaining enough. The real value was towards the back of the complex as the crowds thinned there were some very interesting buildings in the setting of beautiful deciduous trees which made for some great photos and memories.

We went with family and explored this amazing palace and were not disappointed. Spring is the best time--mid-April when the flowers are blooming. Be sure to visit the museums--I preferred the National Folk museum as it showed a lot more of the Korean culture. There are free guided tours in several languages during the day that start near the information center that last about 1 hour but we found just reading the brochure and taking our time the best way to go.

This palace is the largest among the grand palaces built by the Joseon Dynasty; so obviously very important part of SK's history and culture. It's huge and very picturesque esp the time we visited. It was in January this year. It snowed the day before our arrival and flurry on the day of our visit, and it covered the palace with snow and was very pretty. The visitors, being winter, were fewer, and so we're able to take beautiful photos. Also, the district where Gyeokbokgung Palace is located is my favorite. It's like the history and art district of Seoul. There were art museums, even the contemporary ones. Also it's near Bukchon Hanok Village. I really want to visit again and take more photos. Whilst the snow/winter made the photos we took looked amazing, it also cut our visit short because S.Korea's winter can be brutally cold! The snow slowed us down also as it was very slipper to walk.
What a great place to visit and see! Totally loved our tour of this site. A lot of cool history and a lot to see!

Except for central part of the palace, most were destroyed by fire or during the Japanese Invasion but be assure the rebuilding would take decades to complete.It will not be as grand as the Forbidden Palace but you can imagine the king's simple lifestyle. My guide told me, the kings were rather short-lived, died around age of around 45+ and do not have time for romance like what we saw in the korean serial.I spent an entire day here, joined guided tour in English as well as Chinese.Visited 2 free museums next to the palace as well.

Not to miss if you are in Seoul historical area. This palace was the main residence of the king for several hundred years.In front of the Gwangghwamum gate and in the inner courtyard you should also attend the guard changing ceremony provided at specific times. It lasts approx. 10 minsIt is recommended to get part of a free guided tour provided in several languages in order to learn about the historical aspect of the park and buildings .During spring time the trees are starting to bloom and everything becomes beautiful.The entry fee of 3000W (approx. 3$) is very reasonable.

If you want go to another 3 palace and Jongmyo shrine better you but package for 4 palace and Jongmyo Shrine and you can go in 1 day from morning 9.00 AM (South Korea - Seoul time) take alot of picture

Not to miss if you are in Seoul historical area. This palace was the main residence of the king for several hundred years.In front of the Gwangghwamum gate and in the inner courtyard you should also attend the guard changing ceremony provided at specific times. It lasts approx. 10 minsIt is recommended to get part of a free guided tour provided in several languages in order to learn about the historical aspect of the park and buildings .During spring time the trees are starting to bloom and everything becomes beautiful.The entry fee of 3000W (approx. 3$) is very reasonable.

Beautiful palace surrounded by various blooms of the spring. Nice place for a stroll and learn about Korea's culture and history. Exit at Gwanghwamun station Exit 9 and you can see King Sejong and Jung Yu-shin general statue at the Gwanghwamun Square on the way to the palace. If you are interested to know about their history, do drop by the King Sejong and Jung Yu-shin general Museum located just behind King Sejongas statue. There is a secret stairway leading down to the museum right behind the statue.

Make sure you stop by at the entrance of the metro in front of the palace in order to get some free traditional garb to wear. Bring an ID to leave with them. Attend the free guided tours. English was at 9am, 1130am, and 130pm. It begins right through the main gate on the right after where you have your tickets checked. It gets sunny! Bring sunglasses and some water.

If i have a foreign frind ,I would take him or her to this place. This is because this place is one of our outstanding heritages in Korea and you can see the intact palace in the middle of city. Also,you can see the performances in the palace at certain times. There are guide services, which offer at certain times. You should check out the time on the website.

It is very near to Insadonf, Buchon. Walked non stop with rented Hanbok that gave free admission to a lot of UNESCO Sites. Inviting and great royal feel in the architecture and cleverly constructed engineering around us.

Interior of palace is a bit sparse but still a nice palace to stroll through.b Definitely go for the audio guide (only krw 3000) which will make it more meaningful. Beware that you have to leave your ID as collateral for the audio device. I was a bit hesitant to leave my passport but all went well. Maybe try offering them a lesser form of ID like drivers LIC.
Beautiful big palace with many sections that have been well preserved. We were lucky to have gone there on a nice sunny day. A few trees have cherry blossoms already.

A palace strongly reminiscent of the Forbidden City in Beijing, spread out over a large area with many different buildings. They have been nicely restored and you are free to wander about. There are many displays with information in a few languages, including English, so you can get a good idea of the history.

Gyeongbokgung Palace was amazing. We got there just in time for the changing of the guard, which was much cooler than I expected. The throne room was the most impressive thing I saw in the entire country. A must visit if you're in Seoul.

It was a pleasant experience. We even got to see the changing of the guards. Cons is only when we visited there are a lot of tourists as well so the place was too crowded and its hard to get solo pictures.

Besides the magnificent structures and design of the entire Gyeongbokgung Palace and grounds, what really attracts people here is the changing of the royal guards procession that takes places everyday at 9.30am til 11am. Although they are not exactly real royal guards (like in Stockholm and London), the procession is very realistic and depicts very accurately the manner the changing of the royal guards would have been back in the days where South Korea was still ruled by a monarchy. Charges to enter the palace grounds are relatively affordable (compared to other palaces around the world) at KRW3000/adult and KRW1500/person 7-12 years. children below 6 years enters free. This is consistent with the fares charged at other royal palaces in Seoul. If you are a history buff, you would enjoy the walk-around and tour of the Gyeongbokgung palace as it is the other palace aside from Changdeokgung that has a very rich history behind it. Strongly recommend it if you want to learn more about the history of south Korea during the Joseon dynasty and if you admire the beautiful designs of traditional Korean buildings and structures. The palace opens at 9am to 6pm (depends on different seasons) so if you would like go during less crowded times, try to go in at 9am or towards the late evening to avoid the busloads of group tourists.

Beautiful palace surrounded by various blooms of the spring. Nice place for a stroll and learn about Korea's culture and history. There is a secret stairway leading down to the museum right behind the statue.

Tourists can rent beautiful traditional Hanbok/king costumes to wear around the palace to get the feel of the olden times. We were lucky to have gone there on a nice sunny day. A few trees have cherry blossoms already. Stroller rental available too. A must visit for all tourists.
nice n beatutiful palace in clear cool seoul.. we went there in winter...so this big palace look stunning with the snow on its ground...and the white mountain as background..
Nothing much to see unless you're into history and such. Guards changing ceremony was mediocre too. A few scenic spots and that's it.

Admittance was very affordable. Tour guide services was available and courteous who knew a plethora of languages. Bathrooms were very clean. Plenty of opportunities to take photos. Very serene and interesting. A must visit!
Large Palace with several courtyards and structures to visit. A great way to spend a few hours exploring.

It is a touristy attraction, changing of the guard has commentary via PA system in english, which makes the ceremony just a parade for tourists, but the palace complex is very nice and well maintained, incl. the museum.

Great heritage site to intake Korean history with a full standing historic site.The buildings and Architecture are interesting and a good look to understand more of how royals lived in ancient times.Spent approx 1.5 hours.Able to rent some olden day costumes to enhance your experience.Suggest to link it up with insadong and bukchan.

Massive complex of the restored palace, still a work in progress, but it is a lovely place. Huge area, museum just outside the grounds, easy to get to. Large numbers of people, but after you pass by the first buildings, it appears almost deserted. Buildings are quite beautifully done. Many areas make for lovely photos. Honestly, after a while it all tends to blur into on and another, as it all starts to look the same, but still a must see if you are in Seoul.
You can visit this place when in Seoul, but everything is recently rebuilt. You don't see an old palace, it's a fake.

I was planning the palace in the morning, but an accident waste 3 hrs. Basically, I searched for the palace name in one of the most famous map app and blindly follow the direction. The app took me on a train for almost 2 hrs before I realized that it's taking me to a different place. So I recommend anyone who plans to just follow an app suggestion to double check.Anyway, I finally made it to the palace, and fortunate at the exact time to see the guard change. A must visit place in Seoul.

Make sure you are there 15 min before they open 9am and go through the carpark entrance (right side street) you will see all the guards getting ready to start.Do not forget to rent a traditional custom for the fabulous pictures.. there's a lot of places near where you can rent them.

The overall palace ground is beautiful and its like a step into the past. However, the place is crowded with tourist and was quite noisy especially at the area around the main hall. The visit would be more worthwhile if visitor were allowed to enter into the buildings as most buildings are off limits to visitor and we were only allowed to view from the outside. Aside from that, there should be more description about the history of each buildings .

Entering the palace is like leaving the frenzy of Seoul outside and entering a place of quietness. Due to the policy of allowing free entrance if you appear in traditional Korean clothes enhances the atmosphere of entering a different world.The palace has very beautiful buildings giving a very good impression how the Korean Royal family lived and governed the country.

This was one of the highlights of our time in Seoul. It was easy to get to (unlike many attractions in Seoul) and we were more enchanted by it the more we walked around the grounds. There is more to see than you would expect and the photo opportunities are endless, particularly on a sunny day. We were lucky enough to see a procession come through which heightened the sense of tradition and culture. Definitely worth putting aside half a day for, especially as it's free.Just don't go on a Tuesday, as it's closed!

The place we visited is called Gyeongbok Palace & Folklore Museum, but Trip Advisor does not have an exact listing. Built in 1394 as the main palace of the Joseon Dynasty (1392-1910), the compound features typical rooms (women and men's quarters were separated), offices, meeting halls, works of art, funerary objects and items of daily life (including huge earthen pots for kim-chee, preserved cabbage).

It's an imense palace, surrounded by a peaceful neighborhood. You can walk around the palaces and trees, and enjoy the tranquility of the place. It's included a ticket to the Folklore Museum, an atraction that should not be missed.
I like the palace. If you like history you will enjoy being there but you don't need more than 20 minutes

Great place to understand Korean culture and history. If you get lucky enough or well organise try to visit it at the same time as the guards showThe palace is well maintained and there are free guided tours which gives you lots of information I strongly recommend this palace if you have only time for one

Lots of walking and lots of dull looking palace buildings. It'd be more interesting if there were more English signboards explaining the history of the building. I guess this is how tour guides make money. Do try to dress up in traditional Korean clothing but you have to arrive early to get a costume. Guard changing happens at certain hours. That's interesting to see. Exit at the Korean national folk museum to get to Hanok village.
Great place to visit. A ticket gets you in to three attractions making it very inexpensive. Very interesting place!

Make sure you are there 15 min before they open 9am and go through the carpark entrance (right side street) you will see all the guards getting ready to start.Do not forget to rent a traditional custom for the fabulous pictures.. there's a lot of places near where you can rent them.

The overall palace ground is beautiful and its like a step into the past. However, the place is crowded with tourist and was quite noisy especially at the area around the main hall. The visit would be more worthwhile if visitor were allowed to enter into the buildings as most buildings are off limits to visitor and we were only allowed to view from the outside. Aside from that, there should be more description about the history of each buildings .

Entering the palace is like leaving the frenzy of Seoul outside and entering a place of quietness. Due to the policy of allowing free entrance if you appear in traditional Korean clothes enhances the atmosphere of entering a different world.The palace has very beautiful buildings giving a very good impression how the Korean Royal family lived and governed the country.

There is more to see than you would expect and the photo opportunities are endless, particularly on a sunny day. We were lucky enough to see a procession come through which heightened the sense of tradition and culture. Definitely worth putting aside half a day for, especially as it's free.Just don't go on a Tuesday, as it's closed!

It's an imense palace, surrounded by a peaceful neighborhood. You can walk around the palaces and trees, and enjoy the tranquility of the place. It's included a ticket to the Folklore Museum, an atraction that should not be missed.

Great place to understand Korean culture and history. If you get lucky enough or well organise try to visit it at the same time as the guards showThe palace is well maintained and there are free guided tours which gives you lots of information I strongly recommend this palace if you have only time for one

Lots of walking and lots of dull looking palace buildings. It'd be more interesting if there were more English signboards explaining the history of the building. I guess this is how tour guides make money. Do try to dress up in traditional Korean clothing but you have to arrive early to get a costume. Guard changing happens at certain hours. That's interesting to see. Exit at the Korean national folk museum to get to Hanok village.
Great place to visit. A ticket gets you in to three attractions making it very inexpensive. Very interesting place!

I went on tuesday and didn't browsing before go. And what i found it was closed on tuesday ㅠㅠCouldn't see gyeongbokgung inside just i spend time around this palace. Amaze with architecture and location on center of city. Next time i will come again not on tuesday

Originally built in 14 century but later restored in 19 century because of fire, Gyeongbokgung Palace is the largest remaining palace in Seoul from the old Joseon Dynasty. It houses many old palace buildings that are still standing today, some are national treasures. However, Hyangwonjeong Pond is closed to visitors for unknown reason.  The National Palace Museum of Korea is located south of Heungnyemun Gate but is currently being renovated, and the National Folk Museum is located on the eastern side which is highly recommended. The best entrance is through Gwanghwamun gate. There are performances of guards changing ceremony taking place every day. Please find out their timing before you go. Please remember the palace is closed to visitors every Tuesday. Do not be caught unaware.
Given the historical significance this is certainly worth ONE visit, but otherwise I was not that impressed.

It's beautiful. The best thing about it for me was that if you are wearing traditional Honbok of Korea they let you in without a ticket so you see many people walking around in the traditional Korean clothes

A great place to visit.. the entrance is around 3000 won .. The place is big and has manyhouses to see.. take a sun screen as it can get hot..There are many shops around the palace which rent thier traditional clothes for 2 hours and u can get them and visit the palace. . It gives a very authentic experience.. The folk Meusum is just next to the palace. . ( inside the premises ) make sure to go there as well..

This place is a must see. Do not be in a rush, you can spend a lot of time walking around and seeing all the beautiful buildings. There are plaques everywhere so you can read about the history of the palace.

We came on the last Wed of March so entry was free, but the entry fee isn't expensive anyway. The grounds are large so even though there were lots of visitors it didn't feel crowded. We enjoyed taking photos by the pond, and there were lots of people in Korean dress which added to the atmosphere. We found the gate to the road in front of the Presidential Palace (Blue House) by chance - just look for the security guards at the far end of the complex. We also enjoyed watching the changing of the guard at 2pm, those guys must have a hard time ignoring all the visitors who get photographed beside them!
It is a good place to visit if you want to know the History of the Korean King and Queen. It is a huge place to roam around and it can be tiring as well

The palace is worth a visit atleast half a day and looks different depending on the season. In winter one can see frozen lakes inside the palace. The best way to see and know the palace is through free tours offered by Korea tourism board where you can book just a day in advance in their website. Palace has got a Rich history with separate kings and queens living places. Also you will most photographed spot in the palace where new wedding couple, kids take photo sessions. Don't miss the parade infront of the palace. National museum just outside the palace is good to visit for around 2 hours. Observe the dragons placed on top of the palace structure and paper windows. Also learn about underground heating system used during those times in the palace.
Can't be better.You can rent Han-bok (Korea traditional Clothing) from shop where close this Palace.Not serious place, but should be polite. because of Palace of Korea's.

I went on tuesday and didn't browsing before go. And what i found it was closed on tuesday ㅠㅠCouldn't see gyeongbokgung inside just i spend time around this palace. Amaze with architecture and location on center of city. Next time i will come again not on tuesday

A massive place to walk around. Lots of history. Lots of photo shots. Wednesday was free entry! It's quite close to the hotels. This place should be number one on your sightseeing list!
Is an eye opener as the palace is quite different compare to the China Forbidde city. 无论是规模还是气派，整个宫殿都没有北京故宫的气势恢宏, 而是崇尚自然的园景。
This place is incredibly beautiful from entrance to the end. There is an entrace fee but it is worth it. You have a free museum right next to it and many spots to get beautiful pictures.

Rather than book the 1 hour tour at the palace, we booked a 2 hour tour through the visitseoul.net website that is operated by the city of Seoul. The walking tour is free you just pay for your entrance to the palace. The volunteer guide, a retired banker, who took us through the site was excellent. Because of the impeachment, there was only two of us on the tour and the palace grounds were quiet. Jeon provided the background information necessary to bring the site alive. Korea has such a fascinating history. Would highly recommend booking the walking tour through visit seoul website.

pros:- a great place to learn about Korean historical site- great place for photos, walking around- dont miss the event of changing guard (traditional guard). please check the schedule- the location is nearby metro railway- you can see sakura if you're at the right timecons:- mostly are open areas, so dont forget to bring umbrellas and rain coat during rainy day- you need to pay for entrance- there are several location that may be troublesome for someone who is using wheelchair. - no proper restaurant within the palace. there is only one small coffeshop which can be easily packed with people- theres only one small gift shop within the palace - most areas within the palace are covered in dirt (not all covered with stone floor). so during a windy day can bring a lot of sand and dust. if you're allergic to sand and dust dont forget to bring mouth and nose cover.- it requires walking within the palace. theres no transportation inside palace

We went in winter and it provided the most romantic backdrop for me and my husband. it felt like it was our second honeymoon. We also managed to catch the change of guards ceremony and appreciated the english commentary explaining the actions of the guards.

We visited Gyeongbokgung Palace is the most important Palace and depicts history from the 15th - 18 century . The floors were heated to keep the royal family comfortable. The site is very large with numerous buildings and areas to explore . I would wear comfortable walking shoes and plan 2 hours to visit the whole site . This palace is located in the heart of Seoul . We visited on a Saturday which I would try to avoid . For 17 straight Saturday's there have been very large peaceful protest in support of the former President who was impeached and removed from office . These caused large traffic slowdowns and I would avoid unless you want to see democracy at work in South Korea . Gyeongbokgung Palace is a example of Korean history that was on my must see list .

Although everything has been rebuilt given the fact that it was all destroyed by conquering nations, this was a wonderful quiet and tranquil place that was in the middle of Seoul. What was most interesting to see so many young people that came dressed in old traditional costumes. Take your time and see everything.

Conveniently located at Gyeongbokgung Station, we arrived at around 10 am to catch the changing of the guards ceremony (10 am/ 11 am/ 1 pm/ 2 pm) - it only lasted for about 15 minutes or so, but was definitely very insightful. We bought our admission tickets (free for 65+) and went into the main palace. We joined the English speaking tour and our tour guide was very knowledgeable, providing us with insights into the history of South Korea and the palace.

Two thumbs up! Place to visit for tourists. The palace has some exhilarating views; lagoon, mountain, the modern buildings as back drop. One must avail a map and translator to help you go around the place. Would be advisable to bring comfortable shoe wear as the place is huge. There are also for rent traditional costumes nearby for the tourists for pictorial purposes.
A massive place to walk around. Lots of history. Lots of photo shots. Wednesday was free entry! It's quite close to the hotels. This place should be number one on your sightseeing list!

Went here in the morning to catch changing of royal guard ceremony.Lots of tourist at this time. This palace is big so you need to allot more time to look around. Wear comfy shoes & prepare yourself for a walkathon

I was planning to join a half-day tour of the palace but realized the hop-on-hop-off bus stopped not far from it. Go in the morning to avoid the crowds. Don't miss the changing of the guards. It's a nice recreation. The grounds are pleasant to walk around. But there were too many tourists dressed in the Korean national outfits. A bit too cheesy for me.
I recommend to visit the palace when you are wearing old korean cloth and take a photo graph. the photograph will be one of your favorite.

Sprawling area with huge gates, stairs, separate zones for the military and the illiterate. Statues that depict some humour can be found in the compound. Heated floors have also been thought of to keep the King and his family and staff warm. A historical site, good to spend some time. Best use a guided tour or the audio guide to gain more insights. Worth the visit but need to wear good walking shoes as the grounds are massive.
Gyeongbokgun palace is definitely a place to learn and feel Korean history and culture. Guide was explaining very good, in detail. I wish I had more time there

Unfortunately most of what is original to Korea has had to be rebuilt. The lack of authenticity was excused when so many of the tourists visitinnworebtradional clothing. It is an interesting walkin museum

Viaited this palace in mid-March 2017 with my wife. We arrived at 2 PM and managed to watch the guard changing ceremony. We toured the palace with the free walking tour. Our guide, Mr. Chang, was very friendly, nice and knowledgable. The palace complex was huge. It took us around 2 hours to complete the tour. Different sections gave me different feelings. The main gate, the courtyard and the main palace building awed me. The beautiful pavillion at the back was so serene. Considering the relatively cheap ticket price and the whole experience, it was totally worth it.
Such a beautiful location. We learnt a lot about the history of Korean royals. Would highly recommend taking the walking tour.

Just like the other palace, you will see older building and not too many surprise ! But it is very good culture learning and beautiful gardening . We were there a bit too early , the weather is very cold. Suggest visit Korea after March .

In Seoul city there are near about four Kings Palace. Among them the Gyeongbokgung Palace is the most important, centrally located and covers a larger area. The heritage palace is nicely maintained and depicts the Korean history from the 15TH TO 18TH Century. Please visit the palace prior to 4 pm otherise you cant by ticket to enter inside the palace
