The heritage palace is nicely maintained and depicts the Korean history from the 15TH TO 18TH Century. Please visit the palace prior to 4 pm otherise you cant by ticket to enter inside the palace

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a wonderful place to visit and a must when in Seoul. Truly magnificent. The view is spectacular and one should try to put on the traditional garb and enjoy relieving Korea's glorious past.

Let me tell you first, that the entrance fee to this place is only 3,000 krw (less than $3). This is incredibly cheap, considering how vast and large this place is. Also, if you rent and wear a hanbok from any hanbok rental shop near the palace, your entrance fee is FREE.I really recommend going here with a tour guide because it's really incredible listening to the history behind each building and architectural element, starting from the ondol floor heating technology dating back to the Joseon era, to the different symbolisms embedded into the walls, floors, and roofs of the palace. Much of the palace was destroyed by the Japanese forces during the Japanese occupation, and some buildings have still not been restored. You can also visit the residence and deathplace of Queen Myeongseong, who was assassinated by the Japanese in the 1900s.I would say Gyeongbokgung takes a good 2 hours to fully look around. But definitely, Gyeongbokgung is a must-visit for any travelers wanting to experience the history of Korea.

I'm a Kdrama fan and finally traveled to South Korea with the hopes of visiting significant places that are always shown in a drama. I don't know why but I'm into Saguek kind of drama with Kings (Wang) and Crown Princes (Seja) as the main characters. That is why my first stop is the Gyeongbukgong palace. I was imagining as i was there how the entourage of the king of about 20 or almost, would follow him wherever he goes and when he talks to any of his concubines let's say outside of their quarters, those entourage will look the other way and pretend not to hear anything. Although the palace was flocked by tourists everyday, i'm glad i was able to see it and its beautiful garden. I went there last autumn season and the trees were very colorful, needless to say, a sight for sore eyes. Just take the subway in going there. You can go down Gyeongbukgong station, which is the nearest to the palace or go down Gwangwamun station and see first Statues of King Sejong and admiral Yi in Gwangwamun square then head straight to the gates of Gwangwamun then the palace itself. The famous Cheonggyecheon stream is also nearby. Since i was traveling solo, selfies overload was what happened. Anyways i enjoyed every minute of it. Turns out it wasn't boring traveling solo afterall.

The highlight of my visit to Gyeongbokgung Palace is the Changing of the Guards ceremony. Make sure to schedule your visit or watch out for the actual changing of the guards schedule while you are the the vicinity of the palace. It is an experience that you will not regret! You may even take a picture or a video while the ceremony is taking place. Walking distance from the Gwanghwamun Square. Don't miss this on your trip to Seoul, South Korea!

Tour guide did a good job showing my friends around. Good time management and good explanation. Were really having a good time and will totally bring my friend here again. Winter time is the best to visit such place.

This place is accessible via subway (Gyeongbokgung Station) and follow the signs for the exits.There is an open area for you to take pictures at the main entrance if you just want a keep sake with some of the palace architecture in the background. However, if it is you first time, I would recommend paying a small fee to enter to see the entire palace ground at least once. This place is huge so be prepared to walk around a lot. But every corner was mesmerising. Especially if you're into those period dramas - you could picture what it was like in those days because some of the buildings have actual furniture (chairs, beds, vases, books, shelves etc.) so you get to see what the rooms might have looked like in the past. There is security around so it is pretty safe. If you're going in the day, bring your sunglasses because this place has lots of bare sandy ground and can get quite bright. Lots of photo ops and you can rent hanboks nearby to really blend in and get into the period atmosphere if you'd like. If you'd like a shot without too many tourists in the picture, there are many secluded spots towards the back of the palace. They have guided tours too that will help you to learn more about the history. In all, I would recommend to visit this place at least once.

My wife and I decided to visit the Gyeongbokgung Palace yesterday morning to acquaint ourselves with some culture and history of this vibrant nation of South Korea.We took a cab there for convenience instead of going by subway.We went there early at 9.30am because we wanted to witness the Ceremony of Gate Guard Change. This is held twice everyday at 10am and 2pm except on Tuesday when the palace is closed. The guards in full ancient soldier attire will march into the royal courtyard to the accompaniment of a marching band comprising, drums, trumpets and cymbals. It's quite spectacular to watch . This was the highlight of our tour . As for the palace tour , it is not as grand as what I have seen in China by comparison. There is an entry fee of 3,000 won per person and seniors above 65 enter free of charge . So if you are a senior don't forget to bring along your passport to show your age to qualify for the free entry.

When the KDramas were in bloom in 2000's, I was dreaming Korea as my home. I never expected that it became a reality. I love all the places especially where these historical destinations. I was really amazed when I got in the gate, there are 4 palaces to visit. This was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty. Best visited during Cherry Blossom seasons (in my opinion).

As you can see from the title, yes, free entrance is possible if you rent a hanbok (Korean traditional clothes). There's shops near Gyeongbokgong that rent out the hanboks. You can do some research first before going. And if you're like me, you've been there and just want to walk around taking pictures as well as seeing the shift changing of the gate guards, arrive there around 1:00pm or 1:20pm. If not mistaken, the ceremony starts at 1:30pm. For me, I've been there like 4 times and I've already know how the palace looks like, so I just walk around Gwanghwamun without paying a cent to enter the palace. Besides, there's a museum near the subway exit near Gyeongbokgong which is FREE OF CHARGE.
One of the tourists spot that you must not missed. A lot of foreigners wearing Korean costumes and have pictorial in the place. It's a vast place to walk so wear a comfortable shoes.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a wonderful place to visit and a must when in Seoul. Truly magnificent. The view is spectacular and one should try to put on the traditional garb and enjoy relieving Korea's glorious past.

Let me tell you first, that the entrance fee to this place is only 3,000 krw (less than $3). This is incredibly cheap, considering how vast and large this place is. Also, if you rent and wear a hanbok from any hanbok rental shop near the palace, your entrance fee is FREE.I really recommend going here with a tour guide because it's really incredible listening to the history behind each building and architectural element, starting from the ondol floor heating technology dating back to the Joseon era, to the different symbolisms embedded into the walls, floors, and roofs of the palace. Much of the palace was destroyed by the Japanese forces during the Japanese occupation, and some buildings have still not been restored. You can also visit the residence and deathplace of Queen Myeongseong, who was assassinated by the Japanese in the 1900s.I would say Gyeongbokgung takes a good 2 hours to fully look around. But definitely, Gyeongbokgung is a must-visit for any travelers wanting to experience the history of Korea.

Although the palace was flocked by tourists everyday, i'm glad i was able to see it and its beautiful garden. I went there last autumn season and the trees were very colorful, needless to say, a sight for sore eyes. Just take the subway in going there. You can go down Gyeongbukgong station, which is the nearest to the palace or go down Gwangwamun station and see first Statues of King Sejong and admiral Yi in Gwangwamun square then head straight to the gates of Gwangwamun then the palace itself. The famous Cheonggyecheon stream is also nearby. Since i was traveling solo, selfies overload was what happened. Anyways i enjoyed every minute of it. Turns out it wasn't boring traveling solo afterall.

The highlight of my visit to Gyeongbokgung Palace is the Changing of the Guards ceremony. Make sure to schedule your visit or watch out for the actual changing of the guards schedule while you are the the vicinity of the palace. It is an experience that you will not regret! You may even take a picture or a video while the ceremony is taking place. Walking distance from the Gwanghwamun Square. Don't miss this on your trip to Seoul, South Korea!

Tour guide did a good job showing my friends around. Good time management and good explanation. Were really having a good time and will totally bring my friend here again. Winter time is the best to visit such place.

This place is accessible via subway (Gyeongbokgung Station) and follow the signs for the exits.There is an open area for you to take pictures at the main entrance if you just want a keep sake with some of the palace architecture in the background. However, if it is you first time, I would recommend paying a small fee to enter to see the entire palace ground at least once. This place is huge so be prepared to walk around a lot. But every corner was mesmerising. Especially if you're into those period dramas - you could picture what it was like in those days because some of the buildings have actual furniture (chairs, beds, vases, books, shelves etc.) so you get to see what the rooms might have looked like in the past. There is security around so it is pretty safe. If you're going in the day, bring your sunglasses because this place has lots of bare sandy ground and can get quite bright. Lots of photo ops and you can rent hanboks nearby to really blend in and get into the period atmosphere if you'd like. If you'd like a shot without too many tourists in the picture, there are many secluded spots towards the back of the palace. They have guided tours too that will help you to learn more about the history. In all, I would recommend to visit this place at least once.

My wife and I decided to visit the Gyeongbokgung Palace yesterday morning to acquaint ourselves with some culture and history of this vibrant nation of South Korea.We took a cab there for convenience instead of going by subway.We went there early at 9.30am because we wanted to witness the Ceremony of Gate Guard Change. This is held twice everyday at 10am and 2pm except on Tuesday when the palace is closed. The guards in full ancient soldier attire will march into the royal courtyard to the accompaniment of a marching band comprising, drums, trumpets and cymbals. It's quite spectacular to watch . This was the highlight of our tour . As for the palace tour , it is not as grand as what I have seen in China by comparison. There is an entry fee of 3,000 won per person and seniors above 65 enter free of charge . So if you are a senior don't forget to bring along your passport to show your age to qualify for the free entry.

When the KDramas were in bloom in 2000's, I was dreaming Korea as my home. I never expected that it became a reality. I love all the places especially where these historical destinations. I was really amazed when I got in the gate, there are 4 palaces to visit. This was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty. Best visited during Cherry Blossom seasons (in my opinion).

As you can see from the title, yes, free entrance is possible if you rent a hanbok (Korean traditional clothes). There's shops near Gyeongbokgong that rent out the hanboks. You can do some research first before going. And if you're like me, you've been there and just want to walk around taking pictures as well as seeing the shift changing of the gate guards, arrive there around 1:00pm or 1:20pm. If not mistaken, the ceremony starts at 1:30pm. For me, I've been there like 4 times and I've already know how the palace looks like, so I just walk around Gwanghwamun without paying a cent to enter the palace. Besides, there's a museum near the subway exit near Gyeongbokgong which is FREE OF CHARGE.
One of the tourists spot that you must not missed. A lot of foreigners wearing Korean costumes and have pictorial in the place. It's a vast place to walk so wear a comfortable shoes.
Great place to learn history. You should take the tour because you get to know more about the place. You also get to see the blue house where the current president lives.
Is was wonderful to visit here , during winter time and u can see the ground is all cover with snow , very cold and I enjoy the scenery here and people here all are very friendly .

3 TIPS TO ENJOY THE GYEONGBOKGUNG PALACE1. Rent a traditional costume.You can get stunning photos while wearing a traditional costume within the palace grounds. Search online for where to rent a hanbok. 2. Get a map.Plan your route, evade the huge crowd of tourists and still cover all the spots of the palace. Maps are available before entering the gates.3. Wear comfortable shoes.You won’t want to be limping through your time travel or be distracted by a painful blister.

Visited the palace on a Sunday many korean people dressed in taraditional costumes. The palace is very grand and steeped with history. There are so many beautiful sections to see in apeacful environment.

I definitely recommend visiting the palace wearing a hanbok. It adds quite an authentic look to your photos! Join the free tour which starts at the information center near the main gate. But join the earlier schedule so you won't be rushed in the afternoon as they close on time. The guards were shooing us away as we were still taking photos. We had to keep on running and stop for a bit to continue taking photos when the guards were busy shooing other visitors! Worth the visit only if you join the tour as this would give you an idea why and how the whole place came to be.

One of must visit palace in seoul.Their palace sure are huge..but this is the hugest palace and need lot of walk.for me once is enough, I walked for over two hours there.But very nice experience..Maybe will bring my family for tour, but personally i won't come back by myself.its easy to get lost

This is a don't miss experience for any tourist in Seoul. The palace grounds are extensive and the thing to be sure you don't miss is the changing of the guard ceremony, which occurs several times during the day. It's bright and colorful and occurs just outside the gate between the palace walls and the bus parking on the east side. You can hear the drums from anywhere inside, but they do block the entrance for awhile as the guard passes....the best photo spot in between the parade grounds and the bus park. There's not a whole lot else to do inside the palace but do walk it and get a feeling for the grandeur of times past.

My mom is not a fan of museums and she was totally blown away by the structures and the interesting backstory. It is beautiful there and if you arrive in time you can join one of the free multi lingual tours! Highly recommend it.

We went to this beautiful landmark early in the morning to avoid the crowd. We only have a little time left in Seoul so we did our tour inside quickly. Many tourist in groups often stop near the entrance taking pics etc blocking your way lol so to skip this, keep on walking inside as the palace is huge. Not much description written on each room in the palace, or maybe we just had to take the guide book or something at the entrance. We did the whole palace in 1 hour by keep on walking and taking pics quickly.

Originally built in 1395, this complex was the seat of the Joseon Dynasty until destroyed by the Japanese in the 1590’s. Instead of rebuilding, the royal family moved to another palace site. In 1867-68, the Prince Regent sponsored a reconstruction. Unfortunately, it again was almost totally destroyed during the second Japanese occupation prior to World War II, and the events of the Korean War. Restoration work began again in 1989, but according to our guide, only about 50% of the buildings have been completed. Nonetheless it is a fascinating place to visit and easily accessible. Inevitably, one will compare it to The Forbidden City because of similar design, but on a smaller scale. Make sure that you see Gyeonghoeru Pavilion (on the lake), one of the structures that dates from the 1867 restoration. It was used for entertainment when important foreign visitors visited the palace. Another point of interest is the video that deals with the assassination of Empress Myeongseong by Japanese agents in 1895 (and her quarters). One thing that added charm to our visit was the large number of young folks wearing traditional dress. Evidently, the clothes are available for rental and this has become a “thing to do” on a date, or just a lark.
Great place to learn history. You should take the tour because you get to know more about the place. You also get to see the blue house where the current president lives.
Is was wonderful to visit here , during winter time and u can see the ground is all cover with snow , very cold and I enjoy the scenery here and people here all are very friendly .

Wear comfortable shoes.You won’t want to be limping through your time travel or be distracted by a painful blister.

We had to keep on running and stop for a bit to continue taking photos when the guards were busy shooing other visitors! Worth the visit only if you join the tour as this would give you an idea why and how the whole place came to be.

Many tourist in groups often stop near the entrance taking pics etc blocking your way lol so to skip this, keep on walking inside as the palace is huge. Not much description written on each room in the palace, or maybe we just had to take the guide book or something at the entrance. We did the whole palace in 1 hour by keep on walking and taking pics quickly.

Inevitably, one will compare it to The Forbidden City because of similar design, but on a smaller scale. Make sure that you see Gyeonghoeru Pavilion (on the lake), one of the structures that dates from the 1867 restoration. It was used for entertainment when important foreign visitors visited the palace. Another point of interest is the video that deals with the assassination of Empress Myeongseong by Japanese agents in 1895 (and her quarters). One thing that added charm to our visit was the large number of young folks wearing traditional dress. Evidently, the clothes are available for rental and this has become a “thing to do” on a date, or just a lark.

There's a metro station just beside the palace so it's very easy to go to. On the front gate, you may take your pictures with the royal palace guards. And every hour, there's a performance where the guards change their duty shift. Apparently, there's a little ceremony for that!Once the performance is done (roughly after ten minutes), the application for the use of guards costume opens. But you have to very quick because they only accommodate max of 10 pax per time slot. We were just lucky enough to be included!!! You may choose from the 4 costumes you want to try. Once you're on it, you can only wander along the ground but not too far! So it's just good for taking pictures. :)Entrance to the palace is 3000 won for adults. Palace ground is huge and very picturesque so it's worth your while to roam around. :)
Here is the large palace and it is big enough, there are the lake, garden, trees and the location is in city.We can go here using public transportation such us train, bus or taxi
Nicely maintained and serene atmosphere. People who have visited many indian palaces would find it too plain .. but worth the short time it takes to complete the same. enjoy

If you are limited for time then of the main tourists sites this would be my recommendation for the one to do. Located within easy walking distance of City Hall the palace is a juxtaposition of the surrounding modern buildings. Very relaxing to take a stroll around the grounds and when we visited in early afternoon the reflections of some of the buildings on the water were stunning. It is also worthwhile taking in the National Palace Museum which is located near the main entrance and is free to enter after you have paid your initial entrance fee of KRW3K. Great value for money and a wonderful place to great away from the hubris of the City and see the locals ( and some foreigners) dressing up in local costumes.

A beautiful historic site. Similar in layout to Forbidden City in Beijing but on a smaller scale. Beautifully restored and maintained buildings. This site must not be missed on any visit to Seoul. Not suitable for mobility challenged as considerable walking is required and some stairs. Folk museum is on site with excellent exhibits, gift shop and washrooms.

Every time I've been to Seoul on business trip, I go to visit Gyeongbokgung Palace with different people from my countries. We usually have no tourist guide and our people are not good at English as well as Korean so I have to introduce them about this palace by myself. The more I visit this palace, the more I feel how great it is. Even it was burnt down once but Korean people rebuilt and re-act all the activity so people can understand what happened there several hundred years ago. It's also very good place to take a walk then you can enjoy very nice food so called Samgyetang at a very famous restaurant nearby.It's really nice place for visiting at any time of the year.

The place itself was amazing! it's combined with nature and a very exquisite design..it was a great place to take pictures and to go if you're wearing hanbok. yes, i was there and wore hanbok. The pictures and the traditional place was a match made in heaven! You should try!..if you're into the architecture and design, this place is for you. but I guess they're trying to build up the new building when was there.

This used to be the main palace but many of the original buildings were burnt down. Nothing much to see except the pond and the little pavilion here. You can either purchase a single ticket for this palace or a combined ticket for all 4 palaces. All the palaces are connected. A secret garden is a must to see.

The palace was very designed and harmonised with the beauty of the surrounding nature. You could appreciate the creativity of the designers of the palace. At the end of the tour, I was most touched by the sad story of the Queen who was assassinated by the Japanese soldiers. Visitors are allowed to watch a video of the story, visit her rooms and imagine the atrocities happened in the past. Highly recommended.

This place is on a defifnite must-do list if it's your first time to Seoul! Filled with so much culture and history, you need to come here! Beautiful in the fall and the spring (but I also went in the summer and sweated and still had fun), it's a must-do in Seoul.

This is like the main palace in Seoul. Although it is very crowded with tourists, and this is the second time I've visited the place, I am still awed by the structure and how one can experience history in these modern times. It is inexpensive to enter and you can enter the museum for free.

Honestly, I had no time to walk around the palace i just walk only outside of palace but i could say i miss this that i did not go inside anyway even outside it really nice place, unique i recommend you to visit

Living in the Seoul area, I have visited Gyeongbokgung Palace many times with friends and family. It is BIG and accommodates all the visitors it receives from schools, tour groups, and explorers like me quite easily. There are so many things to photograph including the guard changing ceremonies at the gate and the procession that takes place in the large square. Although I have been here several times, I find that I am discovering sights I overlooked the first time, which makes it interesting for me when I accompany first time visitors. For extra fun, consider renting traditional Korean clothing to wear as you tour, because being in a historical location wearing historical clothing makes your photos even better! There is a small admission fee and you need to make sure the palace is open the day you go (it is closed on Tuesdays and the hours of operation vary by season). If you enjoy historic sights, interesting architecture, and beautiful scenery and if you don't mind walking (wear good shoes), this is one of the places to go in Seoul. Fans of historical Korean dramas should not miss Gyeongbokgung Palace!

Lovely place to visit. Shame the original palace was destroyed.But great that koreans are rebuilding it (as best as possible) to preserve their history. I guess in the summer it's even more beautiful.We we lucky that a high school student, Mary, offered to guide us. We got lots of information about Korean traditions, old customs and history.. And lots of information about the palaces history.We spend several hours there before heading to the Folk Museum in the area.

The Admission: 3,000 won.The Palace: One of the biggest palace in Seoul. Beautiful architecture!! This palace was the first royal palace built in the Joseon Dynasty. Sumunjang changing of the guard ceremony(twice a day) 10am & 2pm.Gwanghwamum changing of the guard ceremony (twice a day) 11am & 1pm.They also offer English, Japanes and Chinese guided tour.The Location: Subway Line 3, Gyeongbokgung Station, Exit 5

We went here late afternoon and spent atleast an hour. On our way to the palace, we passed by a group of uniformed students who offers FREE TOUR of the palace. We took that tour and it was nice of them to assist us from were to buy tickets to the palace which is 3,000 won to where is the best spot to take a photo of the palace. The tour is very informative and enlightening about the Joseon Dynasty. Tips:1. If you rent a Hanbok, you can have free access/entrance on the palaces. A lot of tourist local/foreign wore hanbok inside the palace.2. Take the free tour offered by the studentsDirection:Take Metro Line 3 Orange Line. Get off at Gyeongbokgung Station and take Exit 5. Walk straight ahead until you pass by the museum.Palace is closed every Tuesday

The place is beautiful, the mountains on one side and the modern buildings on the other makes this a unique sight! Combine a tour at the palace and it's surrounding buildings with a visit to the National Museum of Korean Contemporary History, just across the street.

Nice palace. Well maintained attraction. Very inexpensive to get in. The grounds are large, so on a nice day, this is a very nice walk. Would've been nice to see on of the buildings furnished as it would've looked during the period. So after looking at many buildings, we got kinda bored.
This place is so beautiful with unique building. I can feel korean historical culture there. I love this place soooo much. Of course, wanna visit there again one day.
Brings back memories of Korean dramas, not so big grounds, easy to walk around, good outing site for a bit of fresh air in a metropolitan city.

Honestly, I had no time to walk around the palace i just walk only outside of palace but i could say i miss this that i did not go inside anyway even outside it really nice place, unique i recommend you to visit

This place is so beautiful with unique building. I can feel korean historical culture there. I love this place soooo much. Of course, wanna visit there again one day.

A nice palace in the city with some photos spot. Don't forget to bring your camera with you as there are some other places of interest located nearby Gyeongbokgung Palace too. Easy to find and only few minute walk from Anguk Station. Went there on early March with cold weather, the palace was crowded with tourist and many people wear traditional dress. Entrance fee is KRW 3,000 per person.

This is not a place to go in cold months! You are practically all the time outside and keeping in mind that Korea has a pretty cold winter weather .... otherwise it's really interesting. Did you know they had central heating ....
i arrived around 10 am and at the same time with changing guard ceremony in the place. The view of nature was very beautiful with the snow was falling that day.
bring food and hot drinks, other than that we like this historic place, to get free entrance wear a hanbuk, confirm free, rent it or buy it just outside the palace

This Palace located near the hotel we stayed so we decided to visit it once. It was a great place to get to know about the Korean's history. You might need half day to complete this place. A beautiful place to see if you travel to Korea!

If you don't have much time in Seoul, this is one of the palaces you can definitely visit the next time around. Go to the Modern Art Museum or some smaller art galleries instead. The changing of guards at Gwanghwamun (the Gate at Gyeongbokgung) is OK but the group felt small, not sure historically if the number of guards would have been more. If you do choose to visit, it would be much more enjoyable if you joined a guided tour with your admission ticket. The guide is very knowledgable but you'll find a lot of the buildings have not been fully restored since the grounds were pretty much systematically demolished during the Japanese Rule in the early 20th century.

Gyeongbok Palace is the largest in Seoul, completed in1395. King Taejo also built Changdeok Palace completed in 1405. Yi Seonggye an army general that overthrew the government and took the name King Taejo. Yi started the Joseoy Dynasty which ruled from 1392 to 1910. ending with the defeat in the first Sino-Japanese War. He moved the Capital from Gaegyeong to Hanyang (later became Seoul). Gyeongbok Palace is not only beautiful, its history where all the social attitudes formed, powerful etiquette, and the cultural norms..

Gyeongbokgung Palace is the biggest palace in Seoul. It shows a very important part of Korean history, reflecting how people used to live.The gardens are pretty large, with many buildings in the area. As the palace is in a very historical area, there are many "hanbok" renters around, and tourists may dress in Hanbok for authentic experience. As for me, watching people around in Hanbok was very interesting. A not-to-miss is "the change of guards ceremony" - takes place at 10:00 and 14:00. This is a reenactment of the original ceremony from 1400's, takes about 20 minutes and they announce the actions in Korean and English.Also, you can dress-up as guards for authentic photos. The Gyeonghoeru Pavilion on Hyangwonjeong Pond the biggest pavillon in Korea, and it is a beautiful view with the mountains at the back.Strolling in the gardens of this palace and viewing the mountains, trees and ponds, I felt like in a movie from the old times.
Great to visit , cheap 3000 Won ( <3$) , tranquil, mountains one side & the city the other.Nice to stroll round & reflex.

The traditional buildings were very beautiful and interesting to see. The changing of the guard ceremony was also nice to see. There were lots of Korean young women in traditional dress, which was fun. I visited before spring had really gotten started, so the grounds were still brown for winter. I can imagine the grounds would be quite beautiful for walking in the spring as things start to get green.

A nice palace in the city with some photos spot. Don't forget to bring your camera with you as there are some other places of interest located nearby Gyeongbokgung Palace too. Easy to find and only few minute walk from Anguk Station. Went there on early March with cold weather, the palace was crowded with tourist and many people wear traditional dress. Entrance fee is KRW 3,000 per person.

This is not a place to go in cold months! You are practically all the time outside and keeping in mind that Korea has a pretty cold winter weather .... otherwise it's really interesting. Did you know they had central heating ....
i arrived around 10 am and at the same time with changing guard ceremony in the place. The view of nature was very beautiful with the snow was falling that day.
bring food and hot drinks, other than that we like this historic place, to get free entrance wear a hanbuk, confirm free, rent it or buy it just outside the palace

This Palace located near the hotel we stayed so we decided to visit it once. It was a great place to get to know about the Korean's history. You might need half day to complete this place. A beautiful place to see if you travel to Korea!

If you don't have much time in Seoul, this is one of the palaces you can definitely visit the next time around. Go to the Modern Art Museum or some smaller art galleries instead. The changing of guards at Gwanghwamun (the Gate at Gyeongbokgung) is OK but the group felt small, not sure historically if the number of guards would have been more. If you do choose to visit, it would be much more enjoyable if you joined a guided tour with your admission ticket. The guide is very knowledgable but you'll find a lot of the buildings have not been fully restored since the grounds were pretty much systematically demolished during the Japanese Rule in the early 20th century.

Gyeongbok Palace is the largest in Seoul, completed in1395. King Taejo also built Changdeok Palace completed in 1405. Yi Seonggye an army general that overthrew the government and took the name King Taejo. Yi started the Joseoy Dynasty which ruled from 1392 to 1910. ending with the defeat in the first Sino-Japanese War. He moved the Capital from Gaegyeong to Hanyang (later became Seoul). Gyeongbok Palace is not only beautiful, its history where all the social attitudes formed, powerful etiquette, and the cultural norms..

Gyeongbokgung Palace is the biggest palace in Seoul. It shows a very important part of Korean history, reflecting how people used to live.The gardens are pretty large, with many buildings in the area. As the palace is in a very historical area, there are many "hanbok" renters around, and tourists may dress in Hanbok for authentic experience. As for me, watching people around in Hanbok was very interesting. A not-to-miss is "the change of guards ceremony" - takes place at 10:00 and 14:00. This is a reenactment of the original ceremony from 1400's, takes about 20 minutes and they announce the actions in Korean and English.Also, you can dress-up as guards for authentic photos. The Gyeonghoeru Pavilion on Hyangwonjeong Pond the biggest pavillon in Korea, and it is a beautiful view with the mountains at the back.Strolling in the gardens of this palace and viewing the mountains, trees and ponds, I felt like in a movie from the old times.
Great to visit , cheap 3000 Won ( <3$) , tranquil, mountains one side & the city the other.Nice to stroll round & reflex.

The traditional buildings were very beautiful and interesting to see. The changing of the guard ceremony was also nice to see. There were lots of Korean young women in traditional dress, which was fun. I visited before spring had really gotten started, so the grounds were still brown for winter. I can imagine the grounds would be quite beautiful for walking in the spring as things start to get green.
there is a small pond or lake inside this huge propertypalace is actually small but lots of open areas for walkingsecurity staff aplenty
I recommend seoul city tour. Excellent guides. Beware travelling on any Saturday. They are protesting against/for the S korean President. The traffic was literally deadlocked after 2pm.
It is okay for photoshoot. People came and rent Hanbok for nice pictures. The place are huge and need up to 4 hours to explore the whole place.

We didn't learn that much as we didn't have a guide. Nonetheless, it's a nice thing to walk through if you're in the area. If you have no special interest in old buildings then leave it out if you're on a short visit. I would personally then climb a mountain instead.

It's easy to access there.1. Line no 3 - orange line - get off Kyong Bok Palace. gate no 5 to the palace.  it consist of several palace building. the most beautiful and greatest palace.2. you can also walk to there from Kwang Hua Moon or City hall. 3. in the palace, there is a museum. it's quite good place to go. 4. on it's right side, there is Sam Chung Dong. now it becomes a famous place  Korean Traditional style houses(Han Oak) village. it's good place of walking.
This is a great place to make beautiful photos and enjoy the local culture. You will need a lot of walking, but it's nice. I wish I took more photos. But I have a great time and memories.
The Palace was easy to go via the train.. the buildings were awesome and so old but well maintained. Amenities like toilets are clean.
Come and get the feeling of being in a place that hundreds of years ago the living history of the country were walking around. Great feeling, beautiful palace and landscape

You can't visit Korea without seeing this palace and witnessing the changing of the guards. Rich history and amazing architecture. I thought travelling at winter time would be a problem, but it ended up perfect, lesser crowd for one and nice to walk around when it's not hot.

Besides the main palace and the man-made lake, there's really not much to see here. Lots of empty space. Be sure to wear sunblock when visiting in summer. The National Folk Museum is in the palace if you're into museums. Changgyeonggung Palace and Changdeokgung palace while smaller, are much more interesting in my opinion. There is much more to see and appreciate in these palaces than Gyeongbokgung.

The palace is very large and is broken down into several sections depending on where you stand in life. Meaning Royalty, servants, and others. Royals also have several house within palace for safety reasons. And whT animals on the roof means and color of roof means. Your need a guided tour to learn everything.
either stroll around or, what I prefer, just sit and take in the scenery, let you thoughts do the walking and relax in the middle of a busy city

Missed this historical landmark and attraction with our first visit last year. Didn't want to make the same mistake this time! We were able to walk from the hanok we were renting to the south gate of the palace. The changing of the guards ceremony welcomed us which was fascinating to watch (It occurs four times daily). Afterwards, we toured the grounds and different restored structures and buildings - all beautiful particularly the lakes and landscaping around the buildings ! We spent most of the time in the National Folk Museum where it was not only WARM, it was marvelously arranged by themes and organized with facinating exhibits! Highly recommend!

This place is great for walking. It is big and beautiful. And so oriental. And there were a lot of young girls in national dresses. There is not only a palace, but also a park with lake. And nice trees.
The show is worth to see. Very traditional Korea. Highly recommended . Interesting place and a lot of tourist. Easy access on parking. Ticket entrance very affordable
Nice historic palace. The guide came free: very knowledgeable and friendly. We booked the guide online before going, and she arrived punctually and gave us an hours tour

We are so happy to heony moon at South Korea, we just only say 4 days at Seoul, whatever you go, you can see the yellow and red tree, look so romantic, you can take MTR easy to join the trip, there a lot of shopping hall, and the things is cheaper, we try to eat their Korea food of the （Gejang）soy sauce of crab, the crab did't cook, they clean the crab after they catch, put them in their soy sauce at less 7 days, this is my first time to eat the fresh crab, it's sweet and the sauce is good, the higlight you must put the rice in the raw crab, mix together eat, it's was delicious! The set for it many other side dishes see attach photo, 20000 won only.

This is the biggest palace and a must see when in Seoul and very picturesque. The architecture was grand, so ancient, and very impressive. The gardens were very relaxing and lovely in Autumn. Don't miss the changing of the guards ceremony at the main gate entrance at 10 am- 4 PM hourly. Highly recommend the free guided English tour offered daily at 11 AM, gives you insight into different aspects of the architecture and culture. The Korean Folk Museum inside was very neat if you are interested in Korean history and the the different Monarch's. Autumn was lovely time to visit. The palace grounds are so nicely maintained and very safe. I was there at the end of November and it was comfortable in layers during the day. Palaces close at 5 so dress warmly if you plan to be out and about in the evening.

Out of all the places I visited on my 6-day trip to Seoul, this is my favorite. Went there during winter and it was amazing. Wasn't able to cover the whole palace during my 2-hour visit. Would visit again if I come back to Seoul.
This palace is one of the largest and most precious ones in Korea. It is really easy to approach in Seoul.

This palace is one of the largest and most precious ones in Korea. It is really easy to approach in Seoul.

Gyungbok palace is one of the MUST visit places if you want to have a tour in Seoul. if you compare with forbiden city in Peiking, feeling is very different with that one. It will be interesting to compare two different palace. Walking along the main building to the backside ponds with Queen's place, you can feel from the enormous authority to the relaxed calmness.Good fun with Korean traditional cloth,Hanbok, you can have free pass if you rent a cloth and enter the palce wearing Hanbok. This will give you much fun with good memorial photo.As Korea has 4 distintive seasons, different seasonal visiting will provide you totally different feeling as well.
Love the architecture and the fact that they make sure that the palace grounds are kept clean and restored! Popular place to see a glimpse of history.
One of recommended palace in seoul you can go there with subway to gyeongbokgung station. There is a change of guard ceremony every day at 10 am don't miss it.
An ancient castle, huge and amazing, very unique design and artful. Also here we can see how Korea perform the ceremony the royal army escort door replacement is carried out.
It was in same place with korean folk museum. Check to close day, in my opinion best time to go there is april or may, its so cold in winter and there is no flower

Worth to go to Gyeongbokgung for sightseeing and for quick photo-taking. Will be much nicer if tourists choose to sightsee during autumn season. Attraction fee for each adult is KRW 3000. Tourists may purchase the one-day pass which includes the entry of all Korean palaces.

I visited this palace twice, once in the summer and another during winter and I can say that both experiences were amazing, since the scenery of lakes and trees makes the place very different. My only advice is during winter wear warm clothes with layers, protect your hands and head and enjoy the tranquility of this place.There is a change of guard at 10:00am every day with narration so the visitors will understand what the ceremony is about. Arrive a few minutes early to get a good spot to see it. There are other times during the day, check in the website. I bought the ticket next to the main gate and I also got the booklet with information. There are tours in several languages but I did not want to wait for the English tour that would start at 11:00am and just wondered on my own. It is very busy but don't get intimidated with the crowds. If you start the tour from from the back, you miss all the tours and have a lot of peace and quiet. I just wandered for 2 hours, contemplating, taking pictures and watching people. Some girls rent the Korean dress called hanbok to enter the palaces for free and it's nice to see them walking about in the palace it makes you wonder what life must be like in the old days. You also can use your ticket to enter the National Folk Museum of Korea.

Majority of the palaces may looked the same. But to me, the story is of the palace is the one thing that makes a difference to it - main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty built in 1395. The change guard ceremony was interesting! Recommend to make time to watch it. It happens at every hour from 10am-4pm (please check again before you visit).
Decided to hike to the top of the tower and was not disappointed by the view. There are buses and cabs that you can take if you don't want to do the hike.

This is one of several palaces in Seoul that provides a very interesting look in to Joseon dynasty history. Fascinating very large grounds with many buildings. We made it for the am guard changing ceremony. The ceremony takes place a couple of times a day and is a nice addition to the regular palace tour. Make sure to visit the national foll museum next to the palace grounds for an even more in depth look in to Korean history and culture.

You can't skip coming to see the Palace if you visit Seoul. History at your fingertips. highly recommended

A good place to know about Korea Palace and the history by joining the tour provided by the palace. Do visit the muzium nearby. Should try their hanbok dress cheapest is ₩13k rent for 2hrs and free entrance to the palace. Lovely experienced.
This palace is beautiful and a very big property. Wear good walking shoes as you will walk a lot and not all surfaces are even. Changing of the guards was fun to see as well
Fascinating building and premises. Only spent 10 minutes. Got there late. Palace closes at 5pm. Took some wonderful photos there.
Beautiful Palace tour with One Day Korea. This is a very historic palace in South Korea, definitely a must see while in Seoul.

If you have any difficulty walking or with stairs this is not for you. The buildings are all roped off, so the most you can do is climb to the top of the steps and look in. The changing of the guard at the gate which happens multiple times a day is worth the visit as is the museum which is next door.

We went to Gyeongbokgung Palace on the coldest day so it was freezing walking around. We were only there for 30 mins. The palace is smaller than I expect but The story behind it is interesting. Coming to the palace in early Feb is not recommended.

Our visit here started with watching the changing of the gaurds ceremony at 10AM. We weere lucky to watch it as it was quite freezing weather and at some point , in severe weather the ceremony is cancelled. The palace itself is a complex of beautiful palaces demonstaring the maginifecnt architecture and are a must-see whie in Seoul.
Some old surrounded by new in Seoul. Come at the right time and you will see a crowd watching some happenings at the front gate. Shame you have to pay to get in though.

This palace i believe is the more popular one among the 5 nearby. It is huge and due to the hectic schedule we are unable to explore the place. Probably need like half a day to properly explore the area. There is a museum inside.

Be sure to join Gyeongbokgung Palace's free guided tour to better appreciate the place. It will only take one hour for you to learn more about Korea's rich history. If you plan to go to Bukchon Hanok Village, better ask information which gate you should exit. You might also want to check out the Blue House while you're in the Palace. They have an exit that will allow you to see the front of the Blue House. We weren't able to see the Changing of the Guards, but you might want to fix your schedule so you can see it.

The place was very beautiful because of the view with the mountain,ponds with fish..its interesting to come when spring season...im going there on summer still beauty, the places also open midnight but hard to get the ticket on midnight... go here if you want to watch the guard ceremony changing, it amazing, here also near to insadong and also cheodukgung palace and blue house, museum of kotemporary also there and musuem art king joseon also around there...may spend all day there.

This is a large complex of palace buildings with a two museums attached. There are some rooms which are furnished. We saw the changing of the guard ceremony. Lots to look at and do. This is manly outdoor - but the museums give a chance to go indoors.

You will not only be amazed by the decors of each part of the Palace , you will actually be amazed by how the Korean people are proud of and how they have been able to preserve their heritage ... something we Filipinos can learn from...

To know Korea from its core. It is unique in its style from those of China, and Japan. Chinese's is a castle in itself, and Japanese's is a fortress, indicating the nation's monarchaic living style while Korean is more of an living quarters with low walls and not much luxury.
" this place is very near our hotel, we were able to go by just walking, we really enjoyed taking pictures of the palace, in fact i made it as my profile picture' background".
not that great - unless you get those costumes and take pics. not enough info available on the diffrent sights station and the book is not informative enough.

Last time in june 2013 , i didn't get enough time to explore the whole palace. Now in january 2017, i can get fulfilled my wish to explore the whole palace. It was really awesome place to get know history of korean.

Go on a nice day and enjoy the home of former kings and queens. The extensive palace grounds and buildings take a couple of hours to get through, and they're totally worth your time. The architecture is impressive and varied, the gardens are beautiful and seasonal, and the mountains in the background are breathtaking. The entire place represents old Korea so well.If you take kids, they can run around outside which is nice too! It can be exceptionally busy, so be prepared to gently elbow your way through the busy areas.The subway access is good, and there's a museum attached to the station which I didn't visit but heard was good.

This palace is absolutely huge and you can easily spend you whole day there. I didn't see the change of the guard but heard it's a must see and will definitely get to it next time. There are so many beautiful pictures you can take of the place, this is a must see for anyone who visits South Korea.

Was there for the change of guard ceremony which was impressive. Otherwise didn't enter the palace ground per se but walked at its parameter which allowed views inside, which was at that point of time just okay. Maybe due to the late fall weather.
Very nice historical place to visit. What arrived the Guard change was interesting to look at with national dressing

The palace is extremely picturesque. I took some amazing shots here in the Autumn. The old architecture combines beautifully with fall colors. I think it's a fantastic place to go if you're looking for amazing photographs.
The history of Seoul is so unique and the people are extremely friendly. Very safe area. Lots of ex pats in down town.
The Palace is big and it is worth witnessing the change of the guard ceremony that happens multiple times during the day.

This is my second visit and i really enjoyed being a princess in one day, where you can rent a hanbook (tradisional uniform) across the road.Rented fees is 30,000 won for 2 hours and we entered the palace with free of charge because im wearing it.Beside that, u can try the men traditional cloth for free at main gate. If this is your first time, you can join with others tourist as they provide English tour guide.I went there by subway,

Many beautiful scenery to capture by your camera. The place is huge. There are many temples to visit. Don't miss this palace when visiting Seoul. The changing of guards ceremony is also worth watching.

We began our visit at the Palace with the changing of the guard ceremony. I highly recommend being at the Palace in time to see this ceremony. It was so interesting to watch and afterwards you have an opportunity to have your picture taken with one of the guards. So fun!

The changing of the guard was really awesome to watch! If you're planning on going to Gyeonbokgung which I personally think is a must, be there during those times. I think there's a 10am and 2pm session and it goes on for 20 minutes. The queen's chamber was also a very interactive experience. We had to take our shoes off before going in and we were allowed to look around. It was probably the best thing there!

This is such a peaceful and beautiful destination to visit if you are in Seoul. The palace is massive and although you cannot step into all the houses you can visit the museum to gather informational pamphlets and walk through to learn about the imperials throne, traditions and view their clothing, tools and even see the structure of how the formation of the dynasty. I would not recommend you to go if you are not into seeing old museums or looking for adventure.

Was there for the change of guard ceremony which was impressive. Otherwise didn't enter the palace ground per se but walked at its parameter which allowed views inside, which was at that point of time just okay. Maybe due to the late fall weather.
Very nice historical place to visit. What arrived the Guard change was interesting to look at with national dressing

The palace is extremely picturesque. I took some amazing shots here in the Autumn. The old architecture combines beautifully with fall colors. I think it's a fantastic place to go if you're looking for amazing photographs.
The history of Seoul is so unique and the people are extremely friendly. Very safe area. Lots of ex pats in down town.
The Palace is big and it is worth witnessing the change of the guard ceremony that happens multiple times during the day.

This is my second visit and i really enjoyed being a princess in one day, where you can rent a hanbook (tradisional uniform) across the road.Rented fees is 30,000 won for 2 hours and we entered the palace with free of charge because im wearing it.Beside that, u can try the men traditional cloth for free at main gate. If this is your first time, you can join with others tourist as they provide English tour guide.I went there by subway,

Many beautiful scenery to capture by your camera. The place is huge. There are many temples to visit. Don't miss this palace when visiting Seoul. The changing of guards ceremony is also worth watching.

I think there's a 10am and 2pm session and it goes on for 20 minutes. The queen's chamber was also a very interactive experience. We had to take our shoes off before going in and we were allowed to look around. It was probably the best thing there!

The palace is massive and although you cannot step into all the houses you can visit the museum to gather informational pamphlets and walk through to learn about the imperials throne, traditions and view their clothing, tools and even see the structure of how the formation of the dynasty. I would not recommend you to go if you are not into seeing old museums or looking for adventure.

It is quite big and has a lot of things to see inside. there's also a museum there as well. After you finish looking around there you can easily access buses or subways as well as many other attractions in the neighborhood.

second time visiting this palace, and it is still great. best place to learn the culture and history of korea. the place is really huge so prepare for a long walk! there is also museums to visit inside.for more fun experience, you can rent those pretty hanbok and get inside for free, i believe. it was very cold when i visited though so i decided not to rent one
it was a freezing day but it was a beautiful palace, just sad that I have see the guard parade. it's very easy to get there with the metro

We made it to witness the guard changing ceremony at 10am. The palace is huge and we spent hours walking around. We managed to get discount as we were traveling in a group of 12 so it's Korean won 2400 per pax. Worth the money as we went in and took some beautiful pictures

The grounds here are large and beautiful. There were a lot of tourists groups but it did not feel crowded. There are amazing views and photo ops and it is just nice to spend the day outdoors in such a beautiful place. There was also a gift shop and cafe there. Stay for the traditional changing of the guard ceremony, it was nice and not too long. There is a charge to get to the grounds and a separate charge to go inside the palace, we opted not to go into the palace, there was plenty to explore anyways.

We went to this itinerary during winter. Some parts of the ground are very slippery. Several people slipped and fell.We have someone to guide us through the palace. Great and meaningful history.Must visit this historical palace and get a guide to explain the building structure and share it's history.

My daughter and I decided to visit the palace. I am so glad we did. The palace is so beautiful and we spent about an hour and a half waking around.It was freezing cold and it was nice to be able to grab a coffee during the walk.We also stopped to have traditional tea.It is well worth the visit. And a cab fare is really cheap if you take an orange cab. The black cabs are more expensive.

in spite of the cold we visited the palace and walked around these beautiful grounds as much as possible. It's a must-see, especially if you should be lucky enough to see the changing of the palace guard. We weren't able to - cancelled due to the snow, however, they were standing at the front gate entrance. Very colorful and fierce looking guys who didn't mind having their photos taken.The palace was built in 1395 and was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty and destroyed by fire during the Imjin War (Japanese invasion - 1592-8) and abandoned for two centuries. Mount Bugak is the backdrop and if you want to have a lovely view of the entire grounds, walk over to the National Museum and take the elevator to the (? can't remember; might be the 8th floor or higher?) where there is a terrace that provides a marvelous view.
The palace is great culture, good for pictures, and offers free English tours. The place is huge, and near other attractions, so I recommend planning your day around it.

We went in November. A bit chilly out but no queues and less tourists. Well preserved old palace with traditional guards in Korean dress. Changing of the guard ceremony was beautiful. Earlier in the day was nice as we were largely alone. If it is rainy day I would not recommend as there is very little in the way of shelter. Even in winter, the gardens were beautiful! In a truly busy metropolis, this was 2 hours of less noise and a hold onto Korea's past which is not always evident with the rush to modernity!

It is quite big and has a lot of things to see inside. there's also a museum there as well. After you finish looking around there you can easily access buses or subways as well as many other attractions in the neighborhood.

it was a freezing day but it was a beautiful palace, just sad that I have see the guard parade. it's very easy to get there with the metro

Stay for the traditional changing of the guard ceremony, it was nice and not too long. There is a charge to get to the grounds and a separate charge to go inside the palace, we opted not to go into the palace, there was plenty to explore anyways.

Earlier in the day was nice as we were largely alone. If it is rainy day I would not recommend as there is very little in the way of shelter. Even in winter, the gardens were beautiful! In a truly busy metropolis, this was 2 hours of less noise and a hold onto Korea's past which is not always evident with the rush to modernity!

This was one of our very first stops upon arrival in South Korea. I would definitely suggest going in springtime, when the cherry blossoms are in bloom, and hopefully the lotus flowers in the pond are blooming too. You could easily spend half a day to a full day to see each and every piece of this area. We got some great photos, and definitely plan to head back again before our couple of years here are done!

Walking through Gyeongbokgung Palace was an amazing experience. All of the buildings are beautiful and full of rich history. Free tours run every few minutes in various languages. Our tour guide was extremely knowledgeable and kind!

A must go place!You may find it is a good to place to go in different seasons, go with a big group or good to go alone! A place where you can sit to enjoy the scenery, take pictures and to find out more the Korean Royal life.Go connection with Metro!

Don't miss this if you are visiting Seoul. The guard changing ceremonies are the highlight and performing daily in short and long sessions. Do at least stay for the short one if your schedule allowed. There are also free guided tours available in different languages. Head to the right from the main gate for the information center once you purchase the entrance ticket. The staff was very helpful! The palace was indeed amazing in winter. Many girls - tourists and locals alike dressed up in hanbok. It was such a beautiful scene. I've been to Seoul countless times but this was the first to the palace. I would totally come back again the next time to learn more about its history, and hopefully the weather won't be too cold so I can dress up in hanbok to take a stroll in the palace.
being over 65 years old we were very surprised that we did not have to pay for the entrance fee as seniors.Place was very grand , very inteersting and worth seeing

One of the best places for pictures! Lots of walking though and there's really only a few spectacular places. One is the pond in back the the small pagoda and the other is behind and to the left of the main throne room- it's a huge dinner hall in a rectangular pond. Find these and a few others and you're good. Otherwise it can get exhausting. Beautiful in winter, too.

We spent an hour to get to 'Jongro-3road' station, because we wanted to go to "Gyeongbokgung". Before we go inside of it, we could see a large door called "Gwanghwamun". We could see quite a lot of people wearing "Hanbok" when we get through the gate. The palace was absolutely astonishing. We couldn't see the end because it's vast compound. Also when we looked inside of the Hanok(Korean traditional house), we could see beautiful colored ceiling. We could feel that this palace is the history of the place. It was almost hard to take in. We felt overwhelming. Also there is a wonderful lake. This lake was surrounded by large trees. In the middle of the lake there is a small island. We were honestly, completely blown away by this. Because we saw this place, we become aware of the sheer wealth and power of the Joseon dynasty. Absolutely incredible place. I highly recommend to visit here. Visiting this place is just the same with seeing a little piece of a picture in the past. Tip : It spends more than 3 hours to look this palace. Also even if you are foreigner, you can go inside the palace for free if you wear a Korean traditional clothes. You can rent it $20. You can get a great picture with it.

We were there the same date as the korean celebrate lunar new year hence the new year decoration. Had lots of fun taking photos and most importantly we got to wear on Korean traditional clothes for photo shooting and it was for free!
The highlight was the changing of the guards, which was colourful. I loved the mountains in th backdrop.

This is the second time here. A lot of tourists as usual, but well manicured. Quite big, takes an hour or two to walk the whole palace. Must see if you haven't already, but probably not more than once.

The highlight was the changing of the guards, which was colourful. I loved the mountains in th backdrop.

This is the second time here. A lot of tourists as usual, but well manicured. Quite big, takes an hour or two to walk the whole palace. Must see if you haven't already, but probably not more than once.
We visited during winter. Beautiful palace. Definitely worth the visit! Better to wait to watch the change of palace guards.

I think i only explore 1/3 of the whole area as it was so cold during my visit. but the scenery that you can expect is beyond your imagination, i must say that this is one of the best place for you to visit. Great ancient architecture. Be there at 10am every morning to watch guard changing ceremony at the front yard. The palace closed on Tuesday. Admission fee is cheap, only KRW3000 per pax.
We were fortunate enough to be present for the changing of the guard ceremony (check times). It was very colorful, the horns sounded just like bagpipes!

This beautiful palace with history that spirals back to 13th century is definitely to be included in your top 3 to do items in Seoul! Located convenienty by Gyeungbokgung metro station,it come conplete with free guided tours in many different languages.Our English guide ,Ginny was very poised in her traditional costume and was never short in updating the group about the tiniest details of the Joseun dynasty from the smart palace architectures to its fate from invasion of Japanese occupation amongst other info...the view of the well preserved palace on the blue sunny winter day was breathtaking!The palace was also located side by side to the National Folk Musuem that houses a lot of historicsl artifacts.The many traditional activity booths set up there due to the Lunar New Year celebration made the visit all the more an interesting learning experience

Very convenient to travel to Gyeongbokgung Palace. Is just outside a metro station. Interesting palace to visit. Totally recommend for family who are bringing elderly. A slow stroll and a place to see their Korean palace culture.

It's large, impressive and historial. But a bit boring in the winter. Most of the courtyards are mud and wet after the snow. Very crowded with Chinese tour groups during the Chinese New Year holiday. Most of the buildings you don't enter and you just look in through the door or window. Might be more interesting with a tour group. Overall worth seeing if you have some time to fill since it's only 3k won for the general entry. But I wouldn't consider it a "must see"

Truly beautiful. Bit of a hike to get around and see everything there, but on a nice pleasant Seoul day well worth the extra steps. Interesting architecture and would recommend taking the time to just take a step back and take it in. A guide would be somewhat helpful, but a good tour guide book can be nearly as accommodating.

We went here during winter but it was still busy! We bought tickets on arrival then decided to hire some Hanbok (traditional Korean dresses) which were all located outside the palace on the main roads. We didn't know that if you are wearing traditional clothes you get to enter the palace for free! The ticket lady at the door told us to go get a refund for our tickets. It was simply amazing! All the intricate little details of the design was mesmerizing! Definitely a must see!

Had a short walk in the compounds before coming out as my aged father could not walk much. That said, the trees were barren and I think it would definitely be much nicer during spring and autumn. During winter, I felt that the buildings on its own could not muster the same majestic feel of European palaces could without the help of landscapes
the biggest palace in seoul..it's huge! the changing guard take place in the main gate before entrance..if wearing hanbok (korean traditional costume) got free admission
We visited during winter. Beautiful palace. Definitely worth the visit! Better to wait to watch the change of palace guards.

the biggest palace in seoul..it's huge! the changing guard take place in the main gate before entrance..if wearing hanbok (korean traditional costume) got free admission

A really large and absolutely beautiful especially during autumn. 2 hours won't be enough to go around and see everything. i suggest anyone to rent a hanbok then went here. too much beautiful place to take pictures
This was our first palace on our first day in Seoul. We enjoyed the time at the palace and was pleasantly surprised with the free tour that was provided in English.

Even in the freezing cold you can appreciate the beauty. Everything had a crisp, frozen shine to it. We saw many couples in traditional dress taking wedding photos, and whole families dressed up for the lunar new year.

The Palace is a great photo stop, there is a museum in there and they are free pf charge. I saw some people walking around in Hanbok, so maybe you should be able to rent a Hanbok in the area for a full experience...
i've been to this palace three times already, and don't get sick of it. it's beautiful, and it's worth to read a little bit about it before, so you can understand it better. highly recommended.

I love palaces and castles. I enjoy history so I like such palaces. But my brother thinks they are all the same and boring. So, to each his own. This is the biggest palace, so it's a must-see. But it's a nice place for photos, get a feel of Korean culture. Fun to see many people walking around in Korean hanbok clothes too. Feel like they came from another age into the modern world. There's guided tours provided in various languages. Be sure to check which one you want to join from the website timing before you go, so you can plan your day better. Wait at the front of the information office for the tour. I would suggest going for the tour so you can get more structured information about the palace. The national folk museum and palace museum are on the same grounds. Both are free but the palace is not. If you enjoy palaces, buy the combination ticket as its 4 palaces + 1 shrine (total ₩14000) but with the combi ticket it costs only ₩10000. Value for money if you will visit most of it. Good to spend a day wondering around the palace and museums. Recommended!

It's a decent place by itself. If you never seen an Asian palace then you should go. But if you had been to Kyoto, Thailand, or Beijing, then this becomes quite trivial. Don't let this palace be the reason to come to Seoul.

It's not the best palace which I've bee and it's nothing compared to some other palaces. Yet, it's definitely worth a visit. Also great to take pictures with other visitors who dressed up as the emperors and empresses!
This palace has a lot of Korean cultures, it shows the different type of architectural work and design of Old Korea and there is very beautiful nature in the palace as well.

In winter season this place looks more great... Cause is better for taking picture while you wear a traditional korean clothes.. It called hanbok. The background of the emperror are fantastic... And there is a place of museum

A really large and absolutely beautiful especially during autumn. 2 hours won't be enough to go around and see everything. i suggest anyone to rent a hanbok then went here. too much beautiful place to take pictures
