It's still the same admission price and it's open from 6-10pm but lines start forming at 5pm. There are limited stilts for both tourists and locals so be sure to come early. There were exhibits and a traditional Korean dance and program showcasing their culture and the story of King Sejong (?). It was held in one of the pavilions on the lake and with the full moon it was just breathtaking! There were a lot of young people dressed in the traditional hanbok because they get to come in free :-)
The Palace is nice but your visit gets better when you see the gardens. I was so lucky I went during Fall/autumn, so I could see the different colour of the trees.

First thing we did when arrived in Korea was visiting Gyeongbok palace. Good spot to start your visit in Seoul, where you can learn about history. Ticket is not expensive, and you can buy a special pass to visit all the temples and palaces in the area with a discount.

This is a must for any visitor to Seoul, the grounds are massive! Many visitors every day but as the are is so large it is not overcrowded. Many teenagers and young adults dress up in traditional costume for photo sessions, pretty entertaining.
Visited the palace and gardens with my wife and 14m old son. Great place to stroll around and to take some beautiful pictures.

This huge palace complex is stunning, comparable to the best in the world. Every courtyard or space reveals new treasures and, despite being crowded, peace can be found around many a corner. An absolute must-see if in Korea!

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a must-visit when you are in Seoul! Do note that the palace is closed on Tuesdays so avoid going on that day. It is extremely accessible via the metro (alight at Gyeongbokgung Palace station itself, Line 3, Exit 5). You can even walk to Bukchon Hanok Village from there. If you're in Hanbok, admission to the palace is FREE!
The palace is closed on Tuesday though. It's crowded inside. We managed to take better photos from the National Museum outside.

If you are a history buff and plan to visit any of the palaces, and if you have only a very limited time, I would suggest that you visit Gyeongbokgung.It is close to Insadong and Bukchon hanok village. You can sort of do all there in one day. Mind you, there is a lot of walking to do, so be prepared.I was not very impressed by the changing of the palace guard, but if you have the time go for it.Check out the timing for this, as they do this only twice a day, depending on the weather. However, do not avoid the palace visit just because you missed the changing of the guard.

As I rode the bus from Incheon Airport to my hotel in Jongno, I got my first glimpse of Gyeongbokgung Palace. It was way after midnight and the lights from the outer gate and just the presence of seeing a palace for the first time blew me away. I visited the palace and it was such a wonder to see.

During our time in South Korea, being the history buffs we are, we purchased the Integrated Pass for Palaces, which basically gave us tickets and access for all five major palaces for 10,000 won, as compared to 14,000 won if purchased individually instead. From our visits, we could safely say that out of the five, Gyeongbokgung Palace seemed to be the most well known, and perhaps unfortunately, the most crowded too.We happened to visit during the Golden Week holiday period in China, and that meant hordes of Chinese tourists swarming the Geunjeongjeon, or Throne Hall. It would have been a little more ideal if I had been able to secure a slot for the night tour, where the crowd is much lesser and it is more beautiful for night photography. Luckily, it seems that most tour groups bring their tourists to the Geunjeongjeon area only. Beyond that, if you are willing to walk more and more further, you will be rewarded with less crowds.The architectural style of the palace is somewhat closer to the Ming Dynasty style, such as the Forbidden Palace for example. This is in contrast to the other palaces such as Changdeokgung Palace, which has a more traditional Korean style. It might look similar at first glance, but on closer inspection, some differences can be seen. The Gyeongbokgung Palace that is seen standing today is actually a reconstruction and restoration, as the original one was sadly demolished during the Japanese colonial era in 1915. Still, the amount and scale that has been restored so far is astonishing and must be seen first hand to understand the very soul of Korea better.The National Folk Museum of Korea happens to be inside Gyeongbokgung Palace and it can provide a respite from the heat with the building itself being air-conditioned. The exterior of the museum is quite beautiful and is worthy of some great shots. There is also the Hyangwonjeong Pavilion that is worth walking far enough for a great shot. You should not miss the royal guard changing ceremonies done by reenactors that take place at Gwanghwamun, the main gate of Gyeongbokgung Palace at 10 am and 2 pm. The ceremony takes about 20 minutes and it is an experience you should not miss. You can even take photos with the royal guards after the ceremony too!Do take note that Gyeongbokgung Palace is closed on Tuesdays and sometimes it may close if it gets too crowded, so do plan accordingly. A night tour would be even better if you are able to get a slot. This is an excellent place to see both the locals and tourists in Hanbok, the Korean national costume, since those in Hanbok get in for free. If you want less crowds however, I would strongly suggest Changdeokgung Palace instead if you only have time for one palace to visit.
The Palace is nice but your visit gets better when you see the gardens. I was so lucky I went during Fall/autumn, so I could see the different colour of the trees.

You can sort of do all there in one day. Mind you, there is a lot of walking to do, so be prepared.I was not very impressed by the changing of the palace guard, but if you have the time go for it.Check out the timing for this, as they do this only twice a day, depending on the weather. However, do not avoid the palace visit just because you missed the changing of the guard.

As I rode the bus from Incheon Airport to my hotel in Jongno, I got my first glimpse of Gyeongbokgung Palace. It was way after midnight and the lights from the outer gate and just the presence of seeing a palace for the first time blew me away. I visited the palace and it was such a wonder to see.

During our time in South Korea, being the history buffs we are, we purchased the Integrated Pass for Palaces, which basically gave us tickets and access for all five major palaces for 10,000 won, as compared to 14,000 won if purchased individually instead. From our visits, we could safely say that out of the five, Gyeongbokgung Palace seemed to be the most well known, and perhaps unfortunately, the most crowded too.We happened to visit during the Golden Week holiday period in China, and that meant hordes of Chinese tourists swarming the Geunjeongjeon, or Throne Hall. It would have been a little more ideal if I had been able to secure a slot for the night tour, where the crowd is much lesser and it is more beautiful for night photography. Luckily, it seems that most tour groups bring their tourists to the Geunjeongjeon area only. Beyond that, if you are willing to walk more and more further, you will be rewarded with less crowds.The architectural style of the palace is somewhat closer to the Ming Dynasty style, such as the Forbidden Palace for example. This is in contrast to the other palaces such as Changdeokgung Palace, which has a more traditional Korean style. It might look similar at first glance, but on closer inspection, some differences can be seen. The Gyeongbokgung Palace that is seen standing today is actually a reconstruction and restoration, as the original one was sadly demolished during the Japanese colonial era in 1915. Still, the amount and scale that has been restored so far is astonishing and must be seen first hand to understand the very soul of Korea better.The National Folk Museum of Korea happens to be inside Gyeongbokgung Palace and it can provide a respite from the heat with the building itself being air-conditioned. The exterior of the museum is quite beautiful and is worthy of some great shots. There is also the Hyangwonjeong Pavilion that is worth walking far enough for a great shot. You should not miss the royal guard changing ceremonies done by reenactors that take place at Gwanghwamun, the main gate of Gyeongbokgung Palace at 10 am and 2 pm. The ceremony takes about 20 minutes and it is an experience you should not miss. You can even take photos with the royal guards after the ceremony too!Do take note that Gyeongbokgung Palace is closed on Tuesdays and sometimes it may close if it gets too crowded, so do plan accordingly. A night tour would be even better if you are able to get a slot. This is an excellent place to see both the locals and tourists in Hanbok, the Korean national costume, since those in Hanbok get in for free. If you want less crowds however, I would strongly suggest Changdeokgung Palace instead if you only have time for one palace to visit.

Great place for pictures, go on a weekday if you can because weekends can get overcrowded with tourist buses. It was amazing to walk around and sight see. Very beautiful and it was very memorable. It is not very friendly to strollers, especially in the entrance areas. It will not be a smooth ride. I recommend baby wearing if possible.

This is right across from my office and have been staring at it through the window every business trip. Decided to check it out. The palace is ok not very elaborate like others around the world. A guided tour may have been interesting. The change of guards is good.

There are several things you need to do it in the palace or else you will regret in your visit1) Bring a good camera so you can take some magnificient picture of the Palace2) After pay the ticket, go right of the palace to check out the tea serving ceremony or rice cake ceremony so you can taste and learn some , as the class or ceremony is depended on the timing3) Have pictures with the soldiers there4) Have pictures with the pretty korean with hanok ( korean costume )5) Have fun jumping and running as it is really huge!The last thing is, visit every single corner of the palace and it is sweet enough if you can take some nice pictures with the nice scenery with your love one!
Its 600 years old. Made from wood. So many beautiful Korean design. But the most important thing is that the secret garden, It is amazing.

Came here with a private guide. The history was extremely interesting and well worth the time spent there. Our guide knew just when to arrive for the changing of the guard, is well worth seeing. The grounds are amazing. The guide explained the differences between Chinese, Japanese and Korean architecture which will be interesting to compare. A must see if you are in Seoul.

The palace itself is not so much to see. On a sunny weekend, you can find citizens/tourists wearing Hanbok in it, as if it is a movie studio. It's great to get some Korean vibe. Also, do visit the palace at night! The palace is glowing with some lights on. There are some beautiful pine trees besides the park.

The palace is open for public visits. And as with most of the palace worldwide, there is guard changing ceremony. If i'm not mistaken, it is carried out twice a day. Its an interesting ceremony and tourist should grab the chance to watch it. The entrance fee is quite cheap and inside, you can take pictures and learn many Korean's history. There is also some place inside where you need to pay extra if you want to enter. Fir me, i just pay the initial entrance fee and spent around 2 hour visiting the palace. To go there, its quite easy using the subway.

This was a great temple to visit and you could easily spend a few hours wandering the grounds. It's especially nice to see lots of people in Korean traditional dress as it allows them free entry, but also adds to the atmosphere.

September is not really ideal yet to visit Seoul. If one is lucky, a day may have temperature at below 30 degrees celcius.Tourists should loan the Korean traditional costume for photo taking within the palace compound. Enjoy!!!

A must visit when in Seoul. Stunning and well-preserved architectures. Love the vast gardens, walkways and ponds. During my visit, there was a stage performance going on. It was interesting to see people in Hanboks walking around.
Quaint and memorable palace in Seoul.When we went there it's a bit crowded but nevertheless it's one of the places you simply can't forget.

Previously when I visited gyeongbukgung in the morning, I was pretty unimpressed as it was very crowded and we didn’t manage to secure tickets to see the interior of the palace. However, this time round, we visited at night with a friend and wow, I prefer coming here at night than in the morning. Taking photos here is always pretty surreal – you have the mountains in the backdrop and the tall buildings around the palace and all that is just 10 times better looking at night. The night tour of the palace was really nice and I enjoyed the various bits of historical information we got along the way. There was a performance at one end of the palace and that was beautiful. Totally recommended.

Was here, there is some kind of park around the palaces, but nothing "wow", just a traditional-style buildings. Worth visiting once when it's your first time in Seoul, but I wouldn't recommend it as some great attraction

There are 4-5 palaces in Seoul and this is a biggest and most famous one. There are many people wearing traditional clothes come here so it create a very special/different feeling when visiting Seoul besides the modern, shoppings and skyscrapers in other places.
Fabulous visit, beautiful place with stunning architecture & artwork. The adjourning museum us well worth the visit too.

beautiful vast grounds & well preserved structures. Very thankful for our Goodwill Volunteer Tour guide whose stories brought us back to the past amazing life of the royals and its people in the palaces.

A huge palace complex with courtyards and gardens and a gorgeous pond. While we were there it was a national holiday so people were wearing national costume and there was music and dancing by the pavilion. One of the highlights of Seoul.
Stunning buildings, amazing architecture and cute Korean girl wearing traditional dresses. You haven't been to Seoul if you don't visit this palace.

We are lucky to visit on a special festive day where entrance to the palace is free. We spent an hour or so walk around the palace and it was so chilly during autumn month. Beautiful gardens and clean environment, well maintained architecture & there are free tour around the garden (English speaking). Overall, this is a must-visit place if you are a first timer to Seoul, Korea.

Really interesting and huge palace compound. Try to see the small parade which is at 11 am and possibly 2 PM. There are so many building to walk around and see, and there is an English speaking tour twice a day at noon and possibly one later. Found it interesting but tour, at 1 hour, was too long for our Elem. age kids.

Large estate where you can wander around or take a detailed audio tour Interesting to see the ancient dynasties. Lots of young girls in the traditional folk costumes also made for good people watching.There's also a number of art galleries nearby so check out modern Seoul as well as heritage sites.

The palace is huge and gives a good insight into Korean culture and dynastic lifestyle. don't miss the evening light and sound show encompassing several cultural events.( only foreigners allowed). make sure you carry your passports
Definitely a must-visit when you travel to Seoul. This palace is very well-preserved and they are continuing with the restoration work.
Good attraction, large palace, different structures, Korean heritage. Went on a day when there was a cultural festival going on. Lot of youngsters wearing traditional and colourful dresses

Nice place to explore. It's a huge complex so there are lots to see. The changing of the Palace Guards takes place at 11am. What I didn't like was the large number of tourists during the peak hours. Some of them, especially those bus load of visitors from China tend to get really noisy and aggressive when taking selfies. I saw a bunch of them man handle the Palace Guard so that they can have that perfect selfies. So the best time to visit is early in the morning or at night.
It was so great when Harry was teaching us about the history here in Gyeongbukgung Palace. I was amazed by how they maintain the structure of this place and the cleanliness too.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is part of the itinerary of all the day tours in Seoul, which tells you that it is worth seeing, but as my husband and I discovered, it is an easy 20 minute walk from the City Hall neighbourhood where our hotel was located. In other words, it is possible to see come of the city's rich history even if you don't have much time to spare. The palace is an commanding structure and gives a real sense of the wealth and sophistication of Korea at the time when Europe was still emerging from the Middle Ages. But, the thing that we found most impressive was the pride and patriotism shown by the Korean people, many of whom were dressed in colourful, traditional costume. Gyeongbokgung Palace is the perfect solution if you are in Seoul on business and don't have much time but still want a taste of the country's history.

The palace is a must-go site if you are first time traveler to Seoul. We spen around 2-3 hour in this palace. However, minus point is that it always crowded. Small bonus point is you can rent a traditional clothes nearby and go into the palace to take picture

We really enjoyed visiting this palace. Its the best we saw during our stay in Seoul. Do not miss the ceremony when the guards change.

Too beautiful place and all the place look like a picture too cause the tree and the lake If you are korean drama fans you will be crazy haha ;D cause you will see all the scenes in your eyes and you will know how big in gyeongbokgung palaceIt's very fun and beautiful place Full of Korea historical place and look :)Must do and come list in Korea!!!!

I had been to the palace in the day some years ago. Last week, I had the chance to go in for the night tour last week. Please go there at about 6:30 pm, to queue up for the foreigners' tickets, for entry at 7 pm (although they let the people in before then). The palace looked beautiful at night, because they lit it really well. It had a dance and a light show (every hour, I think). The reflections of the buildings and the trees in the lake were particularly impressive. Allow about an hour for the night tour and it was worth a visit. Pictures:

I would say a must if you're visiting Seoul. Or only is admission cheap but you get to go into the palace. I like going to historical places and they do have people dressed up as guards that you could take pictures with, also gives you access to the national museum.

We chose to visit Gyeongbok Palace over other palaces due to time constraint and it was a very worthwhile visit. We were marveled at the architecture in a very distinct Korean way and the detailed danchung painting of the roof overhang. In addition, Goenghoeru Pavillion in the pond was an outstanding idea to have a royal reception or celebration among noble people. Walking northbound, we were able to see a part of neighboring Chungwadae which is the residence of the Korean President in the backdrop of a mountain and it was absolutely beautiful. For the entertainment, there are changing guard procedure and military drill as the King watching. This can't be compared to the changing guard performance of Buckingnam Palace in London in quality, but it adds to understanding of the Joseon Dynasty. I highly recommend to visit the palace and the surrounding area. One can finish touring in as little as 1 hour or all day long.
Went there with the tour from the US , and this Palace was one of the attraction, we love the visit ,See all Palaces the learn Korean culture and History and shoots lot of pic . it was just great.

Well worth a visit, mainly for the notable scale and architecture. The terrain, buildings and gardens are all impressive. The textual descriptions are spare, but there are free tours. Personally, I though the highlight was just seeing the buildings themselves. You can rent "hanbok" nearby and walk around in costume for an extra treat.

Come early morning as soon as it opens for a peaceful walk around and good photo opportunities. Gets crazy crowded and noisy as it gets closer to lunch. Also a good idea to set aside time to do the National Folk Museum here as it's just to the side of the palace. Must see if you have not been to Seoul before.

We were in Seoul for 5 days but only chose to visit one Palace, and after research it was obvious to me this was the one to go to. My reason? It's the birthplace of the Joseon Dynasty. When the capital was moved to Seoul, this was the first Palace, and the entire walled city of Seoul at the time was designed around this Palace. We went less for the architecture and more for the history and layout- specifically, with the mountain as a backdrop and the pond in the rear. Walking thru and spending time in the adjacent dongs, all which had their own purpose serving this Palace, made their history all the more interesting as well. You can reasonably do the Palace in one hour, and there are free English guided tours available 3 times each day- check the times on their website to plan your visit.

It's a grand palace with huge open space. Well preserved architecture. It's now free admission in conjunction with Korea sale Festa. Good for sightsee and photo taking. To experience it fully, suit up in their traditional costumes first! After this palace, do go to Changdeokgung's secret garden for 5000won per entry. 10-15 mins walk east of Gyeongbokgung.
This palace is located in the city and its just enormous. On the back it goes all the way back in to the mountains with a nice lake and park. The buildings are superb, its the highlight of Seoul.

There is a shop opposite the palace that you can rent from but I would recommend to rent them at Insadong as it is MUCH cheaper (40k vs 14k for 4 hours) :)

A nice palace with lot of history. Easily reachable via the metro. Just follow instructions when you reach the metro station and you will never get lost.

The palace is huge, with a lot of buildings. Walking is easy though, as it's mostly flat. The palace features the mountains as its backdrop, enhancing its picturesque quality. The ponds are beautiful, and we're built to reflect the mountains' beauty. Make sure to see the changing of the guard ceremony at 10am or 2pm. Go a bit before then as they also have a short parade outside the side gate with the guards making in formation.

Majestic palace which offers a glance to the splendour past. Several palaces with its history plus a leisure park and lake dotted the landscape. Be sure to watch guard changing ceremony. A refuge from busy city just a step away
The palace, the views -everything is gorgeous. I would definitely recommend people to spend some time here.
we took hop-on hop-off tour bus and with various stops you can get off and get on, the route was pretty good and inexpensive..

Nice garden outside the museum and palace . The palace look nice but the facades and even interior looked so freshly painted and lacked historic feel but nice to see pretty ladies in traditional hanbok.

The palace is impressive in itself. Also impressive is the way it is taken care of, including keeping its background view of mountains, in center Seoul with all the high rises around it.A real monument to Korea's past.
Catch the changing of the guard ceremony, dress up in Hanbok, join a free tour, visit the museum afterwards.. you could spend the best part of a day just on this one location alone :)

There are multiple palaces in Seoul so I would recommend to only visit Gyeongbokgung if there is any time constraint. Tip: admission fee is waived if you visit in Korean traditional clothing. There is a shop opposite the palace that you can rent from but I would recommend to rent them at Insadong as it is MUCH cheaper (40k vs 14k for 4 hours) :)

It might be boring to many people but it's amazing for history lover. It's very huge and needs time to walk there. Especially that there is also museum. The palace complex was actually hugh! The palace itself was really beautiful and grand. The architecture of all the buildings in the palace complex the really mesmerizing. I was particularly impressed with the Royal Guards manning the entrance. They were awesome.

Visited at the end of the day and it was superb. No large groups so the place was quiet, almost serene, the surroundings are lovely and the buildings interesting. Can easily find a quiet spot to read a book. I didn't go with a guide and later regretted as I believe it would have made the visit even more enjoyable.

As one of the most popular tourist spot in Seoul. Prepare for huge crowd of tourists and buses in the area. Very nice place to visit and add knowledge of korean history.There is a show at the gate once in a an hour (might change) where guards will perform a war march.
There are site with nice views but didn't offer much to see since most rooms are barred from entrance. Only peeking from windows are allowed.But quite a place to visit anyway. Love the lakes though.

Gyeongbukgung, or known as Gyeongbuk Palace. It was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty built in 1395. I never expected that I can be so fascinated by visiting palace, guess the details and the richness of the beautiful architectures drew me into it.

As with all my reviews to sights in Seoul I will preface this by advising visitors to carefully check opening days and times and whether timed entry tickets are needed to access certain parts of the attraction and also the times for booking guided tours in their language of preference – bearing in mind that numbers can be limitedThe palace and grounds occupy a large open space and although the attraction gets very busy (especially with school parties) there are quiet places that can be found to enjoy the architecture and the scale of the palace. Most of the buildings are highly decorative and have been heavily restored and in some cases recreated. If staying in Seoul for some time I would suggest buying the "all in " ticket giving access to all the main palaces in the city

I've been to Gyeongbokgung a few times. My first was in the middle of winter, and not all of the ponds had water, no leaves on the trees.... It was all pretty bleak.I went another time in fall with my sister. We got there in time for the changing of the guard ceremony which is worth scheduling around if you can. My third visit was on a special evening opening. I had to book a ticket online. I went, like most others, with a tripod and my DSLR to try and get some sweet pictures. There was a full moon that night, so we weren't disappointed.
A half day well spent surrounded by friendly and smiling local visitors. Monuments descriptions could be more detailed though if you have any interest in the actual historical facts

this is one place you should not miss when visiting seoul even for the first time. it has a lot to offer and don't forget to bring an umbrella or a hat to protect you from the scorching heat. too bad there was no personal tour guide to explain to us the different features of the palace.

Wow--for a limited time (24 Sep-28 Oct 2016) they are offering special night tours of Gyeongbokgung Palace. If you've never been before or have only visited during the day, I highly recommend trying to get down there. It was the best 3,000 won I have spent in Seoul!!!! Called the "Bridge of Time" there was a spectacular light and dance show at the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion. Don't ask me how they did it but the building kept changing colors--it was so impressive I had to watch the 15-minute show twice. They also had a portion of the show dedicated to a traditional dance in front of the Pavilion, all the while with the lights changing. Plus, upon entering the complex there was another light show as you crossed Yeongjegyo Bridge in the bed of Geumcheon Stream. I read in the local press this is the first time they have had this kind of light show there. The tours run from 19:00-22:00 with the final admission at 21:00. When I was there people began lining up around 6:00 pm and I was told they begin selling the tickets around 6:45 pm. 500 tickets are set aside for foreigners, which are bought at window #1. I arrived around 7:45 on a Sat evening and was still able to get a ticket but may have been lucky as there was a big firework show going on that same evening elsewhere in Seoul. While still crowded, I suspect it was less crowded than normal. Cost was 3,000 won, which is the normal entrance fee. While only a limited part of the complex is open it was nice to see everything all lit up and provided a different perspective to my daytime visit. The special light show and dance performance at Gyeonghoeru Pavilion were done four times and lasted about 15 minutes: 19:20, 20:00, 20:40, and 21:20. I arrived at the tail end of the 20:00 performance and could barely see anything there were so many people. I opted to wait the 25 minutes between shows and got a position in the front center that was great for photo taking. Afterwards, I wandered around a bit and was passing by in time for the last show which was the least crowded so watched it again, it was that good. Anyhow, I was super impressed and plan on recommending this night tour to others. If you are in Seoul right now, go...it will probably end up being one of the favorite stops you make!

The palace complex was actually hugh! The palace itself was really beautiful and grand. The architecture of all the buildings in the palace complex the really mesmerizing. I was particularly impressed with the Royal Guards manning the entrance. They were awesome.

Visited at the end of the day and it was superb. No large groups so the place was quiet, almost serene, the surroundings are lovely and the buildings interesting. Can easily find a quiet spot to read a book. I didn't go with a guide and later regretted as I believe it would have made the visit even more enjoyable.

Geongbokgung Palace is majestic! This is a must visit if you're visiting Seoul. If you can visit during night time (only open few months of the year), it's absolutely beautiful. With a view of the mountain in the background, it's a paradise for photography enthusiasts. Lots of history behind this palace and if you time do checkout the museum to learn about the history. They have free guided tours in English.

It's a one of THE places to visit if you only have a limited time in Seoul. Huge palace grounds and gardens to explore. It can get really crowded at times so avoid the weekend crowds or school holidays.
Scenery is good.But, it will be pressed against the historical recognition.Good things will be on the bad.I will not revisit absolutely.

As one of the top sights of Seoul was looking forward to history and beautiful buildings, but rather disappointing.It has been destroyed over the centuries, however it looks totally new with little in evidence of its history to bring it to life. The site is also bare and feels empty.

Only seen palaces in kdramas but visiting and seeing first hand is awesome. i was literally in awe. the designs and architecture is definitely . Aside from the shopping, you need to set aside time to visit this

There are quite a few palaces in Seoul. The sheer size and scenic location within the city with the mountains in the background, as well it's historical significance make it a must-see in my opinion. It's located fairly centrally and easily accessible via the metro. There are also quite a few other museums located nearby. Our ticket allowed us free entry into the Folk Museum (or Children's Folk Museum? or both, I can't remember). You can spend hours walking around here. You can't enter the chambers or rooms but you can walk through the main structures and there are a lot of them! Wear good walking shoes.There are many ramps around so it's also very wheelchair and stroller accessible. Clean bathrooms with toilet paper, soap and water are also on site. In order to visit the pavilion, I believe you need to make an advance reservation online. A visit to this palace can be as short or long as you want, but if you want to see most of it (at a leisurely walking pace), you should allot at least 2 hours. It's felt smaller than the Forbidden City in Beijing China, and the restorations seemed more apparent. Still, the buildings and layout were beautiful.

This is typically a king palace during old time. When you experience Seoul in the first place, give a chance to come here and spend aprox. 2 hours to stroll around to the palace and national museum. If you happens to like history and place to photos then you might be spend more time there. For me, it is good to go and take a look of changing guard ceremony at their official site or any blogger site available.

This palace is quite massive, when I first saw the image in TripAdvisor, I thought it was just one building and that was it. I was quite surprised by how huge this palace is. Most of the tourist are just in the front area of the building and probably left thereafter.If you want to see the entire palace, be prepared to walk quite a bit and spend at least 2 hours there.The palace is quite beautiful and well maintained. I highly recommended to visit this place.We were there on Oct 2. which was a Korean holiday, lots of people dress up in traditional clothing and take pictures in the palace, quite interesting to see.Looks like some tourist also dress up and take pictures against the palace.We arrived around 2 pm and there were so many tourists there, I wish we arrived earlier, it would probably be nicer and less crowded.

Beautiful grounds to explore filled with heritage and history and pride for nationality. Photographers paradise. Beautiful gardens, seemed to be a popular place for children and teens to go dressed in traditional clothing to take photos - which I was told would be as gifts for family. As a young western woman a lot of the young girls asked for selfies with me which I was happy to oblige and I returned the favour they looked stunning in their traditional dress. In places it did feel a little busy- lots of people around. But at no point did it feel overwhelming. I got used to the fact that Seoul as a place was densely populated so figured everywhere you went would be people in large numbers. I loved the juxtaposition of the placement of the place cradled between modern buildings all around was this nugget of history within the city. Make sure you go with a full battery on your camera or phone. Much needed. You can enjoy a traditional tea ceremony too. Plenty of literature also to inform all those niggling questions. A great day out. A lot is in the direct sunlight so if there in summer bring suncream and some coverage but once you get to the gardens there is plenty of cover in the shade.
I went at 9am before the crowds. A delightful way to spend and an hour or two wandering around beautiful palaces and even some wildlife to see!

With a view of the mountain in the background, it's a paradise for photography enthusiasts. Lots of history behind this palace and if you time do checkout the museum to learn about the history. They have free guided tours in English.

Kingdom in the middle of the city. Tourist crowds at this attraction because of its beautiful structure and interesting facts about Korean history. The palace does really get crowded with different tour groups so it's really hard to find a good spot for beautiful shots without tourists around. Overall it's interesting and worth the visit!

Gyeongbokgung Palace is very historical. Our tourist guide said that it was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty built in 1395. I was so amazed when i knew about it that this palace was so old yet the structure is firm.

This is a must see if you are visiting Seoul. It's beautiful and full of history. Very inexpensive stop and you can take endless photos. You will also see many people dressed in traditional outfits walking around. I loved it.
we only spend a short time to see a couple of palaces and this one had a nice changing of the guards
its was really interesting to see the Gyeongbokkgung Place. Whit the Metro its just to easy to find it.

I give this 4 ratings because objectively, it is an amazing place though, honesty, it is not my favorite. Why? this place is crowded (like really crowded) and way too large (it takes hours to go round and check out the castle area). If you are really interested and eager to visit this place, plus you are a history geek, go ahead. But if you only want to take a beautiful picture in a typical Korean castle so you are able to post it on your social media, you'd better check other castle (e.g. Changdeokgung Palace). Other castle is just as beautiful and way less crowded. But, the thing is, this palace is like a must-visit-place when you are in Seoul, so it's all up to you. Once again, it's nice place but not my personal favorite.

This Palace is very renowned for the Kings of Ancient Korean Dynasty, its a Must Visit Place to know the Korean Dynasty History and Their Culture. The Ticket Prices are very Low and make sure you go on a Weekday, weekends are usually over Crowded.

Quite a cool place for pictures, palace is quite big so some substantial walking is needed. Has heritage and convenient mountains at the background while taking pictures. Good that there were no high rise buildings on that side of the city

The area is very big and alot to see. But it's hard to take a good picture at the gate because it's always full of people. The sightseeing inside much more tranquil. I was in there at 11a.m and got a chance to see the guard changing. They only walked a few feet long so if you want to take picture, you have to be very quick

Gyeongbokgung Palace is the perfect place to go to learn about Korean history. It's 3,000 won (about $3) per adult and they have English tours at 11am, 1:30pm and 3:30pm. The palace complex includes two museums. One is about the royal families and the other is about the commoners. They do have activities/buildings you need to book in advance so look into that if you want more than the walkthrough.

The Gyeongbokgung palace is nestled slightly north of Seoul and is walkable if you are staying in there myeongdong neighborhood of Seoul. The palace has several layers and houses multiple palaces. If you continue to walk in, you will enter the folk museum. Great place to hang out and enjoy history.
I did the self guided audio tour and was very happy with it. The palace and grounds are beautiful. I was there very early at opening and the crowds were small on a Saturday morning.
It was a very nice palace to be around in seoul,with absolutely gorgeous nature and history of korea..Its must see if some one visit seoul.

Not to be missed in your itinerary when you go to Seoul. You should go early to witness the first changing of guards which is really amazing. They have a free fit of guards costume. Affordable 3000krw for entry.

OH MY GOD! This is a huge area with lots of palaces all connected to each other that makes the whole place feel like a maze!The biuldings are beautiful and the architecture is superb. The decorations are really nice! Just one problem though, there wasn't enouh info about the places in this palace. We didn't want to walk with a tour and wanted to look around on our own pace so we didb't get much info.There's a good resting place with food and drinks and souvenir shop at the entrance. you can get a hanbok and wear it while you go around.

The guard-changing ceremony in the first courtyard (with the ticket sale counters) would be quite worthwhile watching.The entrance to the palace grounds from Gwanghwamun gate looks quite ordinary, but once you get past all the initial buildings and explore the grounds, it's very beautiful with all the trees and lakes. There are very signboards explaining the buildings' histories or usages. If I had gone with the free tour (set times), I'd probably have been more interested in the buildings!
Beautiful place, great to visit on a sunny day. Free English tour is available. There are also nice performances, so you will enjoy your walk.
We visited the palace during the Thanksgiving period. Free entrance was a bonus, but would willingly have paid the admittance fee. What a beautiful, relaxing, serene place. Wonderful!!!
You should go and see this place. It is like movies.nice and good for walking. It is really big as well !

The decorations are really nice! Just one problem though, there wasn't enouh info about the places in this palace. We didn't want to walk with a tour and wanted to look around on our own pace so we didb't get much info.There's a good resting place with food and drinks and souvenir shop at the entrance. you can get a hanbok and wear it while you go around.

The guard-changing ceremony in the first courtyard (with the ticket sale counters) would be quite worthwhile watching.The entrance to the palace grounds from Gwanghwamun gate looks quite ordinary, but once you get past all the initial buildings and explore the grounds, it's very beautiful with all the trees and lakes. There are very signboards explaining the buildings' histories or usages. If I had gone with the free tour (set times), I'd probably have been more interested in the buildings!
Beautiful place, great to visit on a sunny day. Free English tour is available. There are also nice performances, so you will enjoy your walk.
We visited the palace during the Thanksgiving period. Free entrance was a bonus, but would willingly have paid the admittance fee. What a beautiful, relaxing, serene place. Wonderful!!!
You should go and see this place. It is like movies.nice and good for walking. It is really big as well !
Lovely palace to walk round on a beautiful day.There are many buildings and a secret garden.Very cheap entrance fee.

This is my second time visiting. This palace is the biggest, oldest & main of the 5 palaces. This palace is huge so it takes a couple of hours at least that you need to wear comfortable shoes! It's located the center of seoul & surrounded by high buildings. You would enjoy relaxing & seeing the gorgeous palace!!

Been here a couple of times but not in Fall. We manage to watch 2 series of changing of Guards at 12 and then at 2 pm. It is worth the stroll and stay to visit the palace. It is a very big palace, make sure you are in a pair comfortable walking shoes if you want to comb every corner of the palace. This is a ticket paying place of interest. Check out the timing of the performance and the translation guide and price before you go.  It is very interesting naming of the each courts in the palace. As both my Friend and I are in the management position, we identified these names and derived that the King needs to hear, think and consult before making a decision based on the proposals submitted by his officials. We love the doors and took some great pictures of the doors of each courts, the libraries etc. Go with a narrator so you can understand the history better.

This place is an absolute must see in Seoul. Its a huge palace complex with lots of history. Should be combined with Bukchok hanok village and Changdeokgung Palace since these are close by and will give a great portion of historic Seoul.If you really are someone who likes to walk I would recommend the following route.Start from Gwanghwamun station (or City hall station and pass Gwanghwamun gate) and follow the main street towards Gwanghwamun Square. Here you will see two huge statues, The statue of the Admiral Yi Sun-sin and Statue of King Sejong. Then just walk towards Gwanghwamun Gate and into Gyeongbokgung Palace. Then take trip into the The folk museum of korea and head up to Bukchok Hanok village. when you get back down from the village, have a nice lunch and head into the Changdeokgung Palace which is just next to the village entrance. When you're done go passed Anguk station and straight into Insadong. Do no visit insadong early in the morning. Go all the way through Insadong and down to Cheonggyecheon Stream. Follow it to the right(towards city hall) and you will eventually come back to your starting point.
A very beautiful palace and garden, even our 4 yo daughter loved it much!! A must visit when in Seoul. Come earlier as this palace gets very crowded with tourists
There is so much to see but start with the changing of the guards at 10 am. This palace like many others has so much history but the grounds, though rebuilt also retells its history very well.

I love the Palace - but I've been before. The place is wonderful, historically important and deeply significant for everyone to visit. Be sure to get a proper guide to the architecture. Be sure to get a proper guide for the historical significance of the place. Make sure that whomever gives you a tour has a good sense of the history, architecture, and significance of S. Korea within Asia. Knowing what you are seeing adds very much to the experience!

This is one of half-a-dozen Palaces and holy places you need to visit in Seoul. You can buy a serial ticket to five attractions for 10000 Korean wons. It is truly amazing to see how these old buildings fit in with the otherwise so modernized city.
Just a beautiful historical i am amazed by the culture also keeping the palace well maintain i would love to come back !!!!

We went to this palace at 9am. It's the perfect time to go as it isn't very busy at this time. We got an audio guide as well as the guide book. It was very informative and we found it sufficient. It took us about 2 hrs to walk the entire grounds. They also do have a free English tour at 11am however it is busy at this time with a lot of school groups.
Lovely palace to walk round on a beautiful day.There are many buildings and a secret garden.Very cheap entrance fee.

Just a beautiful historical i am amazed by the culture also keeping the palace well maintain i would love to come back !!!!

We went to this palace at 9am. It's the perfect time to go as it isn't very busy at this time. We got an audio guide as well as the guide book. It was very informative and we found it sufficient. It took us about 2 hrs to walk the entire grounds. They also do have a free English tour at 11am however it is busy at this time with a lot of school groups.

I did a quick visit - ($2.50 USD each) overall worthwhile with the travel tours as well as the changing of the guards. Definitely worth a visit and even more so if you have kids. I would definitely say its worth the value!
First royal palace that you have to visit if you come to Seoul.Do not forget to take selfies with its guardians!

A good place to hang around. You need to buy tickets to enter. Currency exchange also available near the tickets counter. This palace is large and to see everything you need to do a lot walking. You can try out the traditional costumes of the palace FOC. They'll dress you. You can find costume changing location is in your left side after passing the main entrance.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a great place to explore and learn more about what it was like back in the day, there are also free English tours available.There are also 2 free museums located in the palace as well. I was lucky to have gotten in for free, I don't know what event it was but that was very nice. A really gorgeous place.

As the main palace complex, Gyeongbokgung stands as the biggest. There are a lot of things to see in this complex; thus, a guided tour is recommended if you have time to spare. As my friends and I were pressed for time, we just spent around an hour walking around the palace grounds while waiting for the Gate Guard Change Ceremony. Avoid visiting this place on sunny summer days, as the heat may be too unbearable. The complex also houses the National Palace Museum of Korea which has interesting exhibits and a quirky gift shop/cafe where you can stay in to cool down from the heat.

We spent a few hours here this week. Its a truly massive place and its quite busy with tourists. Head through the main gate, watch the changing of the guard (though this is not official - just actors) then spend some time in the museum to get a good overview of the place. Then my suggestion is go further back to get away from the people. You'll enjoy your time here!

The palace complex is so huge~~ only walking around, it took 2hours to finish! But the palace was really beautiful and could see Korean's art and culture! I loved the pond and the small library at the back of it. It was Hyangwon or something. It was really beautiful! Highly recommend to visit here! Go~~!

Needs ability to walk and climb stairs huge property . Lovely grounds I went there during choseok and we were not charged a fee or else you have to pay a nominal amount to get in. Next to the palace is a Museum which is worth a visit. The Korean people are very gracious and helpful.

Well, this palace area is really big, a lot of similar looking palaces and houses and a lot of tourists too, because it's the most famous palace in Seoul. Nevertheless, I think it's mandatory to see this when visiting Seoul. Plus, you get free entrance to a nice museum, to escape the heat like we did when we visitied.
We had a Seoul pass which meant we could see all 5, we saw this one third after spending alot of time walking around the other two, which we felt we could've skipped and just go to this one.

I did a quick visit - ($2.50 USD each) overall worthwhile with the travel tours as well as the changing of the guards. Definitely worth a visit and even more so if you have kids. I would definitely say its worth the value!

Nevertheless, I think it's mandatory to see this when visiting Seoul. Plus, you get free entrance to a nice museum, to escape the heat like we did when we visitied.
We had a Seoul pass which meant we could see all 5, we saw this one third after spending alot of time walking around the other two, which we felt we could've skipped and just go to this one.

The palace is located at the centre of the city and accessible by subway. The opening hour is 9:00am. It would be better if you could get there in early hours, as tons of people visit there and it gets quite crowded. It is very interesting to see a bit of old times and culture. There is a big building near the water that you can go inside and take a look, but it requires a reservation at least one day prior. If you would like to see that building, I would recommend that you should check the information in advance.

Hanbok is Korean traditional costume and you can rent it around the palace and Insadong. I rent it at Insadong. The reason I mentioned it is I strongly recommend to visit THIS palace in Hanbok if you want to life long valuable picture in Korea! Also entrance fee is free when you are in Hanbok. Go to the ticket box and ask the tickets. Then you will get free tickets. It's very special experience walking in the historical site in tradtional costume. It was very exciting! The building was very great and felt that I was back in the days during Joseon Dynasty! Oh also this place is huge! Keep in mind !

remember to wear shoe to visit this place, as u need to hv long walk and the floor is not flat. sometimes u might need to climb abit and downhill walking.alot of scenery that u might want to take picture, standby ur camera n memory cards. hehe. If you want to see some palace activity like changing shift, make sure to be there before 10am.

Gyeongbokgung Palace kept my attention for several hours when I visited. Its grounds are large and the palaces are beautiful! The entrance fee was $3 which enables a visit to their museum as well. It was well worth the time and $3.

This palace is simply awesome. If you have less time in Seoul to visit other palaces, this palace should not be missed out. The area is very big and the architecture reflects korea's tradition.Changing of guards in different time slots is worth to see. Entrance fee was affordable as well. If anybody wants to hang around the palace in Korean traditional dress (hanbok) either men or woman, I would recommended to hire it and wear before you enter the palace from nearby renting shop.

"When you go there, you might get surprized at it since it's located in the center of Seoul! for me it was great to see since you can find modern and old at a time there! Gwanghwamun? is the main gate of this palace and you can find guards in traditional costume! looks cool to take picture with them! Change of guard ceremony was 10am, it's something! Don't miss it! When my family went there, we dressed up in Hanbok which is Korean traditional costume! If you are in Hanbok, then entrance fee, 3000KRW is free!Anyway it's really fun to go around the palace in Hanbok! We got really good pictures for life! I never forget this special experience

Loved the sight of it as my taxi went down the long road to the main gates and lucky enough to catch the changing of the guard. The place is awesome but there's nothing in it !!! Not their fault as the Japanese burnt it down when they invaded years ago and it took em 200 years to put it right but still a must see and glad I went, and so were they at the end !!! Only joking they loved me
A vast area to visit. Not so recommended on a sunny day. It is quite a nice place to visit. The change of guard is also something that cannot missed.

Maybe for a western visitor like me not used to see places like this it represents an unforgettable experience and for all the visiting time it is like you travel in the past and it is possible to imagine most of the events that until that moment you have just seen in a movie!! real suggestive I higly recommend a visit.

This place is really nice to see, is it really pretty and when they do the dances and other shows is really pretty and so much culture. There is a lot of walking, it is bigger than it seems when you first walk in. Side note: If you go during the summer like we did, make sure you take an umbrella a lot of water and sun screen.

This place is really nice to see, is it really pretty and when they do the dances and other shows is really pretty and so much culture. There is a lot of walking, it is bigger than it seems when you first walk in. Side note: If you go during the summer like we did, make sure you take an umbrella a lot of water and sun screen.

Visiting royal palaces in South Korea produced in me in the long term the same effect of visiting many Buddhist temples in Thailand: they look like very similar, even though size of buildings inside may change. However Gyeongbokgung Palace deserves a visit especially for the very nice entry gate and the change of guard ceremony (held twice a day, at 10am and 2pm), the last one being very solemn. I visited the palace during the day and I must admit that the atmosphere was not so enticing as it could be during night. Free guided tours in English are also offered, which I found very useful to understand a bit more the history of royal families in South Korea.
If you only have time to visit one palace in Seoul, this is the one you should visit. I recommend checking the time the royal guard will change, so you can watch the ceremony.

Gyongbokgung Palace is located not far away from CitiHall Station, walk only 15 minutes north bound following the modern road at the down town Seoul. It is the popular destination of Seoul visitors. The environment of ancient palace of Joseon Dynasty is well maintained and fully restored. The most waited attraction is palace guard changing. The complex is vast and need some time visit and to understand the historic means of the palace.

I went there in the weekend it was busy and full of people. it was very large that you could enjoy taking pictures of different spots. three different performances are presented a day, attending one of them is enough they all seem the same and very simple. I would command the large changing ceremony. the palace is recommended for people who are interested in history and architect.

The first of Seoul's palaces we visited, and by far the most impressive. Incredible architecture & fantastic English guide, who explained so much in so little time. The changing of the guards ceremony was also worth staying to see. Really worth visiting.

The place is just marvelous. This is where no-filter IG-worthy pictures are made of. You can join the tours and watch the changing of guards. The entry fee is cheap like around 2,000 won only and there's a lot to see here.
It's been there over a thousand years in spite of the Japanese burning it down twice. There is a free tour with an English speaking docent that I highly recommend.
We got the audio guides and walked around by ourselves on a sunny Saturday. It was fabulous - definitely a must see.
This was very informative about Korean culture and how they lived and suffered from the Japanese. What a major historical reconstruction effort for the Korean people. This is worth a visit.

Geongbok palace reminded me Korean Historical Dramas, I was walking in the palace in Hanbok which is a traditional costume which is so beautiful, and you know what? If you are in Hanbok then no entrance fee :) 3000krw though Highly recommend to visit in Hannok

We had a private guided tour and this of course was extremely helpful. It is a large complex with a museum - good written explanation as you go with some interactive displays. Very informative and interesting for a European with little knowledge of Korea and its history.

Visited last September 17, 2016. If you are a sucker for history and architecture, then this shouldn't be missed when touring Korea! All the palaces are instagram-worthy! The palace is so huge that an hour is not enough! It's like a Mini "Forbidden City in Beijing" STUNNINGLY BEAUTIFUL!
One of the most amazing places I've been in the world. If you can, go early during the day since the afternoon is crowded.

Nice photos to take, but if without a guide its boring, however i guess you can read about it beforehand so that you can enjoy more. Takes around 1 hour to 2 hours depending on how much photos you take :)There is an option of a combo ticket for 4 palaces and a temple, but although i bought it i do not recommend you do it unless you really enjoy this repetetive rooms and buildings :)May be just one palace and one temple would be ebough, so no need to pay for the combo ticket Try not to miss the guard changing ceremony and take photos witg the guards. So do go early (not after 1:30 pm) to be able to attend one of them (held each 15 minutes i guess)

It is one of the most important places in Seoul! If you are intersted in history and Korean culture in general dont miss it! They do English tours for free to explain the hlights of this great plalace! You will see many Koreans wearing traditional clothes which is super cool!

Its really easy to reach this palace. You can take subway then stop at Gyeongbok gung palace station. The interesting thing is you can rent Hanbook and you can feel as korean woman/man. Don't forget to watch replacement of bodyguard of this palace in the morning and also noon. Really recommended.

This place is great for all types of travelers. It allows those who like history to be able to read and see about a Korean Dynasty. For those who like architecture and cool structures, it gives you a ton to see and lots of detail to explore. And those who like to just go and walk for a little while, it gives you freedom to explore to your liking. Our favorite part was seeing the changing of the guards and the guard performance at the front gate. And not to mention all the children dressed in authentic Korean clothing while on their school field trips....just adorable! We would totally visit here again.
Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the five (5) major palaces in Seoul. If you can, avoid the visit on a weekend as the place becomes very crowded.

We visited the palace as it's a must for tourists. The palace wasn't huge so it only took around 45 minutes. (Disclaimer: we didn't have a guide or book tour so it was just purely browsing)The guards at the front gate were interesting and the shift swap process was entertaining. I would recommend a visit.

The buildings are amazing and gorgeous. The place is ginormous, so be prepared to walk if you want to stay a while and venture around. There is also a free museum that doesn't require a ticket to get in, unlike The Palace. It would have been nice if there were placards or even a recording in English to understand what each building was used for. Either way, the grounds are beautiful. We went on the wrong day, it was during the holiday and it was packed! We probably would have spent more time there if not for all the people.

And those who like to just go and walk for a little while, it gives you freedom to explore to your liking. Our favorite part was seeing the changing of the guards and the guard performance at the front gate. And not to mention all the children dressed in authentic Korean clothing while on their school field trips....just adorable! We would totally visit here again.
Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the five (5) major palaces in Seoul. If you can, avoid the visit on a weekend as the place becomes very crowded.

We visited the palace as it's a must for tourists. The palace wasn't huge so it only took around 45 minutes. (Disclaimer: we didn't have a guide or book tour so it was just purely browsing)The guards at the front gate were interesting and the shift swap process was entertaining. I would recommend a visit.

The buildings are amazing and gorgeous. The place is ginormous, so be prepared to walk if you want to stay a while and venture around. There is also a free museum that doesn't require a ticket to get in, unlike The Palace. It would have been nice if there were placards or even a recording in English to understand what each building was used for. Either way, the grounds are beautiful. We went on the wrong day, it was during the holiday and it was packed! We probably would have spent more time there if not for all the people.

I was taken here as part of an organised business tour. The palace is well worth a visit, covering extensive grounds. We arrived in time to see the staged changing of the guard, which was a great spectacle. I most enjoyed the lake and gardens.

There are a few palaces in Seoul and i believe this is the most significant. There is a museum outside of the palace and it is a good way to relax in the museum after wandering around in the palace under the sun.

Great for a visit during the day - take in the changing of the guard. Even better if you can visit in the evening - the Pavilion lit up with the sunset over the mountains was magical. We managed an evening visit when there was a musical evening. Very atmospheric with many visitors dressed in traditional costume.

It's amazing being able to visit this palace thanks to major restorations and rebuilding. It is a small version of the Forbidden City in Beijing which reminds us of China's historical and cultural influence over Asia.The admission was free because of Korean Thanksgiving when we visited but I would say it's worth it. There is not many historical sites inside Seoul so this one is a must.The metro stops right at the entrance.

The grounds here are beautiful and the structures are as well. The insides, the ceilings particularly are very intricate and colorful but nothing is original because 90% of it was torn down during Japanese occupation which is a shame. The restoration and rebuilding of the structures is very nice, so it is nice to imagine how it would have looked. There are also plaques all around that explain the buildings and it is worth looking up online before you go, but I wouldn't pay for a tour. I was teaching in Seoul and took my family (who was visiting) here in July of 2015 and they enjoyed it but once you have seen one palace in Korea you have seen them all. Doing the hop-on-hop-off bus tour is your best bet! Then you can spend as much time as you would like and move on.

We arrived just in time to watch the guard change over. Three mins in it chucks it down leading them to canceling the change over. Don't want to get their costumes and props wet I guess. Still worth getting a ticket as the palace is huge and the foreign escort place surrounded by water was pretty. The folk museum was good too.
Please join the free guided tour so that you know the history of the palace. The place is quite big, you can spend the whole day inside. You get free entry if you are in hanbok.

This is one of the main and most visited attractions in Seoul, a large palace ground that depicted the rich and long history and culture of the country.We came by here as part of our city tour and it was crowded when we arrived with mostly foreign visitors. The palace is nice with lovely architectural building designs of the ancient times, to some extent, similar to the Chinese versions (no doubt because the country was with good ties with China in the ancient times and thus more or less being influenced by it), nice lakes and ponds with lots of greenery.What is interesting is the schedule of the "change of ancient guard" ceremony at selected timings where soldiers who were dressed in ancient and traditional Korean costumes, marching in and is impressive and usually this scene attracted most crowds. One can also change into these traditional costumes to walk around and take photos.Many visitors here would like to compare it with the other Changdeokgung palace (please refer to my earlier review here too), that is also located nearby. The latter is smaller in size and has much lesser to see but overall with similar themed buildings. We were told by the guide that the reigning king would stay in the former palace while retired king would reside at the latter.However, do take note that the palace is closed on every Tuesday (while Changdeokgung is closed on Monday).It's an interesting place to visit and be prepared to spend at least 1.5-2 hours to be able to see substantial things here and remember also bring an umbrella, hat and bottles of drinking water as it was very sunny and warm during our visit there. (there is also guided tours but do check out the specific timing of the tours at the information counter)Recommended.
It's big, it's beautiful but if you shall get the most of the visit you should be there before 2pm and get a good spot to watch the change of the guards.

Looked very lovely - but should be open all days . I arroved in Seoul on a Sunday, but was wrecked. So was all geared up on Monday for a day of sight seeing - Nothing open. Plan ahead. Not too disappointed as this was a business trip and so sightseeing was not the primary reason for visit!

I was taken here as part of an organised business tour. The palace is well worth a visit, covering extensive grounds. We arrived in time to see the staged changing of the guard, which was a great spectacle. I most enjoyed the lake and gardens.

There are a few palaces in Seoul and i believe this is the most significant. There is a museum outside of the palace and it is a good way to relax in the museum after wandering around in the palace under the sun.

We managed an evening visit when there was a musical evening. Very atmospheric with many visitors dressed in traditional costume.

There is not many historical sites inside Seoul so this one is a must.The metro stops right at the entrance.

There are also plaques all around that explain the buildings and it is worth looking up online before you go, but I wouldn't pay for a tour. Doing the hop-on-hop-off bus tour is your best bet! Then you can spend as much time as you would like and move on.

Looked very lovely - but should be open all days . I arroved in Seoul on a Sunday, but was wrecked. So was all geared up on Monday for a day of sight seeing - Nothing open. Plan ahead. Not too disappointed as this was a business trip and so sightseeing was not the primary reason for visit!

Eat. Sunblock. Comfy Shoes.The place is huge. Starts at 0900. You can try on the traditional dress and roam around the palace for free- just the dress. Entrance cost around 3500won. Afterwards, chill inside the national museum. If your lucky, you can watch the marching of guards. And so you know, tourist swarms all over the area.
The guards at the entrance very interesting. There is not much things to see inside. It was not crowded and probably you need 15 minutes to view the whole palace.

I'm not sure if its because I went on a slightly rainy day or if I didn't get to see the changing of the palace guards, but I didn't find Gyeongbukgung as spectacular as I'd hoped. Don't get me wrong, it's absolutely beautiful, larger than life, and really takes you back to what life was like back then for anyone living in the palace, but besides looking around and getting that blast from the past, it was just a [beautiful] building.However, it's worth a visit if you've never been to a Korean palace! It's always great learning about origins of great nations.
The fee is about 1,000 won =$1 USD. There a English tour in the palace but schedule time. Nice places to take pictures and nice ponds.

Though smaller than the Forbidden City in Beijing, there is quite a bit of the same sense of Asian greatness of this palace. On a quiet morning visit, it is easy to imagine how this place was once the pinnacle of a civllisation now transformed.The palace is located smack-bang in the middle of bustling Seoul, and although the megacity outside the walls is ever active, noisy and effeciently moving on, time somehow slows when inside. The noises of everyday-life are muffled, and a sense of awe is ever present.

The guard changing ceremony happens 4 times a day and I was lucky to watch it the moment I arrived. The place is huge but the buildings are quite similar. I can't enter any of the buildings except for the one in the picture. But that one visitors have to reserve entry a day before. There are a few explanation stands on what the building are but make sure to get the brochure from information counter so you get more understanding of the buildings from the visit.
Who knew that the Korean dynasty was so old or that the 4th king created to Korean language or that it died out because the 27th king was infertile?
Be sure to rent all a costume at a street leftside the palace. Ask the info for directions and get a 10k won discount coupon

I attended a group tour with Koridoor tours to Gyeongbokgung and several other historic sites around Seoul recently. Gyeongbokgung was by far my husband's and my favorite place on the tour. We enjoyed the changing of the guard ceremony when we first arrived, though it was crowded and a bit hard to see the action. After the ceremony, we toured around the palace grounds and were blown away by their beauty. This is a great place to take photos, relax, picnic, and get a history lesson. We plan to return to see the palace in more depth. It is a serene sanctuary right in the middle of Seoul!

You can spend 1 hour or half a day here. It's really up to you. It is very large and on the premise are also the Palace Museum and the National Folk Museum. The palace is beautiful. There are a lot of people wearing the traditional Korean clothes around and it is really nice. At two o'clock, there is a "guards changing" ceremony. If you happen to be there, I recommend it, but if you miss it, I don't think you should be sad. The two story structure shown requires Internet reservation a day in advance, so I was kind of bummed that I did not get to go in. I just walked around and took my time and worked up a good appetite for the yummy Korean food I had later.

Eat. Sunblock. Comfy Shoes.The place is huge. Starts at 0900. You can try on the traditional dress and roam around the palace for free- just the dress. Entrance cost around 3500won. Afterwards, chill inside the national museum. If your lucky, you can watch the marching of guards. And so you know, tourist swarms all over the area.
The guards at the entrance very interesting. There is not much things to see inside. It was not crowded and probably you need 15 minutes to view the whole palace.

It's always great learning about origins of great nations.

There are a few explanation stands on what the building are but make sure to get the brochure from information counter so you get more understanding of the buildings from the visit.

Be sure to rent all a costume at a street leftside the palace. Ask the info for directions and get a 10k won discount coupon

We enjoyed the changing of the guard ceremony when we first arrived, though it was crowded and a bit hard to see the action. After the ceremony, we toured around the palace grounds and were blown away by their beauty. This is a great place to take photos, relax, picnic, and get a history lesson. We plan to return to see the palace in more depth. It is a serene sanctuary right in the middle of Seoul!

You can spend 1 hour or half a day here. It's really up to you. It is very large and on the premise are also the Palace Museum and the National Folk Museum. The palace is beautiful. There are a lot of people wearing the traditional Korean clothes around and it is really nice. At two o'clock, there is a "guards changing" ceremony. If you happen to be there, I recommend it, but if you miss it, I don't think you should be sad. The two story structure shown requires Internet reservation a day in advance, so I was kind of bummed that I did not get to go in. I just walked around and took my time and worked up a good appetite for the yummy Korean food I had later.

This is definitely the must visit palace when you are in Seoul. This place is huge so be prepared to walk a lot. Entry is free if you are wearing Hanbok. If not, 6,000krw per pax. Hanbok can be rented from shops near the palace. We rented our Hanbok for 4 hours for 15,000krw per pax from a shop nearby.Be sure to take lots of photo of the palace.

The oldest and largest of all 5 palaces in Seoul. We signed up with the Seoul Tourism Board free walking tour and we had an English speaking guide. The guide gave us a detailed introduction of the whole palace. It is highly recommended that you visit the palace early as it got hotter during the late morning and there was no shade.
This was my favorite of the Seoul palaces-- don't miss it. Very large grounds to walk around and very impressive to look and and for photos.

The actual palace can only be observed through a wide opening. One cannot actually enter the palace buildings, one can just walk around them and get an impression how the royalty functioned in ancient times. The Koreans do their best to keep up old traditions and it is fun to see the guards dressed up in traditional attire and to see the Changing of the Guards ceremony. In the area there were many patriotic young Koreans walking around being photographed in traditional costumes that it is possible to rent for a few hours at the Hanok Center nearby. The colorful costumes and the Changing of the Guards make the place more interesting. When we were there it was very hot and there is very little shade. Take big hats/sunshades...

This is the number one place to visit for all first timers. Guaranteed you with lots of group tours and people with kids learning about the history. Huge place that takes up to 2 hours for a visit! Get the palace and jongmo shrine pass for easy/quick/best value access!

We visited five palace areas in Seoul, and liked them all. Gyeongbokgung palace is huge, and the scenery behind it is beautiful (mountains look gorgeous)! We ended up sitting by the pond with my friends for hours, just chatting and laughing. At one point the park guard had to come tell us to leave, because the park had closed. The atmosphere was very relaxed.Make sure to get the palace pass which gets you into all the five main palace areas in Seoul. It costs 10,000 won and can be bought at any ticket counter near the entryways.

I like this place very much. Learned about Korean history. It was very pretty and well kept. It was huge and exactly what we expected to see since I have watch lots of Korean movies and see the palace on screen before
The Changing of the Guard was a great photo opportunity. The palace itself is interesting and a nice contrast with modern Seoul right outside the walls.

A sprawling complex with many buildings. Take the tour. That is so helpful. One thing that we found enchanting was the presence of so many young Korean people dressed in native costumes. It was like stepping into the past.

On exiting the metro station, I was approached by a group of Korean youngsters offering tours of the Palace. My guide was a 15 year-old girl speaking perfect English. She was excellent. She refused a tip - said they were not allowed

This is definitely the must visit palace when you are in Seoul. This place is huge so be prepared to walk a lot. Entry is free if you are wearing Hanbok. If not, 6,000krw per pax. Hanbok can be rented from shops near the palace. We rented our Hanbok for 4 hours for 15,000krw per pax from a shop nearby.Be sure to take lots of photo of the palace.

The oldest and largest of all 5 palaces in Seoul. We signed up with the Seoul Tourism Board free walking tour and we had an English speaking guide. The guide gave us a detailed introduction of the whole palace. It is highly recommended that you visit the palace early as it got hotter during the late morning and there was no shade.
This was my favorite of the Seoul palaces-- don't miss it. Very large grounds to walk around and very impressive to look and and for photos.

The colorful costumes and the Changing of the Guards make the place more interesting. When we were there it was very hot and there is very little shade. Take big hats/sunshades...
